introduction: Provide you with the basic knowledge and understanding of ship powering and lifting surfaces used for ship control as required by a naval architect through theoretical and experimental techniques.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide you with the basic knowledge and understanding of ship powering and lifting surfaces used for ship control as required by a naval architect through theoretical and experimental techniques.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The components of ship resistance. [T, AE]
  • The operation of marine propulsion devices. [T, AE]
  • The estimation of the resistance of a ship or marine vehicle. [T, AE, AC]
  • The design of a propeller. [T, AE]
  • The components of propulsive efficiency and how to estimate them. [T, AE]
  • The estimation of the total delivered power of a ship or marine vehicle. [T, AE, AC]
  • The effect of control surfaces on ships. [T, AE]
  • The estimation of the lift and drag produced by control surfaces [T, AE, AC]

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Analyse the powering requirements of a ship or marine vehicle based on your understanding of the physical nature of the fluid flow around the vessel. [T, AE, AC]
  • Define and evaluate the forces generated by a foil through analysis based on simplifying assumptions. [T, AE, AC]

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Apply your understanding of the physical components of ship resistance to estimate the resistance of a ship or marine vehicle. [T, AE]
  • Use your understanding of a marine propeller in order to carry out a simple propeller design. [T, AC]
  • Apply your knowledge of the components of propulsive efficiency to estimate the total delivered power of a ship or marine vehicle. [T, AC]

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Use simple mathematical models, computational tools and empirical evidence to derive engineering estimates of physical quantities. [T, AE]
  • Use small-scale physical models to deduce full-scale quantities through a combination of testing and analysis based on first principles. [T, AE, AC]
  • Evaluate alternative models (e.g. analytical, computational, and physical) to determine the most appropriate for solving a specified engineering task. [T, AE, AC]

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Knowledge of design guidelines and approaches relevant to the discipline. Understand a problem from an engineering perspective and provide a technical solution.

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Derivation or implementation of existing knowledge and skills to provide solutions or approaches.

Practical, subject specific skills
Depending upon assignments there might be a combination of experimental testing, numerical simulation involving calculations and production of code (MATLAB or similar) and report writing.

Key transferable skills
Team working. Report production and presentation of technical material. Enhanced design experience and practical awareness.
learningoutcomes:
To increase students' experience of real acoustical engineering design in practice and applications of taught material from other modules. The work inormally nvolves group activities based around two separate investigations/problem solving and involves interaction, design, calculation/modelling and, where appropriate, measurements. It concludes with submission of a joint written report and, where there are external companies involved, oral presentations of the results and findings.

Examples for 2008/09 considered regulations for noise levels of broadcast adverts on TV (Semester I) and tender for a measurement system for the dynamics of refuelling hoses (Semester II for Flight Refuelling Ltd.)

 

To introduce design principles in acoustics and vibration and provide opportunity for the students to gain practical experience.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • develop essential knowledge and understanding of facts, principles and concepts of biology and the skills needed to use them in both familiar and unfamiliar situations;
  • develop an understanding of scientific methods;
  • encourage an awareness of advances in technology relevant to biology and how this may impact on society;
  • bring together knowledge and understanding of how different areas of biology relate to each other 

Objectives (planned learning outcomes) 

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: 

  • recognise, recall and show understanding of specific biological facts, terminology, principles, concepts, and practical techniques;
  • draw on existing knowledge to show understanding of the ethical, social, economic, environmental and technological implications and applications of biology;
  • select, organise and present relevant information clearly logically and using specialist vocabulary where appropriate;                 
  • use biological skills in contexts which bring together different areas of         the subject.                     

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • describe, explain and interpret phenomena and effects in terms of biological principles and concepts, presenting arguments and ideas clearly and logically, using specialist vocabulary where appropriate;
  • interpret and translate from one form to another, data presented as continuous prose, or in tables, diagrams, drawings and graphs;
  • apply biological principles and concepts in solving problems in unfamiliar situations including those which relate to ethical, social, economic and technological implications and applications of biology;
  • assess the validity of biological information, experiments, inferences and statements

General transferable (key) skills 

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • manage your own learning;
  • communicate scientific information effectively;
  • apply mathematical methods to solve problems in biology;
  • apply problem solving techniques to familiar and unfamiliar biological problems;
  • use IT to support learning

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Environmental traffic management and how it can be achieved.
  • How Intelligent Transport Systems can be used for managing traffic.
  • How urban public transport can be managed.
  • The management of road space and speed for all road users
  • The management of roadspace and vehicle speeds for all road users.
  • Traffic management evaluation methods.
  • Traffic management, control and information systems in urban and inter-urban networks.
  • Transport management methods in developing countries.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Identify the key opportunities and issues in traffic and transport.
  • Describe the key features of traffic management systems and appraise their potential for specific situations.
  • Analyse, design and evaluate traffic management schemes.
  • Interpret results from evaluation processes, including those based on network
  • Propose and evaluate alternative designs and options

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Prepare and produce drawings for specific traffic management schemes.

Key skills

  • Problem analysis and problem solving
  • Information handling
  • Report writing
  • Time management
  • Independent research
learningoutcomes: This module introduces you to the principles and current practice of Traffic and Transport Management related to Transportation Engineering on both urban and interurban roads. The aim is for you to gain knowledge and understanding of the range of traffic management and supporting Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) applications available for improved efficiency and safety of road traffic, and design/evaluation skills relating to the these applications and their integration.

introduction:
Studying is not simply about transferring a set of facts from lecturer to students, but about
developing yourself as an individual and recognising that you are responsible for your own learning.
Knowledge in the 21st century is fast moving and in such a knowledge economy, where the shelf life
of much knowledge is short, you will be expected to be a lifelong learner. In order to do this, you
need to a resilient learner, understand how you best learn and reflect on how you can improve.
This module will help you actively engage with this process.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Enhance your ability to study in an efficient and effective manner.
  • Introduce you to HE study methods and requirements
  • Introduce you to problem solving and solution checking techniques

  • Help you develop you potential as an HE student

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding - Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The requirements for academic integrity
  • How to approach problem solving in a structured way
  • How to receive, evaluate and reflect on feedback on your progress in HE
  • How to use a set of resources to make progress with your learning

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Manage your own learning
  • Apply structured methods to solve problems
  • Apply problem solving techniques to familiar and unfamiliar problems
  • Use IT to support your learning
  • Make a critical evaluation of evidence

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Show familiarity with noise control requirements, including main EU legislation applying to products.
  • Use common units of noise measurement, including mean-square pressure, decibel units and reference values, frequency spectra and the A-weighted level.
  • Characterise noise sources according to their physical behaviour, acoustic efficiency, frequency spectrum and dependence on operational speed.
  • Be familiar with standard methods for the measurement of sound power, their advantages and limitations.
  • Distinguish the main principles of noise control and understand the typical frequency dependence of noise control systems.
  • Use simple models for the sound radiation of common sources including plates.
  • Use appropriate formulae for the sound transmission through partitions.
  • Understand the relation between surface impedance and absorption coefficient and the influence of the main physical parameters.
  • Determine the effects of vibration isolation using a mobility model.
  • Explain the influence of damping and the main means of achieving it.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Evaluate the performance of appropriate noise control techniques for the solution of practical noise problems.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply the noise control techniques considered in an integrated way to a practical design case.

Key transferable skills

Write a report suitable for a client or manager.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Introduce the requirements, principles and methods of noise control.
  • Provide basic knowledge and understanding of noise control necessary for professional practice as a noise control engineer.
  • Encourage the application of this knowledge to practical problems.

  • To describe the basis of how to set targets for noise control.
  • To explain how to characterise, categorise, quantify and identify noise sources.
  • To introduce the main principles of noise control available to the engineer and to place them in a logical framework.
  • To derive the performance of noise control systems using simple mathematical models.
  • To describe physical characteristics of noise control systems and their application in practice.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the tasks and responsibilities involved in managing and contributing to a large engineering project. Depending on the topic of your project and your role in the team, you will also have the opportunity to learn more on specific technical topics.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
Define the technical specifications of an engineering system and the associated targets in terms of costs and time scales
Explore and develop different designs to achieve the objectives
Apply scientific knowledge to model an acoustical problem.
Assess the relative merit of different designs against a variety of criteria (e.g. technical quality, costs, complexity, risks, environmental impact, etc).
Choose a solution to a complex engineering problem guided by sometimes competing objectives.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: Implement a design to a stage where it can be commissioned and used (e.g. by providing drawings, programs, etc). Commission and control the delivery and assembly of an equipment. Test and validate an engineering system.

Key transferable skills
Synthesise and critically review technical information from different sources and on different topics. Work and communicate efficiently in a team. Provide clear and informative reports and presentations. Define, plan and monitor the conduct of a group project. Identify and acquire the additional skills and knowledge required to complete a new task/project.
learningoutcomes:
The specific aim of this module is to train you to design an original solution to a realistic problem in acoustical engineering. The focus is also on defining, managing and implementing an open-ended group project.


To improve team working and communication skill
To consolidate project management skills seen in other taught module
To develop the ability to work on open-ended group project in a context similar to what you cou experience in industry.
To develop the skills and experience for designing a solution to a complex engineering problem.

introduction:
The project is a learning experience that enables you to apply your conceptual knowledge to an engineering design problem. You should also bear in mind wider aspects such as the (a) social, (b) economic, (c) environmental, (d) cultural, (e) and sustainability issues related to the subject matter of the project. Working in groups you will meet regularly with your supervisor and any external sponsor, develop your team working, plan your project, present your work through meetings with your supervisor, sponsor and assessor, prepare and submit reports and oral presentations. At all times you will monitor your progress as a team to ensure you are achieving the objectives set while ensuring quality of output.

CONSULT THE GDP GUIDELINES ON BLACKBOARD for full details regarding the planning and progress of the project, meetings, forms required and important deadlines.

introduction:
The Undergraduate Ambassador Scheme was initially founded to encourage graduates to consider teaching as a career, particularly in shortage subject areas (maths, sciences), and is currently available in other Faculties within the University of Southampton as well as in other universities. However, importantly this module aims to provide you with teaching experience and valuable transferable skills. The module has no formal lectures, but instead involves you spending time outside university within a local school (primary, secondary or tertiary) for approximately ½ day a week for a full semester (10 weeks) supported by tutorials at university. During the placements, you will initially observe teaching but gradually become more involved in the classroom, ultimately carrying out a special project with pupils. As you will be acting as a role model within a local school and due to the limited number of placements, there is an interview process. This also serves to match you with an appropriate school and teacher, based on your preferences and what you want to get from the module.

The module is reliant on placements being secured in local primary, secondary schools or tertiary colleges, which limits the number of students that this module can be made available to. A cap of about 20 students is a reasonable estimate. It is therefore important to select students based on an application form and interview process to assess their suitability for the module and to act as representatives of the University. A Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) check is also necessary before placements can commence, therefore participation on this module cannot be guaranteed to all students that pass the interview
learningoutcomes:
To develop an appreciation of what it takes to be a teacher and absorb some of the requisite skills.
To develop communication and organisational skills and to learn to understand and address other individuals' needs, particularly in a learning context.
To develop ideas for presentation that will provide inspiration for learning.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The needs of different learners in institutional settings and how appropriate teaching methods might address these. (D,AC)
  • The multi-faceted nature of teaching to a variety of individuals with different sets of needs in potentially unpredictable circumstances. (D,AC, AP)


Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Develop and plan teaching materials which are appropriate for the relevant age or standard. (D,AC,AP)
  • Modify and redesign subject material in different ways in order to reach a wider audience. (D,AC,AP)
  • Identify material that represents a source of intellectual excitement and hence worthy of careful study. (D,AC,AP)


Practical and General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Provide support and assistance to teachers in a responsible and confident manner, thus developing skills for collaboration and teamwork. (D,AC)
  • Develop communication and organisational skills. (D,AC,AP)
  • Make up lesson plans and teaching materials. (D,AC)
  • Assess and respond to challenging circumstances in a public forum. (D,AC,AP)
  • Improvise in a responsible way. (A,AC, AP)
  • Provide reflective feedback to others. (A,AC)

introduction: This module introduces students to both the theoretical and practical aspects of systems reliability and design for improved reliability. Lectures on the theory of systems reliability will be followed by practical tutorial sessions where students will apply their knowledge on a variety of problems.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Emphasize the importance of systematic use of reliability engineering methodologies in the early design stages of complex products
  • Allow students to apply systems reliability concepts and techniques to an engineering design project in the field of unmanned vehicle systems

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Mathematical foundations in stochastic processes and their applications into systems reliability modelling
  • Computational models to simulate complex interactions of sub-systems and their effects on the overall reliability of the system
  • The importance of project management skills

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Critically analyse complex systems by applying engineering knowledge and specific techniques in order to reduce the frequency of system failures
  • Identify and remedy the root causes of failures in complex systems
  • Develop strategies to mitigate the effects of unpreventable sub-system failures
  • Estimate the reliability behaviour of new systems

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn and research independently
  • Collate and synthesise/prioritise information according to systems reliability aspects
  • Develop computational models to simulate stochastic behaviour of complex systems reliability
  • Communicate your work in written reports

This module aims to provide students with an architectural understanding that relates broad contextual thinking to precise and detailed design decisions enabling clear and professional communication of plans and ideas appropriate to our time. The module will build on and develop key concepts introduced in Architecture 1 and establish a sound and comprehensive basis for maturing through Architecture 3 and 4.

This involves developing an understanding of the relevance of current thinking on environment, culture, the arts and science and it engages students in the design of architectural elements and space at scales ranging from detail and construction to building concepts and structures to urban configurations and land use. In this way, and supported by a range of appropriate case studies, students begin to think and design holistically whilst acquiring a precise and professional skill base that enables the effective communication of ideas and actions.

Students will also develop a practical understanding of the principles of domestic construction detailing and specification. Students will be able to realise bespoke solutions from first principles through a coordinated, sustainable and creative approach to construction detailing at a domestic scale.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
Aims

To introduce the basic concepts associated with the behaviour of sound and applications of acoustics in the underwater environment. Underwater Acoustics 1 will incorporate proofs of basic relevant physics and describe the range of environments and applications. Though much of the work relates to the ocean environment, sections on non-linear and biomedical ultrasonics are also included. It is important that the student grasp the basic physics underlying the mathematical proofs, in preparation for Underwater Acoustics 2.

Objectives (teaching)

The student should feel comfortable with the underlying physical processes governing sound and ultrasound in liquids, and be able as a consequence to explore similarities between sound in the ocean and ultrasound in the body, and extrapolate to new circumstances through discussion. By the end of the course the class should also have gained the skill of critically assessing the way material is simplified in order to present a coherent story (lecture course, journal paper, web page) to the intended audience, and the limitations this imposes upon the material. Thus material should be placed in the wider context of their past experience, and the diversity of past experience they had appreciated exists in the rest of the class.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

The class should bring together their diverse backgrounds as they first learn basic acoustics, as applied in the ocean environment, obtaining a 'physical feel' for the underlying mechanisms (in preparation for the maths of Underwater Acoustics 2). However they should know the full mathematical descriptions accompanying the material on nonlinear propagation, whilst appreciating the common mechanisms which operate, and are exploited, in common applications of ocean and biomedical acoustics.

Cognitive (thinking) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to underwater acoustics and biomedical ultrasonics.

Describe certain key discoveries and characteristics of underwater acoustics, nonlinear propagation and biomedical ultrasonics.

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide an understanding of fundamental knowledge and techniques of control.
  • To develop tools to analyse control engineering problems by MATLAB software package.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Familiarise the students with various input/output descriptions of dynamic systems
  • Familiarise with frequency domain descriptions and dynamic analysis.
  • Understand the concept of stability concepts and effect of feedback control on sensitivity.
  • Apply the basic methods of classical control system design such as root locus and phase lead-lag compensation based on Bode plots.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • To be able to understand the principles of control theory and to be able to solve engineering problems from first principles in the maritime engineering domain.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use commercial software through a design assignment.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Interface engineering problems to specialist control engineers.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
• Acquaint students with statics and the analysis of stress and deformation of simple structures under simple loads.
  • Provide a firm foundation for more advanced study.
  • Review the principles of dynamics and introduce and apply fundamental dynamic modelling.
  • Discuss the nature of stiffness, mass and damping elements and determine their role in controlling the steady-state response of a mechanical system to harmonic loads and motion inputs. 

Learning outcomes 

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

S1

The distinction between internal and external forces and the difference between statically determinate structures, statically indeterminate ones, and mechanisms.

The conditions of equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies, and how to use them to calculate the reactions at the supports of statically-determinate structures.

How to calculate, and plot diagrams of, the internal forces and moments of statically-determinate beams.

Engineer's Bending Theory and how to use it to determine beam deflection due to bending.

The concept of stress, the way that stresses transform, the concept of strain, and how stresses and strains are linked in linear elastic materials.

 

D2

The fundamental assumptions of lumped parameter mass, stiffness and damper models

Free vibrations of a single degree of freedom mechanical system

Steady-state vibration analysis of a single degree of freedom mechanical system subjected to harmonic forces and base motion.

Vibration based transfer functions, how they are inter-related and portrayed graphically

The trade-off between high and low stiffness/damping for vibration isolation

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

S1

Determine whether a structure is statically determinate, indeterminate or a mechanism.

Construct free body diagrams and use them to solve mechanics problems.

Calculate the reactions at the supports of statically determinate structures.

Calculate, and plot diagrams of, the internal actions of statically-determinate beams.

Calculate the deflection due to bending at different points of a beam.

Carry out stress transformations.

Interpret experimental data to deduce structural or material behaviour

Assess whether theoretical assumptions are supported by laboratory observations.

 

D2

Determine both free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems

Interpret, process and appropriately plot vibration based transfer functions

Predict the effectiveness of a vibration isolator given single degree of freedom assumptions

 

Practical skills

Having successfully completed the module you will be able to:

 

  • Carry out calculations relating to structural behaviour and strength of structural members
  • Experiment on idealised forms of structure in the laboratory
  • Collate experimental data

  • Manipulate experimental data in order to draw specific conclusions

General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will have developed skills in:

 

  • Information handling
  • Self management (e.g. time management)
  • Written communication
  • Numeracy
  • Being an independent learner

introduction: The Individual Project is a learning experience that enables you to do independent research and bring together many of the concepts you have been learning over the last few years. Projects offered to Civil Engineering and Architecture students have a strong focus on design and design processes and will be co-supervised by CE and A tutors, but in all cases the work calls for careful planning, critical judgement, engineering competence, and communication skills. Further details are provided in the Individual Project Guide for Students, which is available on Blackboard. This Guide may be updated from time to time, and include information generally on how to plan the project, and on milestones, important dates, and deliverables.
learningoutcomes:
Project aims:

  • To integrate previously learnt and taught knowledge and skills
  • To provide an opportunity for students to pursue extended independent research into an aspect of engineering/environmental science in which they may have developed a special interest, and provide experience of the way subject areas actually progress.
  • To develop a basic ability to define a research question, plan and execute an investigation to answer that question
  • To encourage students to develop a systematic and critical approach to enquiry through the planning, execution and presentation of a piece of work which involves the application of research techniques.
  • To develop students’ independence, initiative and critical thinking
  • To develop a wide range of transferable skills including problem solving, planning and meeting your own deadlines; selecting, gathering, evaluating and synthesizing information from a range of sources; using information and communication technology to acquire, collate, process and analyse data and information implementation; designing and testing skills; preparing, processing, interpreting and presenting data, using appropriate qualitative and quantitative techniques and ICT packages and communicating ideas and arguments effectively in a variety of written formats
  • To understand the structure and elements of a research project in preparation for undertaking relevant research at work.

Student outcomes

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
b. an ability to design and conduct experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret data
c. an ability to design a system, component, or process to meet desired needs within realistic constraints such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability, and sustainability
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems
g. an ability to communicate effectively
h. the broad education necessary to understand the impact of engineering solutions in a global, economic, environmental and societal context
j. a knowledge of contemporary issues
k. an ability to use the techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The issues surrounding a selected civil/environmental engineering/architectural area
  • The tension between theory and practice for a selected area of civil/environmental engineering/architecture

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Identify and develop the research required for your project
  • Critically analyse data
  • Interpret findings from research or other kinds of analysis
  • Apply findings to solve research questions
  • Defend your findings through reports and discussion with your supervisor and others

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Write a succint dissertation summarizing your research
  • Use CAD/CAM (where appropriate to your chosen area)
  • Demonstrate practical skills relevant to the area of the project selected
  • Apply research skills

Key skills

 

  • Planning and organising
  • IT
  • Information handling
  • Oral and written communication
  • Decision Making
  • Project management
  • Independent learning
  • problem solving

learningoutcomes:
This Module will introduce you to the range of skills needed in the determination of design requirements and conditions, planning, and the design of coastal structures. These skills comprise the determination of wave conditions, the determination and analysis of the effect of waves, tides and currents on coastal structures, the design of new coastal structures as well as the evaluation of existing structures and the analysis of marine renewable energy resource and exploitation options.

This module will describe current thinking and techniques used in the evaluation of environmental loadings on coastal structures and their design as well as the assessment of marine renewable energy options examining the approaches used in the UK and elsewhere. The course will comprise a combination of lectures and a design study.

Student outcomes
a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
c. an ability to design a system, component, or process to meet desired needs within realistic constraints such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability, and sustainability
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems

learningoutcomes: Prestressed concrete is becoming increasingly important in modern structural engineering because it leads to significant improvements in design economy. During this course you will learn how to design prestressed concrete beams for bridges and for use in post-tensioned flat slab buildings. Some of the most exciting structures in civil engineering, such as cable-stayed bridges utilise thin-walled structures to maximise stiffness and minimise self-weight. You will learn the theory of buckling of these structures and you will learn how to apply this theory to the design of bridges. Linear-elastic FE analysis of complex reinforced concrete structures can provide unsafe solutions; as occurred during the design of the Sleipner Oil Platform which sunk at the cost of several hundred million dollars. This disaster could have been avoided if the designers had used the strut and tie method during the design. You will learn how to use this advanced technique to design complex reinforced concrete structures subjected to concentrated loads. You will learn how to formulate a range of the most common forms of S&T models and you will apply these to case-studies such as long-span bridges, through to smaller scale structures such as the design of post-tensioning anchors for buildings. Many structures are considered unsatisfactory because they suffer from cracking. You will learn how to predict and control cracking for reinforced concrete structures and you will consider how movements can be accommodated to prevent cracking. Most steel beams used in bridges and buildings act compositely with the supported reinforced concrete slabs. In this module will you will learn how to design these steel-concrete composite beams using a range of design examples taken from bridges and multi-storey buildings.

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • To give an appreciation of the importance of safety considerations within the ship design process and its impact on operational considerations.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

  • The need to integrate safe design and operation within the ship design process.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Describe and apply the basic tools and methodologies used in the ship design process.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Estimate suitable dimensions for a new ship design, to carry out checks on its capacity, mass balance and compliance with statutory regulations, and to assess its economic viability.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply design tools and synthesise information.
  • Interpret and apply statutory regulations and classification rules.

The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide an overview of shipbuilding practices and applications of ship design methodologies and tools

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • How shipyard facilities and machines are organised.
  • The manner in which these influence the various production stages.
  • The impact of some production activities on planning and management functions.
  • The design process to subdivide a ship & layout the GA (General Arrangement) ensuring a space balanced ship
  • Statutory and regulatory requirements in ship design


Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Estimate labour, material, machine and space resource requirements.
  • Calculate productivity, ship efficiency and machine utilisation figures.
  • Derivation of activity networks for planning purposes.
  • Apply the methodologies and tools used in the ship design process to a design office based ship general arrangement.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Sketch typical production shop layouts.

  • Manipulate historically derived production data for forward planning.

  • Estimate shop floor productivity indices.

  • Evolve an overall ship design meeting the requirements for layout, capacities, choice of cargo handling equipment and machinery, safety and statutory regulations

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Organise and plan work and allocate time for individual ship production tasks.
    • Ship layout, systems and structural components.
    • Background into various types of shipyards and overall layout criteria
    • Plate and section stockyards; pre-treatment; marking; cutting and forming
    • Fabrication activities including fairing, sub-assembly and panel line technique
    • Berth activities including advance outfitting and module building practices
    • Information system requirements, shipyard standards and planning activities
  • Manage an individual design assignment
    • Develop an overall ship general arrangement
    • Implement classification society rules
    • Incorporate Statutory requirements (SOLAS & MARPOL)
    • Develop accommodation to standards
    • Meet design requirements for the subdivision of tanks and hold capacities
    • Detail upper deck equipment & layout

The aims of this module are to:
  • provide insight into the nature of turbulent flows;
  • lay a foundation for their rational prediction and analysis and
  • cultivate an appreciation for the importance of turbulence over a range of disciplines.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge & understanding
As the "last unsolved problem of classical physics" turbulence has received intense scrutiny through the years. The fact that most flows of engineering and environmental interest are turbulent has added a further note of urgency to its study. During this module the student will explore the phenomenology and practical implications of turbulence (K1), why it is a "problem" (K2), the statistical approaches used to analyse it (K3) and the methods used to measure it (K4).

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • general features of turbulent flows. (I1)
  • statistical and experimental methods used to characterise them. (I2)
  • the basic physics of turbulent flows across a range of applications. (I3)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • assess the likelihood of fully developed turbulence in practical cases. (P1)
  • identify the most important features. (P2)
  • assess the extent to which classical analysis might be useful. (P3)

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • study and learn independently. (T1)
  • communicate technical understanding in writing. (T2)
  • solve problems. (T3)

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide you with fundamental knowledge and understanding of the behaviour of rigid structures in a seaway through a step-by-step approach of classical dynamics, the environment and its forces and their synthesis to form a fluid-structure interaction model.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Classical dynamics and their application to modelling the rigid body motions of floating structures.
  • The basic unit of seaways (ie. the regular wave) and its definition with respect to a moving ship.
  • To review statistics and understand/apply probabilistic methods to waves and ship motions.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand and apply the principles of dynamic response for basic systems.
  • Model the seaway using deterministic and probabilistic approximations.
  • Model the dynamic behaviour of rigid floating structures in waves.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Construct and solve suitable mathematical models to describe the dynamic behaviour of bodies.
  • Use a range of measurement techniques to obtain data.
  • Use a range of analyses/techniques to present data.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn independently.
  • Obtain and analyse critically data applying your knowledge/understanding of this module.
  • Communicate effectively your work in a written report.
  • Teamworking through laboratory experiment.

learningoutcomes:

The aims of this module are to:
  • be able to describe the fundamental concepts and approaches for computational fluid dynamics (CFD), and to be able to describe limitations of computational methods;
  • be able to describe curve/surface modelling and fundamental concepts and approaches of grid generation, and to generate high quality geometry and grids suitable for CFD;
  • be able to choose appropriate CFD techniques to solve real engineering problems using bespoke or commercial codes.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:  

  • the basic principles of modelling curves/surfaces and generating grids (T, AE);
  • the theoretical background (T,AE) and practical issues associated with the implementation of the use of CFD codes (T,AC);
  • the latest research developments applicable to CFD (T, AE).

Intellectual and Practical skills skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • generate, adapt and assess high quality geometry and grids for a wide range of different applications (T, AC);
  • choose (e.g. appropriate grids for different turbulence models) and then use a CFD package with an appreciation of modeling limitations, to demonstrate importance of validation and engineering interpretation of results (T,AE,AC);
  • describe likely levels of quality and trust associated with the analysis (T,AE,AC).

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • use commercial CFD packages to define, analyse, and solve a class of engineering problems.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The propagation of longitudinal acoustic disturbances in the form of plane acoustic waves.
  • The concepts of sound speed, frequency, wavelength, wavenumber and characteristic acoustic impedance.
  • The thermodynamics of acoustic compressions and the isentropic assumption.
  • 1-D wave equations and the derivation from linearised conservation equations.
  • Single frequency acoustic fluctuations and the Helmholtz equation.
  • Acoustic wave propagation in three dimensions, including spherical wave propagation and the concept of point acoustic sources.
  • The behaviour of sound in enclosures including analytical descriptions of sound propagation at both low and high frequencies.
  • The basic principles of sound radiation from surface vibration.
  • Estimate source sound power from measurements of sound pressure level under different conditions and be aware of the assumptions and limitations underlying the relationships.
  • Make measurements of sound intensity.
  • Use a sound level meter. Make measurements of the sound pressure level of continuous and transient signals and have a practical understanding of the use of standard bandwidths such as one-third octave bands and standard frequency weightings such as 'A-weighting'.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to basic topics in acoustics.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Model simple acoustical problems involving sources of sound in simple geometries.
  • Undertake measurements of basic acoustic quantities.
  • Use a sound level meter.
  • Make sound power measurements according to the ISO standard.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Manipulate complex numbers in the solution of problems associated with simple harmonic wave motion.
learningoutcomes:

The aims of this module are to:

Appreciate, through analysis and discussion, different factors affecting stability and calm water performance of air cushion vehicles and the containment of the air cushion and the influence of cavitation on hydrofoil design.
  • Develop an understanding of the basic mechanics of sailing craft, with particular emphasis on balance of aerodynamic and hydrodynamic forces and key factors affecting stability and the prediction of calm water performance. Appreciation of and applications of VPP computer programmes.

Knowledge and understanding

  • The mechanics and performance prediction of high performance craft.
  • Appreciate how the basic mechanics in each case are applied in simplified design scenarios through more complex engineering design orientated worked examples presented during the timetabled tutorial periods.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Practical skills

General transferable (key) skills

learningoutcomes:

The aims of this module are to:
  • Introduce offshore scenarios quite different to conventional ship or yacht-based operation and hence introduce analytic and semi-analytic methods of hydrodynamic analysis for estimating fluid loads. The geometries may consist of gravity structures, jacket structures, moored semi-submersible or other production units as well as offshore alternative energy production systems.
  • Appreciate analytic integration of Froude Krilov and Diffraction loads for simple geometries as well as the reduction of 3D fluid structure interactions to equivalent faster 2D methods. Appreciate different methods of formulating fluid-structure interactions for a variety of different distinct situations.
  • Provide an appreciation of how flow descriptions are provided for simple fluid singularities in the presence of a free surface and their application in the analysis of single and multi-body situations. Give students the opportunity to appreciate how to undertake applications of such techniques using structures of interest to them. (This may include ships as well as specific offshore structures). Gain insight and understanding as to why second order effects are important in the hydrodynamic analysis and hence the subsequent motion predictions of moored offshore structures.
  • Explain and Demonstrate use of algebraic and numerical analysis based processes to assess the quality of the solutions generated and hence their value in engineering applications.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Underpinning principles of fluid-structure interaction and the motion dynamics of realistic single body and multi-body situations.
  • Principal issues related to the selection of alternative methods of analysis and the modelling of novel offshore scenarios in shipping, oil & gas production offshore and alternative offshore energy extraction.
  • Scientific / Engineering analysis support to design and assessment of novel designs and devices.
  • Need for clear thinking when undertaking the motion analysis of novel structures and how to use this understanding to formulate appropriate fluid-structure interaction problems.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Formulate appropriate mathematical models of various offshore scenarios irrespective of number of structures involved, their geometry and their degree of rigidity.
  • Identify appropriate motion and hence hydrodynamic analysis required together with appropriate cross checking of solutions to establish degree of correctness achieved in selected solution procedure.
  • Discuss rationally the pros and cons of different approaches to fluid structure interaction and motion analyses.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply with confidence quite complex 'black boxes' simply because their basis is understood and the strengths and weaknesses of the processes have been explained and experienced through the coursework.
  • Make decisions regarding the selection of different analysis choices for different classes of problem.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Undertake appropriate hydrodynamic, motion and probabilistic analyses of a wide spectra of offshore related problems and confidently explain as necessary the underpinning principles (as well as pitfalls) of the different techniques.

introduction:
Fluid Mechanics is based on the fundamental laws which define the general fluid motion. The governing equations of fluid mechanics were written in the 19th century, but they were so difficult that no one could solve them for a practically relevant situation, so they were useless in this sense. To meet the demands of the 19th-century industrial revolution the phenomenological approach (called hydraulics) was developed.

Nowadays, new analytical and numerical methods were developed which are capable of solving the equations of fluid mechanics, while some classical industries for which the 19th-century empirical relations were established are becoming redundant (or are moving from the UK). The modern industry is interested in new processes happening either too quickly or in a very small scale or at very high temperatures or at very nasty chemical environments. While improvements to the 19th-century technologies were possible on the basis of the common sense; the new technologies require the knowledge of fluid flow behaviour under the conditions beyond our everyday experience. Old phenomenological formulae are not relevant, and the new models are to be built up on the basis of the fundamental physical laws. Experimental measurements of the new phenomenological relations are required but such measurements are either impossible or at least expensive to undertake for every geometry change. It is more desirable to solve the equations for all interesting configurations.

SESM3004 is the third course of Fluid Mechanics for the ME students. The students learn the basic governing equations in SESM2007. The idea for the SESM3004 is to apply these equations to several particular problems, such as steady and non-steady plane-parallel flows, water waves, convection, capillary flows and sound waves, and to learn the main concepts of the hydrodynamic instability and transition to turbulence. The students will learn the current hydrodynamic description of some technological processes which involve fluid flows and in addition an attention will be paid to the concept of physical modelling required for understanding and consequent improvement of fluid flow aspects of existent applications.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • To widen appreciation of the variety of phenomena covered by fluid mechanics and the techniques available to handle them
  • To provide an introduction to a number of important specific topics in fluid mechanics, not covered in earlier parts of the programme.
  • To provide an adequate foundation for further self study.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
• Mathematical models of the fluid motion, including steady and non-steady plane-parallel flows, water waves, convection, capillary flows and sound waves, and the main concepts of the hydrodynamic instability and transition to turbulence.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

• Use the material presented as a basis for future self-education in the field.

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
N/A

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

• Follow up lecture material in text and reference books.

introduction:
In the Group Design Project (GDP) you will design an entire hill-climb race car by means of CFD analysis, with the primary goal of improving its performance over the baseline car provided to you in form of a CAD model. The group project is a learning experience that enables you to apply your engineering and scientific knowledge to develop specific race car designs.

Working in a group you will negotiate with your 'client', in this case the coordinator, develop your team working, plan your project, present your work through meetings with your supervisor and assessors, report writing and oral presentations. At all times, you will monitor your progress as a team to ensure you are achieving the objectives set while ensuring quality of output.

You should consult the coordinator for full details regarding conducting the project, meetings, forms required and important deadline dates.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Apply your knowledge to a real engineering problem thereby integrating design and engineering science.
  • Gain experience of working as part of a project team with different experiences and skills.
  • Learn to meet both personal and group objectives.
  • Handle the administration, organisation and finances of a project.
  • Develop communication and presentation skills.

introduction: The aim of the module is to provide students with an understanding of freshwater ecosystems and the factors influencing their ecosystem function.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Successful students should:

  • Be able to recognise potential problems where noise or vibration impinges upon the human environment, and assess whether subjective reactions or deterioration of health might be expected.
  • Recognise and select appropriate standards, recommendations or regulations which might apply to any particular indoor or outdoor environment, e.g. domestic, commercial, transport, industrial, etc.
  • Realise what environmental variables should be measured to document the existing situation, which of those variables may be altered, how they might be altered and by what degree, and the relative improvements which might result.
  • Know which instrumental and measurement techniques would apply to alternative objective assessment schemes.
  • Be able to predict if any particular stimulus change will be subjectively noticeable and produce a beneficial change, as judged by the exposed persons.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will have the basic cognitive skills to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to noise and vibration effects upon people.
  • Understand the principles of measuring, evaluating and assessing both noise and vibration.
  • Apply current standards, limits and criteria for both vibration and noise.
  • Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the investigation of noise and vibration effects.

Practical, subject specific skills
After completing this module, students should have the practical skill to:

  • Identify, evaluate and assess the exposures to human exposure to both vibration and noise and their undesirable effects.
  • Apply standards, limits and criteria (both current and new) for both vibration and noise.
  • Analyse problems and devise coherent solutions to noise and / or vibration problems involving people.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to:

  • Access and understand British, European and International standards.
  • Deal with logarithmic quantities, SI units and reference values.
  • Analyse and interpret how new environmental stressors may interact with existing noise and vibration situations.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide a basic understanding of the human responses to sound and vibration in the environment, and how such environmental stressors / stimuli are measured and assessed. In the end, people will judge the success or failure of any efforts in noise and vibration control; their responses must be understood and anticipated.

  • To provide information on the main effects of noise and vibration on people.
  • To identify relevant variables, and how they can be combined to make quantitative predictions of human responses to noise and vibrations.
  • To introduce important standards and regulations which have been developed to provide a framework for objective assessment.
  • To provide a basic understanding of the various alternative approaches to assessment which might be adopted in any particular case.

The aims of this module are to:
  • establish the fundamental techniques for modelling dynamic systems.
  • analyse and manipulate system models in the time and frequency domain.
  • develop an understanding of feedback control systems and the parameters that influence their stability and performance.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • low order linear mathematical models of physical systems and their manipulation.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • derive a model, making justifiable assumptions, from a description of a physical system.
  • determine criteria for desired system performance and interpret trade-offs in different design configurations.
  • analyze time and frequency domain response characteristics from plots, determine stability and predict responses for modified plots.
  • apply standard design techniques to achieve satisfactory closed-loop performance.

Practical skills and General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • to analyze dynamic systems using standard mathematical techniques.
  • apply these skills in specific domains, e.g. flight mechanics, vibrations and automotive systems.

introduction:
You will conduct your project through careful planning, research and execution of the tasks while developing critical judgement and engineering competence. The work from this project will provide you with the opportunity to produce information or results which can be of immediate engineering value, and are perhaps worthy of publication.

You should consult the section "Individual Project" in the Part III coursebook for full details regarding conducting the project, meetings, forms required and important deadline dates. You are expected to spend more time doing an Individual Project in Industry, than time spent on an individual project at the University. This is reflected in the higher credit worthiness of the Project in Industry.

You will have an industrial supervisor who will advise you on a regular basis and hold meetings with you to review your progress and discuss the work. You will also have an academic advisor that you can contact mainly by Email, telephone or on-line video conferencing. The academic supervisor and or the Industrial Coordinator will visit you at least once during your placement.
learningoutcomes:
Aims

 

The aims of this module are to:

  • To provide an opportunity for students to pursue extended independent research into an aspect of engineering in which they may have developed a special interest.
  • To undertake a project within a research group that involves application of the taught material and also independent investigation and research.
  • To allow students to demonstrate mastery of an advanced aspect of the discipline, including critical evaluation of current research and research methods and/or industrial practice, and an awareness of the current limits of knowledge in this aspect of the discipline.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • essential facts, concepts, theories and principles of a particular subject area (depending on chosen project), and its underpinning science and mathematics.
  • the wider multidisciplinary engineering context of the project and its underlying principles
  • the social, environmental, ethical, legal, economic and commercial considerations affecting the conclusions or decisions made during the conduct of the project.

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply appropriate quantitative science and engineering tools to the analysis of problems tackled by the project, using relevant computer software if appropriate.
  • Demonstrate creative and innovative ability on the synthesis of solutions and in formulating design, taking into account constraints of environmental impact, sustainability, health and safety, cost and/or customer and user needs as appropriate.
  • Comprehend the broad picture and thus work with appropriate level of detail.

Practical skills and general transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to most of the following:

  • Locate, read, understand and review relevant literature (T, D, AC).
  • Plan and meet your own deadlines (D).
  • Prioritise competing demands (D).
  • Communicate information at the forefront of your discipline both in writing and orally (T, D, AC).
  • Give a conference-style poster and presentation summarising your findings (AP)
  • Produce a technical report on your work (T, D, AC).
  • Approach a complex task in a systematic way (T, D, AC).
  • Note taking and time management (D, AC).
  • Depending on the subject of your project, you will learn specific practical laboratory, or manufacturing skills and or you will learn how to use certain computer software for analysis and design.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
The course aims are to provide fundamental and practical knowledge of the advantages and limitations of various types of existing energy storage devices. The course explores the most common energy storage processes/systems and focuses on the principles and applications of electrochemical systems which are treated in depth such as batteries and fuel cells, their material architecture such as pore size, structure, composition, particle size as well as key energy storage parameters such as capacity, power, charge-discharge rates, and lifetimes.

Learning outcomes:
Knowledge and understanding
On successful completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1. demonstrate their knowledge of different energy storage devices, understand their principles and appreciate their differences,
2. recognize and explain the fundamental principles of operation that govern electrochemical energy storage devices and appreciate important developments of this technology for applications in automotive, domestic and industrial sectors.

Intellectual skills
At the end of the module, students will be able to:
1. tackle some problems of energy storage, in principle, using electrochemical devices,
2. appreciate the strengths and limitations of various electrochemical and other energy storage systems and
3. quantitatively describe the performance of an energy storage device for a specific application.

General transferable skills
After successfully completed the module, students will be able to:
1. appreciate and understand the literature on energy storage and their current development,
2. communicate ideas and concepts effectively, both orally and in writing within an academic context, on the principles, performance and challenges of these technologies,
3. appreciate the developments in, and requirements for, future of energy storage technologies,
4. outline and develop, in a selected topics of electrochemistry and energy storage, a series of course works which include a critical reflexion and a critical analysis of results together with conclusions, recommendations and references.

Practical skills:
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. plan, design and present a mini-paper (one page) on a selected topic of electrochemistry,
2. demonstrate the ability to present and defend a specific topic on energy storage in a team or in front of an audience,
3. research topics on energy storage technologies and find relevant information in the literature and
4. write and illustrate a scoping study with appropriate comparative graphs and tables.

Key skills:
1. team work,
2. individual and group presentations,
3. plan and organisation on time and with the available resources and
4. concept development.

introduction: This module aims to provide students with a fundamental grounding in knowledge and skills relevant specifically to civil engineering in the areas of basic science (chemistry, biology and geology) and computer methods (computer programming and computational modelling).
learningoutcomes:
This module aims to provide students with a fundamental grounding in knowledge and skills relevant specifically to civil engineering in the areas of basic science (chemistry, biology and geology) and computer methods (computer programming and computational modelling).

In Chemistry, students will be given a fundamental background in the most important chemical and biological principles which can be used to sustainably preserve our environment through good engineering practice and design. In geology, the module provides a general introduction with an emphasis on understanding its importance to ground construction. The course provides an introduction to the main geological processes and a broad appreciation of geohazards and geotechnical risks, of the formation and variability of geotechnical materials, and the importance of groundwater. Fundamental soil and rock properties are introduced in the context of basic soil mechanics.

In computer methods, the students are introduced to the basic ideas of computer programming using the graphical SCRATCH platform. More formal procedural programming techniques are then developed using MATLAB. As a secondary aim - and to provide programming exercises with which to motivate the syntactic development - the students will be introduced to simple numerical methods (root finding and basic data processing).

Learning outcomes are as follows:

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

• linear and non-linear regression
• numerical solution of simple equations
• the importance of pH buffering capacity in biological systems
• chemical principles behind solubility, precipitation, rate kinetics and enthalpy
• effective stress and Mohr circles
• geohazards and geotechnical risks
• geological materials, their origins, distribution and uses
• groundwater
• plate tectonics and the structure of the Earth
• the importance of geology to civil engineering

The aims of this module are to:

Knowledge and understanding

  • relate these failure micromechanisms to optimised materials microstructures
  • assess likely service failures for a range of service conditions
  • identify appropriate testing approaches to evaluate materials' service performance
  • analyse complex service failure problems and apply the correct fracture mechanics approach
  • propose appropriate lifing methodologies for service applications

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • assess fractographic images in some detail

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • evaluate complex data and propose appropriate engineering solutions
  • discuss problem solving approaches in large and small groups

  • Use commercial software in design context.
