  • Present technical data in a professional manner.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide an insight into the engineering based problems faced in orthopaedic biomechanics, through detailed study of lower limb total joint replacement
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Material properties of bone and soft tissues
  • Mechanics of the lower limb
  • Factors related to the design of hip and knee joint replacement
  • Techniques used to assess the performance of joint replacement

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply engineering analysis techniques to orthopaedic biomechanics problems
  • Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of total joint replacement designs
  • Make informed decisions as to the best method to assess the performance of total joint replacements

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • To use standard software packages in problem solving situations
  • Prepare brief technical reports

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The broad scientific background to your project.
  • Detailed knowledge and understanding in the specific area of the project.
  • Relevant scientific literature and ways to summarise key facts and issues emerging from a detailed study of that literature.
  • The specific resources required for the specific project, and their availability at the appropriate times.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Evaluate research literature critically and identify existing gaps in knowledge.
  • Recognise and select experimental, analysis, and statistical techniques appropriate for the specific project.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Plan for the successful execution of technically complex research projects while constrained by limited time and possible competition for other resources.
  • Assess a project in terms of health and safety issues.
  • Carry out a risk assessment.
  • Understand the ethical implications of your project.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Apply information skills by using a library effectively, in particular its database and archive resources.
  • Write a technical report.
  • Give an oral technical presentation.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Ensure that you are fully prepared to proceed with the MSc project immediately after completing the qualifying examinations in the summer.
  • Develop basic ability to define a research question and plan an investigation to answer that question.
  • Develop written and spoken presentation skills for a scientific audience.

  • To enable you to find relevant literature and to critically review that literature and its impact on your project.
  • To ensure that you identify the resources required to complete the project and that you develop a realistic and achievable plan for the research.
  • To provide feedback on your written and spoken presentation skills.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Current issues, paradigms and approaches within a specialist subject area of the environmental sciences

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Produce reasoned arguments, justifying conclusions and recommendations by reference to appropiate analytical frameworks and supporting evidence
  • Analyse synthesize and summarise information critically, including prior research
  • Address environmental problems in an area of specialization with a systematic and informed approach
  • Use facts and data to support arguments, assemble and critically evaluate relevant information from several sources and develop a personal point of view

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Locate and retrieve data and information from a variety of sources

Key skills

  • Communicate ideas and arguments effectively in a variety of written formats, orally and in the context of formal presentations.
  • Select, gather, evaluate and synthesize information from a range of sources (printed, electronic and other material) and make evidence-based assessment and judgements.
  • Use information and communication technology to acquire, collate, process and analyse data and information, and to make the results available to others in written or electronic form.
learningoutcomes:
The overall aims of the module are
1. To help you appreciate the importance of communication skills in science
2. To enable you to write for different audiences
3. To prepare you mentally for the research project later in the course.
4. To provide transferable skills in information gathering and techical writing.
5. To allow you the opportunity to write an in-dept review on a topic of your choosing relevant to your degree

This module is structured to enable students to appreciate the differences between writing styles and content that may be needed for different occasions. It starts from the premise that all students will have written essays and reports during their degree work and then builds a picture of how these differ from the requirements of scientific journals. The aim is to develop the skills that all masters students need to undertake their research projects later in the course and in life. The module begins with a look at identifying key information in text and how to strip away unnecessary words. This is followed by an examination of the roles of tables and figures in scientific papers and how to make best use of restricted publishing space, emphasising what must be included and what can be assumed. A further session introduces the assessment. You will be required to write a thorough and critical literature review of a topic relevant to your degree title.

introduction: The overall aim of this specialist module is to introduce students to environmental modelling in a spatial context, working at a sufficient level to tackle real environmental issues rather than simply academic exercises.
learningoutcomes:
The overall aim of this specialist module is to introduce students to environmental modelling in a spatial context, working at a sufficient level  to tackle real environmental issues rather than simply academic exercises. The module builds on a basic knowledge of GIS that the student must have acquired through a previous module and assumes a basic understanding of data handling and manipulation techniques, for example, using Excel. By the end of studying this module, students will:

1) Appreciate the variety of modelling approaches used in environmental science
2) Understand why spatial modelling is particularly valuable yet also challenging
3) Know the sources of spatial environmental data and how to manipulate them
4) What species distribution modelling is and how it works by coupling advanced statistical procedures with GIS
5) How to forward project climate based species distribution models in order to explore possible futre effects of climate change
6) How data mining and exploratory tools are used to find associations between global patterns in environmental phenonema
7) How land use changes may be modelled and their effects forecast.

continuousassessment.description: Report Predicting the effects of global climate change on a species distribution
Report Modelling global land cover change

introduction:
To give Engineering Students an introduction to key mathematical concepts and methods that are widely used in quantitative analyses of engineering problems, either directly or through mathematical software packages.

This course consists of two components, (i) complex analysis and (ii) linear algebra in engineering.
learningoutcomes:
Having successfully completed the module, the participant will:

Knowledge and understanding:

  • Have developed an understanding of the role of core mathematical concepts widely used to address quantitative problems throughout all the engineering.
  • Have obtained an understanding how abstract mathematical tools discussed in the module manage to address specific real problems.

Intellectual skills:

  • Be able to utilize techniques based on complex numbers as well as on the properties of complex functions to solve a broad class of quantitative problems in engineering
  • Have obtained an understanding in which contexts problems arise in engineering that are addressed by linear algebra methods.
  • Be able to apply essential methods and concepts from linear algebra to real world engineering problems.

General transferable skills:

  • Have obtained a deeper understanding between the purpose and relation of symbolic methods and their real world applications.

The aims of this module are to:
  • provide the background needed to analyse and develop algorithms for solution of aerospace flows over a wide range of Mach numbers
  • equip students to become intelligent users of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) software
  • to convey many of the principles through the assessed coursework and this requires students to write a quasi one-dimensional CFD code. Typically, MATLAB is used, but any reasonable programming/scripting language can be used.

NOTE: this module does not aim to teach particular commercial CFD packages, but a small number of lectures will employ CFD software to demonstrate important techniques.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • the complexity of current CFD codes - and the many choices facing the user
  • the accuracy of CFD results
  • the principles and techniques upon which modern aerospace codes are based; by focusing both upon the theoretical foundation and practical issues involved in obtaining solutions, and through constructing and running sample programs
  • the issues confronting engineers as they seek reliable CFD results.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • more fully understand the components of a successful CFD solution;
  • make intelligent choices among the numerical and modelling parameters;
  • evaluate the accuracy of CFD results.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • set-up and solve aerodynamic problems.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
Aims

The aims of this module are to introduce you to: 

  • The normal development of hearing, speech and language in children
  • Current theories surrounding language and language acquisition
  • Alternative forms of communication, including sign language
  • The fundamentals of Speech Sciences for Audiological applications

The first 3 aims are covered in Semester 1(2 contact hours/week) and the 4th aim is covered in Semester 2 (1 contact hour/week)   

Learning outcomes

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Demonstrate a basic understanding of speech and language dev in young children and begin to apply this knowledge to Audiological practice
  • Demonstrate understanding of the competing theories surrounding language acquisition
  • Demonstrate a basic understanding of alternative forms of communication including sign language
  • Demonstrate familiarity with the key concepts in Speech Sciences, particularly as applied to understanding hearing loss
  • Demonstrate a practical and theoretical understanding of the nature of speech sounds and how these can be analysed using appropriate computer software

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide an insight into the physics of performance prediction methods and their application in physical model testing.
  • To provide a broad coverage of the experimental techniques that have been applied to the study of the performance of sailing vessels and small power craft and ships. 
  • To provide sufficient appreciation on the available techniques that proposed methods and published data may be reviewed in a critical manner.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Determine appropriate test methods to evaluate different aspects of power craft design.
  • Understand the procedures for extrapolating model tests data to full scale.
  • Appraise the dynamometer and transducer types appropriate to particular model test arrangements.
  • Perform analysis of model tests in order to undertake performance prediction studies.
  • Demonstrate a knowledge of the most common types of full scale trials used to determine a vessel's performance.
  • Have an understanding of the physical and mechanical processes involved in routine model test procedures for both sailing and power craft.
  • Have an understanding of the process by which model test data can be used for performance prediction.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Be able to specify appropriate model test programmes in support of a new vessel design.
  • Be able to critically appraise and utilise results from model tests carried out by commercial facilities.

Practical skills  
n/a

General transferable (key) skills 
n/a

introduction: The module will provide students with an introduction to management and law – knowledge and skills which can be applied to the operations of an engineering-based organisation. The learning outcomes address: managerial decisions, accounting for engineering decision-making, law in engineering, marketing, entrepreneurship, leadership & teamwork and project management & project risk management. Guest lecturers from industry will discuss their on-going learning from current industrial practice and project management, and a range of case studies will illustrate the principles and provide examples. Project management and teamwork will be practiced and assessed through individual and group working in practical assignments.
learningoutcomes:
The module aim is to provide participants with an introduction to management and law applicable to the operations of an engineering-based organisation. Through joint coordination between the Faculties of Engineering and the Environment and Business and Law, emphasis is placed upon introducing managerial knowledge and skills specifically valuable for applying effective management techniques to engineering projects within the context of ethical & environmental concerns and the entrepreneurial, financial, team development and legal processes determining sustainable success in business.

On successful completion of the module the student will be able to:

  • Appreciate the nature, scope and impact of managerial roles, skills, ethics and decision-making, supporting effective project work and evaluation for continuous improvement.
  • Consider options to organise and develop human, physical, financial and knowledge-based resources to address objectives in engineering businesses.
  • Appreciate manufacturing, projects and systems management, operations management and quality management.
  • Define cost categories and overhead cost allocation.
  • Understand the principles of Activity Based Costing, budgeting and financial control.
  • Understand relevant costs and Investment Appraisal.
  • Appreciate Real Options and strategic management accounting.
  • Practice accounting for projects and manufacturing/service processes.
  • Appreciate ethical management of measurement processes and the limitations of financial analysis.
  • Understand legal systems relevant for engineering.
  • Recognise and explore key legal requirements for engineering, including; legal responsibilities, IPR, health & safety, employment, welfare, social and environmental legislation.
  • Assess market needs and contribute to marketing strategies addressing market opportunities.
  • Appreciate price setting and management of product lines.
    Relate managerial decisions to Human Resources Management including employee relations, performance management, personal and team development.
  • Pursue effective and ethical leadership and teamwork including briefing, providing feedback, negotiation, motivation and influence.
  • Understand entrepreneurial characteristics and behaviours stimulating creative approaches and innovation in large organisations as well as in start-ups.
  • Consider how to best manage growth and change.
  • Understand factors affecting project implementation.
  • Use project management techniques for coordinating resources, planning implementation, budgeting and assessing risks in engineering projects, appreciating how these support the achievement of engineering goals within the context of developing internal capabilities and evolving ambitions reflecting the commercial, social, environmental and regulatory environment.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Current issues, paradigms and approaches within a specialist subject area of environmental science.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse, synthesize and summarize information critically, including prior research.
  • Collect and integrate several lines of evidence to formulate and test hypotheses.
  • Produce reasoned arguments, justifying conclusions and recommendations by reference to appropriate analytical frameworks and supporting evidence.
  • Address environmental problems in an area of specialization with a systematic and informed approach.
  • Use facts and data properly to support arguments, and assemble and critically evaluate relevant information from several sources and develop a personal point of view.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Design, plan, execute and report research projects and investigations in a specialist subject area of environmental science, including use of secondary (published) data
  • Carry out field and laboratory investigations in a responsible and safe manner.
  • Collect record and analyse data using appropriate techniques in the field and laboratory.
  • Locate and retrieve data and information from a variety of sources

Key skills

  • Report your work effectively

learningoutcomes: The overall aims of the module are to: 1.Train you in the design, implementation and reporting of a substantial individual research project. 2.Provide transferable research skills in experimental design and development, laboratory and field work, data analysis and interpretation, and technical writing and reporting.

The aims of this module are to:

To provide an introduction to practical control systems: control systems are pervasive in industry and everyday life, they appear in increasing numbers in cars, as parts of household appliances, manned and unmanned vehicles of all sorts. Introduction is given into modelling, dynamics and control through five application examples. You will study state-space analysis of dynamics, design of state feedback controllers and realtime state estimation of multi-input multi-output systems. The final part of the course will cover modelling, analysis, stability and control of nonlinear systems.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The fundamentals of classical control design methods.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to design:

  • lead-lag compensators,
  • state-feedback controllers and observers.
  • you will be able to decide about stability of nonlinear dynamics at stationary points in state space

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Construct suitable numerical mathematical models applicable to the design of control systems.
  • Advance your skills in MATLAB in modeling and control design

General transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Judge the merits of using approximate state-space, frequency response and phase plane models to solve control problems.

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
This module aims to establish a fundamental understanding of tribological engineering exploring areas as diverse as component surface distress to bearing performance, with emphasis on engineering applications. It will focus on the relationships of friction, wear and corrosion, and how these relate to the development of reliable and sustainable engineered solutions for tribological contacts such as rolling element bearings. It will include the detailed analysis of the tribological properties of materials, deformation processes and wear mechanisms.

Students will analyse and critically assess the physical and tribological properties of surfaces, hardness, friction and wear in order to be able to develop robust tribologically engineered solutions with enhanced performance and sustainability of machines. Furthermore, they will be able to deepen their understanding of the interrelation of tribological issues in a design project.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Anaerobic digestion of waste.
  • Composting of waste.
  • How we quantify waste and its potential as a natural resource.
  • Landfilling of waste
  • The implication of key pieces of legislation and their implications for those in the wastes management sector and industry.
  • The management techniques and methods used to introduce schemes for minimisation, reuse, recycle, recovery and disposal.
  • The waste management hierarchy .
  • Thermal processing of waste.
  • Waste: what it is and the definitions that are associated with it.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Develop outline waste management plans.
  • Consider the management of wastes in a rational manner.
  • Recognise the opportunities for maximising the value in waste.
  • Select and utilise in a quantitative manner information for the design of treatment and disposal processes.
  • Critically analyse the limitation of waste mangement strategies and plans.
  • Recognise waste management processess as part if our engineered infrustructure.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Research for further information to develop ideas further

Key skills

  • Problem analysis and problem solving
  • Information handling
  • Develop time management skills
  • Develop independent learning skills
  • Interpret numerical data
learningoutcomes: The module considers solid wastes from industry, commerce and domestic sources. The concept of a waste management hierarchy is introduced and practical ways in which it might be implemented are discussed These include waste minimisation, reuse, recycling and recovery as practical alternatives to disposal techniques. The technology and management strategies associated with such schemes are dealt with in detail and include: the design and operation of materials reclamation facilities; composting and anaerobic digestion; and thermal treatment processes. How the selection of these options is influenced by legislative issues is developed in a parallel manner. The module also considers planning and economic issues associated with the industry in the UK which leads on to a detailed examination of the most dominant current practice of landfill as a final disposal option. In this part of the course emphasis is placed on the design and engineering of landfill so as to maximise recovery options and negate environmental damage. The module may include a field trip to a waste management facility if student numbers allow this; if not visual material will be used to familiarise students with details of typical plant and installations.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • British, European and International standards and UK Planning and Policy Guidelines as they relate to air quality, noise, carbon and other environmental impacts.
  • Environmental impact assessment for transport and energy schemes as practiced in the UK.
  • Road transport noise and emissions calculation and mitigation processes.
  • The inter-relationships between the environment, sustainability, energy and transport.
  • The role of ecofootprinting and carbon counting in assessing transport and energy policies.
  • Transport energy consumption calculations and technological and behavioural approaches to mitigation.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Identify /recall the key issues in energy and environmental policies concerning transport
  • Evaluate a transport scheme for its environmental and energy impacts
  • Prepare and present a critique of the key issues concerning transport and energy options for sustainable environments
  • Analyse road traffic noise and emissions

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Calculate the carbon footprint of transport options.
  • Undertake calculations to determine air quality and noise levels and transport energy consumption.
  • Assess the environmental impact of transport schemes using WebTAG.

Key skills

  • Use creativity and innovation in problem solving
  • Report your work effectively.
  • Learn and study/research independently
  • Collate and synthesise/prioritise information
  • Manipulate and analyse data
  • Manage and organise time
  • Present data in a variety of ways
learningoutcomes: This module introduces you to key concepts in the study of transport, energy and the environment, including sustainability. It covers the principles and practice of monitoring and assessing the energy and environmental impacts of transport schemes, with particular reference to the UK. It also provides detailed coverage of the analysis of transport related noise, air pollution and carbon consumption.

continuousassessment.description: Noise, Air Quality and Carbon Calculations

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Reminder of the wave equations for vibrations in beams and plates.
  • Introduction to variational calculus and the Lagrangian.
  • Formulation of the equation of motion for free vibrations in beams and plates using the Rayleigh-Ritz approximate method.
  • Formulation of the equation of motion for axial and bending free vibrations in beams using the Finite Element Method (FEM).
  • Numerical reduction of a FEM by means of geometrical considerations (symmetry, periodicity, constraints) and using the Guyan reduction technique.
  • Eigenvalue-eigenvector analysis of the matrix equation of motion derived with the Rayleigh-Ritz or FEM methods in order to determine the natural frequencies and natural modes of the structure modelled.
  • Eigenvalue-eigenvector intrinsic (orthogonality) and normalisation properties (construction of the modal matrix for the forced vibration analysis).
  • Forced vibration analysis using the direct and modal methods with reference to both harmonic and periodic excitations.
  • General purpose concepts for the use of commercial FEM codes.
  • Finite element model validation.

 

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Make appropriate modelling decisions (regarding meshing, element type, boundary conditions, solution type etc) which are consistent with the anticipated structural dynamic behaviour and knowledge of the FE formulation.
  • Assess, by judicious comparisons with experimental data, the appropriateness of the model.
  • From an awareness of implicit modelling assumptions and uncertainties, refine the model in a physically meaningful way to match the experiment more closely.

 

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Operate the commercial code ANSYS to solve vibration problems on simplified model systems.
  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to numerical methods in structural dynamics.

 

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Program in Matlab to obtain numerical solutions to large order sets of equations.
  • Acquire a working knowledge of new software packages.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide a general introduction to the use of the finite element method for obtaining numerical solutions to the vibration response of mechanical systems.

 

 

  • To give the fundamental concepts of variational calculus, Hamilton and Lagrangian formulation and the Rayleigh and Ritz method for the calculation of natural frequencies and modes of distributed simple structures such as beams.
  • To provide a general introduction to the theory and use of finite element techniques for vibration analysis of practical structures.
  • To give the student direct experience of the use of computer software which employs numerical methods for the solution of vibration problems.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • General two-port description of transducers including their electrical, mechanical and acoustic properties.
  • Electroacoustic analogies.
  • Modification of a transducer's electrical behaviour by its mechanical environment and vice-versa.
  • Equivalent models for moving coil loudspeakers.
  • Loudspeaker and microphone performance in terms of frequency response, directivity and distortion.
  • The influence of a baffle, a closed box and a tuned enclosure on the response of a loudspeaker.
  • The principles of pressure and pressure gradient microphones.
  • The frequency limits due to equalisation and diffraction.
  • The division of a microphone's response into acoustic, mechanical and electrical parts.
  • The principles of operation of condenser, ceramic, electret and dynamic microphones.
  • Microphone calibration methods.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to loudspeaker and microphone design and operation.
  • Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the analysis of electroacoustic problems.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand product specifications for electroacoustic transducers.

Key transferable skills

  • Interpret manufacturers' catalogues.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:

  • To introduce a general two-port description for acoustic transducers.
  • To discuss the principles of operation and practical use of both loudspeakers and microphones.

  • To develop a unified approach to the analysis of transducers.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Basic fluid properties in Civil Engineering contexts
  • Conceptual design (theory and process) for structures, geotechnics and (for some projects) hydraulics
  • Construction Design Management (CDM) Regulations
  • Failure mechanisms that affect the design of individual structural components and frames
  • Good practice in the construction of steel and concrete structures
  • How the principles of soil mechanics are applied to geotechnical problems concerning foundations and slopes
  • How the principles of soil mechanics are applied to geotechnical problems concerning groundwater flow
  • Modern survey techniques
  • The basis engineering properties and the mechanical behaviour of different types of soils
  • The concepts of conservation of mass, momentun and energy in fluid flow
  • The design process
  • The factors that influence steady flow in open channels and pipes
  • The fundamental relationship between stress and strain for engineering materials
  • The importance and implementation of health and safety issues
  • The principles of limit state design
  • The processes involved in the fabrication of structural steelwork
  • The terminology associated with steel and concrete structures
  • The three phase nature of particulate materials and the parameters used to describe the realtionship between the phases
  • The types of tests required to measure the mechanical properties of steel and concrete

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Communicate effectively with technical staff
  • Interpret specifications for materials
  • Understand the meanings of common terms in structural engineering, geotechnics and hydraulics
  • Recognise common types of structural member and the failure modes associated with each member type
  • Estimate the required size of members using simple design formulae
  • Select materials for construction
  • Create a health and safety plan
  • Analyse and use data from sieve and compaction tests for soils used as fills (physical properties)
  • Analyse groundwater flow around excavations
  • Calculate flow rates and pore pressures associated with groundwater control
  • Calculate stress changes and associated settlements below or near shallow raft foundations
  • Analyse shallow pile foundations at failure, using simple methodes
  • Assess the stability of simple slopes
  • Apply the theoretical principles of land surveying in a practical situation
  • Calculate hydrostatic pressures and forces on submerged surfaces
  • Estimate flows in open channels and pipes
  • Discuss the hydraulics aspects of Civil Engineering works involving the flow of water or other fluides

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Communicate effectively with technical specialists
  • Use a tensile testing machine
  • Use an impact testing machine
  • Select suitable materials for different needs in construction
  • Carry out a sieve analysis
  • Carry out and interpret a standard oedometer test
  • Analyse groundwater flow by sketching flownets
  • Operate common land surveying instrumentation e.g levels, theodolites, GPS
  • Carry out a desk study and walk-over study
  • Prepare reports to a high standard

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Critically analyse problems
  • Present information clearly
  • Learn independently
  • Plan and organise your work effectively
learningoutcomes: This module will provide you with a qualitative understanding of the core subject areas of civil engineering. These include the use of materials in construction, the design of steel and concrete structures, geotechnics, engineering surveying and flows in open channels and pipe. You will acquire a qualitative understanding of structural form, conceptual design, project planning, environmental impacts and the CDM regulations. Working individually you will learn how to carry out preliminary investigations for specified aspects of your design. In this module you will become conversant with modern land surveying techniques. You will improve your time management skills by working to tight deadlines, and your communication skills through the preparation of reports and design calculations, and by making a group presentation to your peers and the academic staff supporting the module.

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide a background to advanced topics of interest to maritime structural designers with particular emphasis on the safety and integrity of structures.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The geometry and material-based non-linear behaviour of plates,
  • The ultimate, collapse strength of plated structures.
  • Safety aspects in structural design.
  • The concepts in long-term structural performance including fatigue and fracture aspects.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Calculate stresses/strains and limit states of stiffened and unstiffened isotropic and orthotropic plates.
  • Assess ultimate strength of plates, beams and structures.
  • Assess structural integrity of composite structures.
  • Calculate safety factors and reliability indices in structural calculations.
  • Apply fatigue design procedures for ship structures.
  • Use fracture mechanics principles in the maintenance of ship/marine structures.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply the knowledge to maritime structural design and assessment.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Improve powers of critical assessment and ability to review, analyse and synthesise maritime structure concepts into maritime engineering science.

introduction:
Student outcomes

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
b. an ability to design and conduct experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret data
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems
g. an ability to communicate effectively
k. an ability to use the techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Pipe flow
  • Pumps and how to match a pump and a pipeline
  • Pumps and pipelines
  • The different types of flow ( identified and then analysed)
  • The different types of flow that may exist
  • The principles of flow in open channels
  • Water surface profiles along both natural and engineered open channels

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Analyse simple and complex pipeline systems, including pipe networks
  • Determine the capacity of pipelines, establish the pressures and the energy gradients along the pipe
  • Identify and interpret situations in hydraulics in a way that is relevant to design
  • Devise solutions for open channel applications as well as pipe flow applications

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Operate systems used in a hydraulics laboratory
  • Exercise technical judgement and make decisions
  • Carry out and present engineering calculations

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Problem analysis and problem solving
  • Group work/team work
  • Report writing
learningoutcomes: This module continues to develop the fundamental themes introduced in the module CENV1011 Hydraulics and applies them specifically to Open Channel Flow and Pipe Flow. The approach taken in the section dealing with Pipe Flow is similar and will enable you to begin to apply this knowledge in engineering practice. You will learn about the fundamentals of flow in Open Channels and at the end be in a position to apply these to the problems you will encounter in industry.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • General environmental concerns, which may include: biodiversity; environmental limits to economic or population growth; demand for, and consequences of water, resource utilization; energy and material producation and use, including alternatives; air, land and water pollution; climate change
  • Human causes and consequences of environmental impact
  • The contribution of the sciences to the identification, understanding and, where appropriate, resolution of environmental issues and concerns
  • The importance of environmental concepts, terms, principles and methods, and the need for multi-and interdisciplinary approaches.
  • The value of an holistic approach to environmental science by using techniques and ideas in different subject disciplines

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Collect and integrate several lines of evidence to formulate and test hypotheses.
  • Produce reasoned arguments, justifying conclusions and recommendations by reference to appropriate analytical frameworks and supporting evidence.

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Design plan, execute and report research projects and investigations in a specialist subject area of environmental science, including use of secondary (published) data and information.
  • Collect record and analyse data using appropriate techniques in the field and laboratory.
  • Undertake field and laboratory investigations in a resposible and safe manner, including risk assessment
  • Locate and retrieve data and information from a variety of sources

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Communicate ideas and arguments effectively in a variety of written formats, orally and in the context of formal presentations.
  • Work effectively as a member of a team by identifying individual and collective goals and responsibilities, recognising and respecting the views and opinions of other team members.
  • Prepare, process, interpret and present data, using appropriate qualitative and quantitative techniques and ICT packages.
  • Evaluate your approach to your work in terms of key skills, identify the skills necessary for self-management and work towards targets for personal, academic and career development, and for career development in an academic and/or professional environment
learningoutcomes: The overall aims of the course are: To learn a range of environmental field skills To examine a range of environmental issues in the field, and relate these to scientific theory To develop field-based transferable skills (e.g. teamwork, project management, time management), plus other related skills (presentation, report-writing) To integrate the year group

continuousassessment.description: Production of a practical report based on field data collection
Presentation based on findings during a group field practical (group exercise)

introduction:
This module provides students with advanced hydrodynamics architectural techniques in terms of computational fluid dynamical techniques. To give students an appreciation of the processes by which naval architectural requirements are influenced by physical constraints and impact upon design.

Venue

University of Southampton
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:
  • To provide students with advanced hydrodynamics architectural techniques in terms of computational fluid dynamical techniques.
  • To give students an appreciation of the processes by which naval architectural requirements are influenced by physical constraints and impact upon design.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Critically analyze the extensive air pollutants databases which exist and evaluate the relevant implications for local and non-local populations.
  • Explain and critically discuss the ethical, political, moral, legal and economic factors that impact upon air quality and its control.
  • Explain and evaluate the nature of air pollutants and the effects on the living and non-living environment.
  • Explain and evaluate the terminology, theoretical principles and practical limitations of air pollution monitoring and control systems.
  • Find, review, interpret, model, critically evaluate and present air quality (and associated) data.
  • Thoroughly assess the roles of local, national and international agencies with respect to the management of air quality.
learningoutcomes:
•To critically examine the status of air quality in the UK and worldwide at the current time and the impacts of air quality on human health, ecological systems, the built environment and climate.

•To critically review and evaluate the philosophies, policies and methods available for air pollutant measurement and control.

•To enable the student to find, review, interpret, critically evaluate and present air quality (and associated) data.

introduction:
The individual project is a learning experience that enables you to carry out independent research and perhaps bring together many of the concepts you have been learning in Parts I and II.

You will conduct your project through careful planning, research and execution of the tasks while developing critical judgement and engineering competence. The work from this project will provide you with the opportunity to produce information or results which can be of immediate engineering value, and are perhaps worthy of publication.

You should consult the section "Individual Project" in the Part III coursebook for full details regarding conducting the project, meetings, forms required and important deadline dates.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide an opportunity for students to pursue extended independent research into an aspect of engineering in which they may have developed a special interest.
  • To undertake a project within a research group that involves application of the taught material and also independent investigation and research.
  • To allow students to demonstrate mastery of an advanced aspect of the discipline, including critical evaluation of current research and research methods, and an awareness of the current limits of knowledge in this aspect of the discipline.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • your knowledge and understanding of essential facts, concepts, theories and principles of a particular subject area (depending on chosen project), and its underpinning science and mathematics.
  • that you have an appreciation of the wider multidisciplinary engineering context of the project and its underlying principles
  • you appreciation of the social, environmental, ethical, legal, economic and commercial considerations affecting the conclusions or decisions made during the conduct of the project.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • apply appropriate quantitative science and engineering tools to the analysis of problems tackled by the project, using relevant computer software if appropriate.
  • Demonstrate creative and innovative ability on the synthesis of solutions and in formulating design, taking into account constraints of environmental impact, sustainability, health and safety, cost and/or customer and user needs as appropriate.
  • Comprehend the broad picture and thus work with appropriate level of detail.

Practical skills and general transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Locate, read, understand and review research papers (T, D, AC).
  • Plan and meet your own deadlines (D).
  • Prioritise competing demands (D).
  • Communicate information at the forefront of your discipline both in writing and orally (T, D, AC).
  • Give a conference-style poster and presentation summarising your findings (AP)
  • Produce a technical report on your work (T, D, AC).
  • Approach a complex task in a systematic way (T, D, AC).
  • Note taking and time management (D, AC).
  • Depending on the subject of your project, you will learn specific practical laboratory, or manufacturing skills and or you will learn how to use certain computer software for analysis and design.

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide an introduction to the design tools and processes employed in the design of sailing yachts up to 50m in length.
  • Illustrate methodology and production techniques in small craft design.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The operational requirements of typical yacht types and the definition of how intended function influences the design process.
  • The methodologies for hull form parameter selection and weight estimation.
  • The synthesis of hull structural design.
  • The prevailing climate and major handicap rules that influence yacht design.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the process of yacht design and the associated regulatory regime.
  • Employ appropriate design methodologies to the production of preliminary and design drawings for a new vessel.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Ability to create hull geometries using a hull fairing package

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Increased abilities towards making engineering judgements / estimations

introduction: Practicing Mechanical and Acoustical Engineers require a working knowledge of aspects of electronics, electrical machines and control systems, as these elements are regularly encountered, for example, when instrumenting mechanical/acoustic structures with sensors, providing electro-mechanical actuation and ensuring stable system control and operation. This module provides students with the necessary theory of these elements, worked examples applied to the domain, and two laboratory exercises to re-enforce the taught material.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:

  • impart an appreciation of the use of electronics in a wider systems sense and an understanding of its relevance in control applications
  • endow students with the ability to design simple analogue and digital circuits to enable interfacing of transducers with controllers/data acquisition systems, in support of future project work for example
  • teach transferrable skills such as algorithm design and an appreciation of the hardware/software trade-offs in their implementation
  • to gain an appreciation of electrical machine types and basic machine drive control
  • establish the fundamental techniques for modelling dynamic systems.
  • analyse and manipulate system models in the time and frequency domain.
  • develop an understanding of feedback control systems and the parameters that influence their stability and performance.

On successful completion of the module students will be able to:

  • demonstrate a working knowledge of the advantages, problems and limitations associated with a range of common digital and analogue circuits.
  • demonstrate a good grounding in the subject area of electronics
  • appreciate the methods used in experimentation involving electronic circuits
  • understand the use of design methods applicable in a range of situations other than electronic circuits
  • understand the sensing, elementary machine and control issues surrounding closed loop motor speed control
  • demonstrate a working knowledge of fundamental mathematical tools used in system analysis and design
  • derive a model, making justifiable assumptions, from a description of a physical system.
  • analyse time and frequency domain response characteristics from plots, determine stability and predict responses for modified plots.
  • apply standard design techniques to achieve satisfactory closed-loop performance.

introduction: The project is a learning experience that enables you to apply your conceptual knowledge to an architectural and engineering design problem, normally a building or other inhabited structure with significant structural challenge, to be designed to a high level of detail both architecturally and structurally. You should also bear in mind wider aspects such as the (a) social, (b) economic, (c) environmental, (d) cultural, (e) and sustainability issues related to the subject matter of the project.   Working in groups you will meet regularly with your supervisors and any external sponsor, develop your team working, plan your project, present your work through meetings with your supervisors, sponsor and assessor, prepare and submit reports and oral presentations. At all times you will monitor your progress as a team to ensure you are achieving the objectives set while ensuring quality of output.
learningoutcomes:
Learning outcomes:Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Design methodologies
  • Multidisciplinary research approach and methodologies
  • Social, economic, cultural, technical and environmental aspects of the research
  • The essential elements of the design process
  • The subject area of the project

 2. Practical skills. Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use computer based engineering tools and modelling to solve problems [as appropriate]
  • Control for quality of output
  • Develop practical skills necessary for the execution of the project
  • Monitor the progress of your design
  • Establish a project plan that is efficient and recognises group strengths and time frame
  • Use sketching, modelmaking and architectural visualisation packages to communicate the design

 Key skills

  • Independent learning
  • Time management
  • Written and oral communication
  • Reflection on group processes in team work
  • Design

The aims of this module are to:
  • Apply the principals of classical mechanics (statics, dynamics, fluids, solids, thermodynamics, and continuum mechanics) to determine the mechanical behaviour of biological cells, tissues and materials
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to describe and explain the:

  • Structure, function and material properties of musculoskeletal tissues
  • Structure, function and material properties of skin
  • Structure, function and material properties of cardiovascular tissues
  • Theoretical methods for approximating the behaviour of biological tissues under loads imposed by the body
  • Pathological mechanisms involved in the degeneration of biological materials
  • Structure, function and material properties of cells and molecules
  • Experimental methods used to assess the mechanical behaviour of biological materials

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply classical mechanics principles to determine the mechanical behaviour of biological materials, cells and molecules
  • Design and apply experiments for characterising the mechanical behaviour of normal and pathological biological materials
  • Derive and apply theoretical models for approximating the mechanical behaviour of biological materials

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Design experiments to assess mechanical behaviour of normal and pathological biological materials
  • Application of constitutive laws to describe complex material behaviour
  • Application of numerical models to simulate complex material behaviour.
  • Use standard software packages to approximate and simulate the mechanics of biological materials
  • Prepare brief technical reports

introduction: This module introduces the students to numerical analysis, programming and finite element analyses.
learningoutcomes:
To introduce the students to numerical analysis, programming and finite element analyses.

  • The programming uses Matlab, which allows the student to quickly and easily generate programs.
  • The numerical analysis topics include solution of equations, the method of least squares and matrix manipulation.
  • The introduction to finite element method (FEM) explains the method and demonstrates how it can be used to analyse simple structures using Abaqus.

continuousassessment.description: Analysis of moment capacity of a reinforced concrete beam section (Matlab)
Roots of equations using well established numerical methods (Matlab)
Numerical analysis of a dynamic system (Matlab/Simulink)
Stress concentration around a hole in a thin plate  (Abaqus)
Modelling the bending of a steel I-beam (Abaqus)

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The basic requirements for environmental noise assessment including an understanding of the possible differences between regulatory and subjective approaches, as based on existing scientific knowledge.
  • The relevance of environmental noise to sustainable development in the context of environmental impact assessment.
  • Existing standards and regulations.
  • General procedures additional to specific instructions defined in existing standards and regulations.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand and critically interpret the literature relating to the specific subject area.
  • Comment on the practical relevance and effectiveness of current technical approaches to environmental noise assessment as defined in current standards and regulations.
  • Anticipate future developments in the light of existing technical and practical deficiencies.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply existing standards and regulations competently.
  • Comment on the extent to which current standards and regulations reflect the most up-to-date scientific, social and political thinking in these areas.
  • Contribute to on-going scientific and technical debate in these areas.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Tackle and then solve real issues arising in actual environmental noise assessment cases.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide both the theoretical and practical background necessary to enable students to approach with confidence assessment, planning and control for environmental and transportation noise management purposes.

  • To introduce the students to the historical and theoretical background to the alternative approaches to environmental noise assessment available under present-day conditions.
  • To cover the specific environmental noise assessment procedures and methodologies currently adopted in the UK, including relevant international standards and European Directives.
  • To illustrate the practical connections that exist between acoustical engineering and the effects of environmental noise on people.

introduction: This module covers the topics on digital and sampled-data control systems analysis and design. To attend this module, students are expected to have learned the classical continuous-time control analysis and design, both in the frequency domain and the time domains. In this module, the discrete-time counterparts of the continuous-time control analysis and design will be studied, motivated by the common implementation of controllers using microprocessors or computers. The robustness property and analysis of control systems will also be covered. Both the theoretical aspects and some of the practical aspects of discrete-time are discussed.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are
• to provide students with an introduction to advanced theory and techniques of control system analysis and design, as well as some issues in their implementation, both in linear and nonlinear framework.
• and to introduce several application areas of digital control, especially those related to electro-mechanical systems, as well as active vibration and noise control, and process control.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
• the fundamentals of applied digital control systems.

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
• Understand the approximate dynamical models used in various control applications for electro-mechanical systems, in active vibration and noise control and in process control.
• Design the fundamental dynamics of the controllers implemented in these applications. You will become familiar with the typical system architectures used.

Practical Skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
• Construct suitable mathematical models applicable to the design of relevant control systems.
• Further advance your usage of MATLAB/SIMULINK

General transferable skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
• Appreciate the need for increased use of digital control to replace some analogue systems.
• Grasp the speed at which these systems advance year by year. The course will equip you with the ability to develop your knowledge further as technology advances.

introduction:
• To explore the evidence base relating to hearing threshold levels in the adult population
  • To explore the relationships between hearing threshold levels, age and noise exposure
  • To consider proactive ways to screen adults for hearing impairment
learningoutcomes:
Aims

  • To explore the evidence base relating to hearing threshold levels in the adult population
  • To explore the relationships between hearing threshold levels, age and noise exposure
  • To consider proactive ways to screen adults for hearing impairment

Objectives (teaching)

  • To set a task for prior learning to obtain some familiarity with the topics of noise-induced hearing loss and hearing screening
  • To facilitate learning in groups on a problem that encompasses the topic of the module
  • To enable you as a group to develop your own plan of work
  • To enable you to research relevant issues and critically evaluate the evidence base relating hearing threshold level to age and noise exposure
  • To facilitate your group task to produce a justified proposal for proactive screening of the adult population
  • To enable you to carry out a critical evaluation of the proposals produced by all groups and prepare a short presentation on this

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

  • Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate
    knowledge and understanding in the following areas:
  • Background issues affecting screening of populations for hearing impairment (e.g. characteristics of impaired hearing including noise-induced hearing loss, epidemiology of hearing impairment, accuracy and validity of methods for testing hearing thresholds, principles of screening, potential benefits of early intervention)
  • Awareness of the current state of research and practice concerning adult hearing screening and noise-induced hearing loss

Cognitive (thinking) skills

  • Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
  • Synthesise information from research literature concerning issues relevant to the module
  • Evaluate alternative methods and procedures for hearing screening

Practical, subject-specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Contribute to the development of improved methods and procedures for hearing assessment and screening
  • Contribute to the design of research studies concerning adult hearing screening
  • Demonstrate appropriate clinical decision making in relation to hearing assessment and screening

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in:

  • Data searching, synthesis and evaluation of data from research literature
  • Team working in small groups
  • Preparing written reports and spoken presentations
  • Evaluation of complex scenarios
  • Personal reflection on contribution to team and learning style

The aims of this module are to:
  • acquaint students with the strategies available to surmount the turbulence closure problem
  • cultivate the skill and insight needed to affect a successful turbulent-flow solution appropriate for the geometry and boundary conditions under consideration
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • methods used to compute and model turbulent flows
  • strengths and weaknesses of popular industrial turbulence models

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • critically appraise results form commercial computational fluid dynamics packages

Practical and General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • study and learn both independently
  • communicate work in written reports
  • demonstrate study and time management skills
  • solve problems

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • '4-stage' travel demand models
  • Junction design and analysis models
  • Microscopic traffic simulation models
  • Stated preference models
  • Traffic signal control models
  • UK and international transport policy

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Identify appropriate model types for a range of transport situations
  • Create models to represent a range of transport situations
  • Analyse the results from transport models
  • Evaluate comparative transport options

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Utilise a range of common transport models

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Apply critical analysis and judgement
  • Analyse and solve problems in a methodical fashion.
  • Time management and independent learning
  • Evaluate modelling results
learningoutcomes: This module builds on the theoretical aspects of road transport engineering (covered in CENV3060) to introduce a more applied approach covering the state-of-the-art in transport modelling. The module is divided into three intermixed strands : 'Macroscopic Models' for predicting overall travel patterns; 'Microscopic Models' for predicting indivdual road junctions; and 'Behavioural Models' for predicting individual traveller responses. The overall aim is to develop an understanding of the different approaches to modelling the consequences of transport engineering and policy decisions.

introduction: Module overview
learningoutcomes:
The aim of this module is to develop your skills in the specialism of paediatric audiology. On completion of the module you will be able to:

  • Discuss the epidemiology of childhood hearing loss;
  • Discuss the scientific underpinnings of children's hearing assessment methods
  • Select and evaluate aetiological investigations after diagnosis of childhood hearing loss
  • Discuss child development in relation to hearing loss and hearing assessment,
  • Compare approaches to hearing aid prescription and evaluation in children,
  • Select appropriate ongoing management of confirmed hearing loss in children
  • Demonstrate awareness of the current state of research concerning detection, assessment and management of hearing loss in children

The aims of this module are to:
  • introduce students to the processes and methodologies of designing spacecraft systems with a focus on remote sensing/earth observation.
  • provide students with the knowledge and background to critically evaluate the impact of future technical innovations in aircraft design on the social and economic issues of environmental damage, including ozone depletion and global warming.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The process of spacecraft design, in term of the quantitative analysis of subsystem performance and the impacts of interactions between subsystems.
  • The process of mission design, and an appreciation of how mission drives design of the space vehicle.
  • The payload design and operation in a particular case, and how this drives the space vehicle design.
  • The space and ground systems associated with civil Earth observation missions
  • the social and environmental concerns of climate change (global warming) and the greenhouse effect, and biological damage due to UV-radiation.
  • The physical processes behind these concerns, and the roles of ozone, carbon dioxide, methane, water vapour, and cloud formation in determining equilibrium conditions
  • The effects aircraft emissions have in disturbing this equilibrium leading to change
  • How aircraft technology (engines and airframes) is evolving in response to possible environmental impacts.
  • How aircraft noise is produced and techniques for reducing it

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Evaluate and understand the impact of environmental change on aircraft design
  • Understand the origin of design requirements for a space system
  • Perform system and subsystem level calculations in support of a overall space vehicle design

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • integrate topics into a multi-disciplinary design environment
  • take responsibility for specific technical aspects of an aerospace design
  • work in a multi-disciplinary technical team

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • work effectively with others
  • employ interactive IT skills
  • prepare a technical report
  • understand the regulatory and systems influence in technical analysis

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas: • Prevalence of neurosensory disorders and associated disabilities. • neurosensory, physical, psychological and social considerations in the assessment of individual patient's requirements in order to determine candidacy for rehabilitation. • Awareness and understanding of the management options including the selection, fitting and instruction in the use of rehabilitation instruments. • Awareness and understanding of the need for verification and evaluation of the rehabilitation process and the means by which this can be achieved. • definitions and classification of health and disability. • reactions to congenital and acquired neurosensory disorders. • cultural and ethical issues related to disability and its management.

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • synthesise all the relevant information you have obtained about each individual patient and, with reference to the evidence base, recognise and select appropriate techniques for successful assessment, management planning, verification and evaluation of the intervention. • apply international classifications and definitions to individual cases. • identify and analyse the range of reactions to neurosensory disorders exhibited by the individual and significant others. • evaluate and synthesise the range of views concerning cultural and ethical considerations relating to neurosensory disability.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • classify health status, identify and classify common reactions to neurosensory loss, identify appropriate referral routes. • carry out a detailed and appropriate history, assess impairment, disability and handicap using appropriate measures. At a basic level, you will be able to plan a customised rehabilitation programme including appropriate consideration of rehabilitation instrument selection, prescription fitting rules and performance measurement techniques in order to successfully fit rehabilitative instruments, verification and evaluation of the intervention. • debate cultural and ethical issues relating to neurosensory disability.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in: • patient handling, history taking, patient management, communication skills. • the use of technical apparatus including computer based procedures. • multi-professional and inter-professional working. • debating and discussing issues.
learningoutcomes:
• introduce you to the topic of neurosensory disability and its implications for individuals and their families within the wider context of international definitions and classifications for disability and health. • give you the background knowledge and a detailed understanding of the rehabilitation process including assessment of patients to determine candidacy for rehabilitation, selection, prescription, fitting and use of basic rehabilitation instruments, patient follow-up, verification and evaluation of the neurosensory rehabilitation process. • enable you to apply your theoretical knowledge and comprehension as a healthcare practitioner to all aspects of the rehabilitation needs of adult patients. • enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from books, web based learning and relevant scientific literature.

• describe previous and current international definitions and classifications of health status with reference to specific neurosensory examples. Describe the medical and social models with reference to specific neurosensory examples. • describe the emotional and psychosocial reactions to congenital and acquired neurosensory loss affecting the individual and their family and friends. • provide you with an awareness of the multidisciplinary team approach to rehabilitation including the role of statutory and voluntary groups. • give you an overview of the cultural issues related to neurosensory disorder. • give you an overview of, and the opportunity to discuss and debate the range ethical issues related to neurosensory disorder. • describe the prevalence of neurosensory disorders and the range of rehabilitation needs of adults with neurosensory disorders. • describe the clinical assessment of this patient group including consideration of neurosensory, physical and psychosocial aspects. • give you an overview of the range of approaches to managing adults with neurosensory impairment, enabling you to determine appropriate clinical management of this patient group or to pursue research in a similar rehabilitation related field. • describe the structure and performance of rehabilitation instruments, understanding and applying the factors involved in their selection and evaluation, and awareness of the practical skills required for their fitting and follow-up.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To further develop the principles of flight with an emphasis on aircraft stability and control.
  • To introduce the core elements of aircraft drags and their reduction strategies
  • To establish the basic concepts of optimal design parameters and flight conditions
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Assess the static stability of aircrafts in various types.
  • Derive CG (centre of gravity) margins for the static stability in various cases.
  • Distinguish between stick-fixed and stick-free conditions.
  • Comprehend the roles of control surfaces: elevator, tab, aileron and rudder.
  • Illustrate how an aircraft can maintain static and dynamic stability.
  • Classify various types of aircraft drag forces and illustrate how they are generated.
  • Derive equations describing the drag forces and explain how they can be reduced in terms of geometric parameters of an aircraft.
  • Calculate the optimal CG position, lift and drag coefficients of an aircraft for maximum efficiency.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Recognise the important aspects of aircraft design in relation to drag reduction.
  • Estimate the basic trim condition and stability of an aircraft through hand calculations.
  • Assess if a particular aircraft configuration is statically stable, and suggest design changes needed to affect the static stability of an aircraft.

Practical skills

N/A

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn independently.
  • Communicate your work in a written report.
  • Demonstrate study/time management skills.
