â¢ Stimulate your interest in, and enthusiasm for, the fundamentals of clinical neuroscience practice â¢ Facilitate the development of your understanding of the basic clinical tests of neurosensory function, how they work, why we use them and what their limitations are. The theoretical underpinning of many tests is considered in greater depth during the Physiological and Psychophysical Measurement and Basic Neurosensory Perception modules. Practical understanding of these tests is developed concurrently during the Clinical measurement and treatment module. â¢ Facilitate the development of your ability to apply this understanding to the interpretation of test results, such as in the context of various neurosensory disorders explored during the Applied anatomy physiology and pathophysiology module. The application of understanding is also developed in the Clinical measurement and treatment module. â¢ Encourage you to take a critical, evidence-based approach to your clinical practice

By the end of this the module, it is intended that you will be able to: A. Explain the rationale, the general principles and theoretical basis, and the clinical utility of the following neurosensory tests for use with adult patients, with reference to evidence (e.g. basic science, professional standards, best-practice guidelines and published research): â¢ Otoscopy â¢ Weber and Rinne tuning fork tests â¢ Pure-tone audiometry (PTA) â¢ Tympanometry â¢ Acoustic reflex test â¢ Click-evoked otoacoustic emission (OAE) test. Visual acuity testing eeg recording and interpretation eeg waveform analysis visual evoked responses visual contrast resolution measurement fudus analysis Glaucoma assessment B. Explain the principal sources of measurement and clinical uncertainty associated with these tests, their impact on the interpretation of the results and the strengths and limitations of approaches to manage these sources of error, with reference to evidence. An important example is cross-hearing and its prevention with masking. C. Evaluate critically the results of the individual tests, and integrate critically results across all tests, with consideration to measurement and clinical uncertainty, leading to potential interpretations, identification of key outstanding uncertainties and recommendations for further testing as appropriate, with reference to theory and evidence. D. Explain the results of these tests that may be associated with common neurosensory system pathologies and explain how the results are related to any neurosensory system loss associated with the pathology, with reference to theory and evidence. E. Demonstrate appropriate and consistent use of terminology, scientific conventions, scientific language and methods for presenting and reporting test results.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Make measurements of the acoustical impedance of different material and interpret the rsults
  • Make sound power measurements using various techniques and appreciate the essential differences between them
  • Understand the different forms of acoustical energy, and appreciate the inadequacies of quantifying sound fields by pressure measurements.
  • Understand the factors which allow some sources to radiate sound power efficiently and others inefficiently.
  • Understand the characteristics of sound field in rooms and the influence of sound absorbing materials for sound control.

Having successfully completed the module you will be able to:

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to expand on the fundamental acoustic theory taught in Part 1 and to introduce further basic principles in acoustics.

To explain the basic theory of one-dimensional sound propagation.
To introduce adiabatic and isothermal changes of state.
To introduce the basic measures of acoustical energy of kinetic, potential energy and sound intensity.
To explain the basic conservation equations in acoustics and how, in their linearised form, they can be combined to produce the acoustic wave equation.
To explain further the principles of particle velocity and impedance. To cover the fundamental theory of sound radiation, and the allied concepts of radiation impedance and efficiency.
To cover the basic theory of sound fields in rooms.

introduction: To critically examine the evidence base on the benefits of the different hearing aid features which are currently available or which may be developed in the near future.
learningoutcomes:
Aims

The aim of this module is to:

Objectives (teaching)

  • To facilitate learning in groups on a problem of relevance to Audiology.
  • To enable you as a group to develop your own plan of work.
  • To enable you to research relevant issues and critically evaluate the evidence base relating to hearing aid features.
  • To facilitate your group task to produce a report assessing hearing aid features.
  • To enable you to carry out a critical evaluation of the report and prepare a short presentation on this.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas:

  • Background issues of relevance to hearing aid features (e.g. characteristics of impaired hearing, technological constraints, epidemiology of hearing loss, prescription methods, methods for assessing performance with hearing aids, quality of life indicators, psychosocial factors affecting hearing aid use.)
  • Awareness of the current state of research concerning hearing aid features.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module you will be able to:

  • Synthesise information from research literature concerning issues relevant to the module.
  • Critically evaluate hearing aid features.

Practical, subject-specific skills

  • Demonstrate appropriate decision making in relation to selecting hearing aid features.
  • Contribute to the design of research studies concerning the evaluation of hearing aid features.
  • Contribute to the development of improved hearing aid features

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module you will have:

  • Data searching, synthesis and evaluation of data from research literature
  • Team working in small groups
  • Preparing written reports and spoken presentations
  • Evaluation of complex scenarios
  • Personal reflection on contribution to team and learning style.

To develop critical faculties for evaluating research To develop basic ability to define a research question, plan and execute an investigation to answer that question To understand the structure and elements of a research project in preparation for undertaking relevant research at work.

You will motivate the work in this module yourself by conducting a critical review of the literature, identifying and justifying a research question to be answered, developing and executing a plan of investigation, collecting and analysing observations, drawing appropriate conclusions in comparison with published work and producing a clearly written report. introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
The class should be able to extend their experience of acoustical phenomenon, which for the most part has been restricted to audiofrequencies, from the infrasonic (in terms of, say, ocean noise) to the 80 MHz (for certain medical applications). They should use this extended range as a scheme through which they can place in context the general acoustics learning of earlier years. This will cover ocean acoustics, nonlinear ultrasonics and biomedical ultrasonics

Cognitive (thinking) skills
The class comes from an acoustics background and should apply the general acoustics education they have this topic which is new to them. They should question the extent to which material taught to them in earlier years during their course is correct, and develop critical skills for assessing taught units, and appreciating the way material is simplified for teaching. An example is in the issue of nonlinearity â the linearized plane wave equation, the concepts of superposition etc. will have appeared as standard in earlier courses, but will here be shown to represent an approximation in acoustics which is not application to many ultrasonic applications.

Practical, subject specific skills
None.

Key transferable skills
The students should attain critical undersanding of the limitations inherent in the approximations employed in much taught material, received wisdom, and engineering practice.
learningoutcomes:
A main aim is to place previous knowledge and remaining in acoustics into the context of the underwater environment, so extending the range of frequencies and acoustics pressures over several orders of magnitude over the levels covered in most of their earlier acoustics education. Another aim is to introduce the basic concepts associated with the behaviour of sound and applications of acoustics in the underwater environment. Underwater Acoustics 1 will incorporate proofs of basic relevant physics and describe the range of environments and applications. Though much of the work relates to the ocean environment, sections on non-linear and biomedical ultrasonics are also included. It is important that the student grasp the basic physics underlying the mathematical proofs, in preparation for Underwater Acoustics 2.

The student should feel comfortable with the underlying physical processes governing sound and ultrasound in liquids, and be able as a consequence to explore similarities between sound in the ocean and ultrasound in the body, and extrapolate to new circumstances through discussion. By the end of the course the class should also have gained the skill of critically assessing the way material is simplified in order to present a coherent story (lecture course, journal paper, web page) to the intended audience, and the limitations this imposes upon the material.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To introduce standard engineering methods for the structural analysis of thin walled beams, within the context of aircraft structural components.
  • To illustrate elementary methods for the structural analysis of beam frameworks.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Many of the components of an aircraft structure can be represented as a thin walled beam in the first instance. This approach allows the engineer to simplify complex structural problems and thus obtain a good estimate of the response to the loads encountered during the life of an aircraft. The objective of the course is to enable the students to apply standard methods to calculate the stress and displacement of thin walled beam-like components subjected to static loads. This will be achieved by deriving form first principles the mathematical laws which relate stresses and displacements to the applied loads. The theory developed will then be applied to analyze structures subjected to different loading conditions: bending, shear, torsion and compression. The limitations of the methods presented will also be discussed, and the place of thin-walled beam theory within the broader field of aircraft structural analysis will be emphasised.

The basic outcome of the course is knowledge of thin-walled beam theory with the capability to assess whether aircraft (and other) structural components are able to withstand the applied loads and meet specified performance. Knowledge of the basic principles of energy based methods of analysis, coupled with an ability to apply them to the analysis of frameworks.

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Structural analysis of thin walled beams subjected to bending, shear, torsion and compressive loading.
  • Structural analysis of beam frameworks.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Derive from first principles the mathematical laws which relate stresses and displacements to the applied loads.
  • Analyse beam structures subjected to different loading conditions: bending, shear, torsion and compression.
  • Calculate stress, strain and deformations of thin walled beam structures.
  • Design elementary beam structures able to withstand specified loads.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Practically implement the intellectual skills described above.
  • Carry out experimental structural analysis of beams.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn and research independently
  • Manipulate and analyse experimental data and compare them with theoretical results.
  • Communicate your work in written reports/drawings.
  • Demonstrate study/time management skills, both individually and through teamworking.

introduction: This module provides an introduction to the basic elements of acoustics for the purpose of aim meeting the fundamental needs of practising engineers. This module provides the knowledge and tools to understand and predict the behaviour of complex acoustical systems, including the behaviour of sound propagation in free field and simple bounded environments, and the characteristics of source radiation.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:
• To develop a competence in the theoretical analysis of simple acoustical systems
• To convey the fundamental physical principle that under pin the behaviour of sound in free field and bounded environments and the behaviour and characteristics of simple acoustic sources.
• To allow the student to gain laboratory experience in analysing and interpreting the acoustic measurements in complex scenarios. To present their results formally, together with a critical assessment of the experimental methods and the limitations of their data.

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:
• Understand the behaviour of a wide range of acoustical situations from a fundamental perspective
• Appreciate the limitations and characteristics of acoustic sources
• Perform advanced measurements and formulate analytical models and solutions.
• Provide critical analysis and conclusions.
• Produce a formal technical report.

introduction:
Student outcomes

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
c. an ability to design a system, component, or process to meet desired needs within realistic constraints such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability, and sustainability
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems
j. a knowledge of contemporary issues
k. an ability to use the techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Basic reaction kinetics and hydraulics of reactor types
  • Engineering requirements for water collection and distribution systems
  • Factors influencing the choice of wastewater collection system
  • Importance of wastewater treatment in the global public health context
  • Treatment plant design and process selection

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Perform advanced calculations for the design of different treatment operations
  • Select treatment options on the basis of an in-depth knowledge of the engineering factors involved
  • Explain the engineering principles of enhanced mass transfer and biomess retention systems for wastewater treatment
  • Develop a process flow sheet for an advanced integrated wastewater treatment plant based on minimising resource inputs
  • Discuss why different wastewater treatment solutions are required depending on population, economic, climatic and geographical factors
  • Assess the options for wastewater collection and how these influence choice of treatment process
  • Calculate design parameters for a range of different treatment processes including low-intensity, alternative and advanced systems
  • Compare the merits of aerobic and anaerobic unit processes and process chains
  • Determine appropriate strategies for control and management of industrial pollutants
  • Simulate treatment processes and their integration using appropriate spreadsheet and modelling tools

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Prepare a preliminary design for the key components in a drinking water supply and distribution system
  • Carry out design calculations for individual wastewater treatment processes
  • Plan the overall design for an integrated wastewater treatment system

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Learn and research independently
  • Analyse and evaluate data
  • Synthesise information and approaches
  • Apply design tools and parameters
learningoutcomes:
The module builds on CENV 3059 and assumes a basic knowledge of conventional water and wastewater treatment systems. The course reinforces the importance of water and wastewater treatment for the protection of public health and draws attention both to the epidemiology of globally distributed water-borne and water-related disease and to growing concern over emerging micro-pollutants.

A more rigorous treatment of reactor hydraulic design and reaction kinetics is provided, which is then built upon by reference to a number of treatment options and technologies. These cover the spectrum from low-technology decentralised systems to advanced and tertiary treatment: consideration is also given to the linking of unit processes and technologies in ways that may provide more sustainable solutions in an energy and resource-limited world.

Industrial wastewater treatment is not covered in detail, but options for the effective management of trade effluents and any special requirements for on-site treatment of potentially toxic elements are dealt with. The unit processes associated with water treatment are covered in the Level 3 module and the aim of the current course is to focus on some engineering aspects of storage and distribution.

introduction:

Completing the module should prepare you to understand the features of compressible flows (steady and unsteady) that are absent from incompressible flows, and be able to judge which of the various simplified models may be appropriate in a given situation.

introduction: The project is a learning experience that enables you to apply your knowledge to the design of a complex building in an urban context that responds to (a) social, (b) technical and ( c) environmental/contextual aspects of a built environment problem. You will negotiate with your 'client', be it your supervisor or an external sponsor, develop your brief, plan your project, present and develop your work through drawn/written and oral presentation. At all times you will monitor your progress to ensure you are achieving the objectives set while ensuring quality of output.
learningoutcomes:
Learning outcomes:

Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Architecture's relationship to social, technical and environmental/contextual aspects of the project
  • The design process
  • Multidisciplinary research approaches and methodologies
  • The building type
  • Site analysis

Intellectual skills. Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Refine an architectural idea into an integrated design solution
  • Resolve and coordinate the technical aspects of the proposal
  • Establish a clear brief and prioritise complex issues
  • Generate ideas related to the project in response to an urban site
  • Realise an integrated solution
  • Evaluate critically your strategy, processes and output
  • Appreciate the social, environmental and commercial risk/implications of the proposal

Practical skills. Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Control for quality of output
  • Produce a comprehensive and integrated presentation
  • Establish a project plan that is efficient and deliverable
  • Use multidisciplinary research which may include computer and physical modelling
  • Develop practical skills necessary for the execution of the project

Key skills

  • Independent learning
  • Time management
  • Written and oral communication
  • Reflection on group processes in team work
  • Design

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Critically discuss the architects codes of conduct.
  • Demonstrate a knowledge of the professional framework in which an architect in practice procures architecture.
  • Demonstrate an awareness of the way in which small businesses operate and the principles of business management.
  • Describe the role of the architect at each stage in the RIBA Outline Plan of Work.
  • Recognise the suitability of distinct procurement routes to a particular project.
  • Understand the significance of the relationship between architecture and its intellectual, cultural and legislative context.
  • Understand the way in which architecture is delivered in a professional context.
  • Understand the ways in which an architectural response can be derived in reference to that context.

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Develop and articulate a theoretical approach to architectural design
  • Apply architectural theories
  • Understand the implications of the architects professional framework on the design process.
  • Think Critically about architecture and its cultural context
  • Summarise architectural theories
  • Articulate architectural theories

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Formulate complex arguments, using written and oral skills.
  • Communicate clearly complex arguments, using written and oral skills.
  • Identify appropriate ways of structuring the management of a project in reference to the architects professional framework.

 

 

Key skills

learningoutcomes: This module aims to enable students to understand and articulate the relationship of architecture to its broader cultural and physical context as well as the professional context in which it is delivered. Students will be able to relate these concerns to their own intellectual thought processes and will test and develop their understanding through private research, group presentations and written work.

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • provide you with an introductory grounding in the basic practical, clinical and technical procedures in adult and paediatric assessment and rehabilitation
  • provide practical clinical training to underpin the theoretical work and ensure a basic entry level of skill for subsequent in-service training in the NHS and private hearing aid dispensing
  • enable you to apply your practical and theoretical knowledge and understanding as a clinical scientist in a range of different clinics
  • enable you to apply your practical and theoretical knowledge and comprehension as a clinical scientist to all aspects of auditory and/or vestibular assessment of patients of all ages
  • enable you to understand clinical findings and draw conclusions regarding diagnosis and management of cases
  • provide experience in presenting, or commenting on a patient clinical case and enable you to offer informed critical opinion on the technical, procedural and management detail
  • enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from the relevant scientific literature

Learning outcomes

The learning outcomes of this module are:

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas:

  • clinical and technical procedures used in adult and paediatric hearing and/or balance assessment and rehabilitation sessions. You should be able to describe circumstances under which it is appropriate to apply the individual procedures
  • the need for a structured approach to patient examination, assessment and management and be able to evaluate how this may require modification to match individual patients
  • the ability to interpret the test results in the light of other factors such as the patient's history, and to assess and analyse those results in terms of the implications for pathology, impairment and future management
  • evaluation and synthesis of information from the evidence base relating to the above techniques
  • ability to present and participate in case presentations in the hospital work environment

Cognitive (thinking) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • recognise and select appropriate techniques for successful assessment of hearing and balance of adults and children with appropriate supervision
  • synthesise information obtained from the patient or their parent/guardian with
  • information from other relevant sources and identify appropriate options for the management of the individual patient
  • restate the outcomes of a clinic session and combine them with other relevant details in a formal report, with appropriate support

Practical, subject-specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • perform the following procedures on routine subjects: pure tone audiometry, tympanometry and acoustic reflexes, otoacoustic emissions, impression taking, otoscopy, hearing aid testing, real ear measurements, basic calibration of audiometers, diagnostic and threshold auditory brainstem response testing, oculomotor testing, Dix Hallpike testing, caloric testing, distraction test, visual re-inforcement audiometry, performance testing, play audiometry, toy test
  • synthesis of information from different areas
  • report on the outcome of assessment and rehabilitative procedures

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in:

  • assessment and analysis of patients’ needs and the evaluation of treatment undertaken
  • patient handling, patient management, counselling and communication
  • management of patient records
  • the use of technical apparatus including computer based procedures
  • synthesis of information from different areas

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide a basic awareness of important flow physics that mechanical engineers are likely to encounter in the range of science and industry careers we would hope they follow.
  • Provide the fundamental basis for further optional courses involving fluid mechanics in part III and IV of all the degree programmes that are offered by the school.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Tensor notation, applied to the equations of fluid motion
  • Conservation Laws for mass, momentum and energy.
  • The importance of common dimensionless groups
  • A basic understanding of compressible fluid flow.
  • An awareness of turbulent flow.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Produce streamline sketches of flows
  • Solve simple one-dimensional flow problems by making appropriate assumptions and by applying sensible boundary conditions.
  • Use dimensionless groups to predict the type of flow physics likely to be present.
  • Solve simple problems in one-dimensional isentropic and non-isentropic flow.
  • Qualitatively appreciate the complexity of turbulence and the need for computational models for turbulent flow
  • Assess flow contexts, be aware of the types of behaviour that may occur, and know where to seek further information to predict behaviour.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Demonstrate skills associated with:

  • Problem solving
  • Researching and reporting assignments

The aims of this module are to:
  • Introduce you to the practice of mechanical engineering design in a number of contrasting applications.
  • Provide you with the opportunity to implement skills and knowledge from across the mechanical engineering syllabus in realistic design scenarios.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The application of structural and mechanical design to extreme environments (superconducting systems)
  • The considerations required when selecting sensors for control system applications
  • Material selection choices and design considerations when designing electro-mechanical actuators

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Undertake mechanical engineering design projects in a variety of different application areas.
  • Appreciate the role of computers in realistic design situations

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Select appropriate components to meet specific design needs

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Produce specialized designs both individually and through team working
  • Communicate intricate design concepts orally and graphically

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The origins and characteristics of some of the most commonly used biomedical signals, including ECG, EMG, evoked potentials, and blood pressure.
  • Sources and characteristics of noise and artefacts in these signals.
  • Use of these signals in diagnosis, patient monitoring and physiological investigation.
  • The application of signal processing techniques, including coherent averaging, digital filtering, spectral estimation, cross-correlation, input-output modelling with biomedical signals, and the interpretation of results.
  • Different approaches and options in common biomedical signal processing tasks, such as the estimation of evoked potentials, automatically detecting heart-beats from the ECG, and physiological modelling.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read and interpret current research literature relating to biomedical signal processing tasks, and summarize results obtained.
  • Recognise, select and critically evaluate appropriate techniques for the solution of specific problems in the processing and analysis of biomedical signals.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Implement key biomedical signal processing tasks in Matlab.
  • Select and evaluate appropriate signal processing methods for specific biomedical applications, and interpret results critically.
  • Synthesize results, discuss interpretations, and propose alternative algorithms.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Acquire a working knowledge of new software applications and IT resources.
  • Implement specified algorithms by computer programming.
  • Discuss technical issues within a multidisciplinary environment.
  • Communicate results, conclusions and problems to health-care professionals (such as clinicians and clinical scientists) with limited mathematical background.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide you with an awareness of different biomedical signals.
  • Provide you with an awareness of some of the specific problems and objectives of biomedical signal processing.
  • Enable you to analyse and critically evaluate current signal processing solutions in clinical and biomedical problems, and to propose alternative designs.

Objectives

  • To introduce you to some biomedical signals, their origins and characteristics.
  • To show you how appropriate signal processing methods are being applied to these signals for clinical practice and biomedical research, and enable you to chose between alternatives.
  • To give you practical experience of applying signal processing methods to patient data.
  • To develop your ability to critically analyse different signal processing approaches, identify some of their strengths and limitations, and enable you to formulate alternatives.

introduction: This is a core module of MEnvSci Aquatic Environment and Resources and MSc Water Resources Management.
learningoutcomes:

To understand the hydrological cycle and its relevance to water management

The aims of this module are to:

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Demonstrate good understanding of the theoretical bases of the method of characteristics for ideal potential flow;
  • Apply method of characteristic to two-dimensional  supersonic nozzle design;
  • Obtain knowledge on fundamental acoustics, wave equation and wave propagation;
  • Understand flow generated noise, its propagation and sources in compressible flow;
  • Formulate aeroacoustic problems for solving it numerically or analytically based on knowledge of aeroacoustic theory and available solution methods.

introduction: This module introduces the fundamental concepts of astronautics and spacecraft engineering and applies the design approach to two separate case studies: the first for an interplanetary mission and the second for an Earth observation mission.
learningoutcomes:
The aim is to give the student an understanding into the critical performance parameters and design approach to enable them to perform a basic concept design for various mission types.

Planned learning outcomes
Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed (A) either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The fundamentals of spacecraft engineering (T, AE, AC)

  • The role of top-level trade-offs within the system design process in driving design decisions (T, AE, AC)
  • The payload design and operation in a particular case, and how this drives the space vehicle design (T, AE)

Intellectual skills

Practical skills

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Basic source models in acoustics, including monopole, dipole and higher order mutlipole sources.
  • Inhomogeneous wave equations and methods for their solution, including Green's function techniques.
  • Integral equation formulations for describing acoustic fields.
  • The basic principles underlying analysis of the generation of sound by unsteady flow.
  • The acoustics of enclosed sound fields at low frequency, including analytical models based on the assumption of light damping.
  • Green's functions for sound propagation in ducts and wave guides.
  • A range of numerical modelling techniques for the solution of the acoustic wave equation based on Finite Element and Boundary Element analysis.
  • The use of these techniques through engineering software packages.
  • The mathematics of Finite Element and Boundary Element methods which is critical to their correct use in practice.
  • The interpretation of the results of numerical models.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to analytical and numerical methods in acoustics.
  • Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the solution of analytical and numerical problems in acoustics.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Prepare data for commercial FE and/or BE codes to solve problems in acoustics to carry out design calculations on simplified model systems.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Acquire a working knowledge of software packages for acoustic computations.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • To introduce the student to the formal analytical basis for the solution of complex problems in acoustics.
  • To describe numerical techniques available for the solution of problems in acoustics when analytical methods provide no means of solution.
  • To give the student direct experience of the use of computer software which employs numerical methods for the solution of problems.

  • Characterise the elastic buckling limit of un/stiffened plate panels.
  • Characterise the structural response of sandwich plates.
  • Characterise the vibrational features of plated structures.

Practical skills  

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  •  Apply the knowledge to practical ship design and assessment.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Improve powers of critical assessment and review, and ability to review, analyse and synthesise plate structures knowledge into ship and marine structure design.

introduction:
• Basic source models in acoustics, including monopole, dipole and higher order mutlipole sources.
  • Inhomogeneous wave equations and methods for their solution, including Green's function techniques.
  • Integral equation formulations for describing acoustic fields.
  • The basic principles underlying analysis of the generation of sound by unsteady flow.
  • The acoustics of enclosed sound fields at low frequency, including analytical models based on the assumption of light damping.
  • Green's functions for sound propagation in ducts and wave guides.
  • A range of numerical modelling techniques for the solution of the acoustic wave equation based on Finite Element and Boundary Element analysis.
  • The use of these techniques through engineering software packages for applications in duct acoustics, in automotive and other fields.
  • The mathematics of Finite Element and Boundary Element methods which is critical to their correct use in practice.
  • The interpretation of the results of numerical models.
learningoutcomes:
Aims
The aims of this module are to:
Provide a general introduction to analytical and numerical techniques in acoustics.

Objectives (teaching)
To introduce the student to the formal analytical basis for the solution of complex problems in acoustics.
To describe numerical techniques available for the solution of problems in acoustics when
analytical methods provide no means of solution.
To give the student direct experience of the use of computer software which employs numerical methods for the solution of problems.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
Basic source models in acoustics, including monopole, dipole and higher order mutlipole sources.
Inhomogeneous wave equations and methods for their solution, including Green's function techniques.
Integral equation formulations for describing acoustic fields.
The basic principles underlying analysis of the generation of sound by unsteady flow.
The acoustics of enclosed sound fields at low frequency, including analytical models based on the assumption of light damping.
Green's functions for sound propagation in ducts and wave guides.
A range of numerical modelling techniques for the solution of the acoustic wave equation based on Finite Element and Boundary Element analysis.
The use of these techniques through engineering software packages for applications in duct acoustics, in automotive and other fields.
The mathematics of Finite Element and Boundary Element methods which is critical to their correct use in practice.
The interpretation of the results of numerical models.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to analytical and numerical methods in acoustics.
Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the solution of analytical and numerical problems in acoustics.

Practical, subject-specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:
Use commercial FE and/or BE codes to solve problems in acoustics to carry out design
calculations on simplified model systems.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:
Acquire a working knowledge of new software packages.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding

  • Be able to recognise the important issues concerned with the human factors aspects of tasks, products and environments.
  • Be aware of methods of quantifying and predicting human comfort, human performance and human health.
  • Recognise the role of standards, recommendations and regulations applicable to tasks, products and environments.
  • Understand the environmental variables that can be measured to document an existing situation, those variables that may be altered, how they might be altered and by what degree, so that improvements may result.
  • Distinguish between stress and strain in relation to human responses and recognise the existence of methods of measuring both the cause and effect in systems involving people.
  • Recognise limitations to currently available methods of predicting human responses, and human performance, including inter-subject variability and intra-subject variability.

 

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will have the basic cognitive skills to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to human factors.
  • Understand the principles of measuring, evaluating and assessing factors influencing human responses.
  • Apply some standards, limits and criteria relevant to human responses.
  • Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the investigation of human factors in systems.

 

Practical, subject specific skills
After completing this module, students should have the practical skill to:

  • Identify, evaluate and assess the human factors aspects of tasks, products and environments.
  • Apply relevant standards, limits and criteria.

 

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to:

  • Understand the importance of human variability in the design of systems.
  • Understand the importance of human comfort, performance and health to systems.
learningoutcomes:
To show how knowledge of the capability of humans can be used for the design of systems and machines and the optimisation of the working and living environment.

To examine the relevant physical, environmental, physiological and psychological information to enable the engineer to take acount of the human element in machine design, working environments and systems organisation.

The aims of this module are to:

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

The objective of this course is to furnish students with such knowledge, increase their awareness of recent developments in structural materials/fabrication (e.g. composites), and prepare them for a possible career as a structural specialist or a researcher. This will be accomplished through clear statements, examples, and case studies delivered in lectures, supported by assignments.

Intellectual skills

Practical skills

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be:

  • able to perform analysis; and interpret the results.

learningoutcomes: This module gives an overview of the policy issues, various planning aids and assessment methods available to quantify energy efficiency and sustainability in buildings. Students will be able to use different tools to investigate building energy performance of existing buildings and new building designs as well as to critically assess the results given by the various rating systems. Special features of module: Assessments of selected buildings on the University’s Highfield Campus will complement the theoretical lecture content with factual observations.

introduction:
The aim of the module is to provide an overview of core scientific and clinical aspects of cochlear implantation as a form of management of severe and profound deafness. The module will run as intensive level 7 module covering a total contact period of three weeks, with outline timetable indicated below. Curriculum content will be divided between (i) an overview of core issues around cochlear implant design, candidacy and monitoring in the context of management of severe to profound hearing loss in adults and children, (ii) focus on a more specialist area of current clinical and scientific controversy or knowledge and (iii) focus on clinical management, governance and professional issues, particularly through the guided clinical observation session and associated individual reflective assignment. Because the module aims to give a grounding across a range of core scientific and clinical aspects of cochlear implantation, the focus will be more on application to adults than application to children, although students will learn about key issues relating to candidacy and outcomes in the paediatric population.

Week one will comprise daily lecture series on the nature of severe and profound deafness, and cochlear implant design, candidacy, tuning and monitoring methods. Formative online tests will be available to support learning. The week will provide a broad overview of core scientific and clinical aspects of cochlear implantation that will form the basis of on-going research and clinical practice.

In weeks two and three facilitated and non-facilitated group work in a small group setting will be used to work on a specialist topic that requires development of a research-baseed protocol in a current aspect of cochlear implant science, culminating in a summative group assignment and summative group presentation. Chosen topics will be based on current areas in cochlear implantation which are at the cutting edge of knowledge and where current knowledge is incomplete or controversial.

A facilitated group observation session will be arranged during the module; this will link with a summative individual assessment but precise timing will be subject to availability. The focus will be on learning outcomes related to the need to become an independent reflective practitioner. The individual assignment will require the student to analyse the clinical session from varying perspective, including professional, ethical, clinical and scientific aspects.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are

  • to enable the student to understand the nature and consequence of severe to profound deafness and their effects in the social, psychological and education domains
  • to familiarise the student with the current status of cochlear implant technology and its key role in management of severe profound deafness
  • to familiarise the student with key issues affecting cochlear implant performance, both in terms of the nature of the intervention and individual characteristics
  • to provide the student with an overview of key issues in selection and management of young children receiving cochlear implants
  • to familiarise the student with the main characteristics of cochlear implant hardware and signal processing
  • to introduce the student to the concept of candidacy criteria and its role and rationale in cochlear implant assessment
  • to familiarise the student with the main methods of monitoring the function of cochlear implant devices, including both subjective and objective methods
  • to familiarise the student with the concept of cochlear implant tuning and its scientific and clinical basis
  • to enable the student to understand, and to start to develop the ability to critically analyse, current scientific literature in the area of cochlear implantation

At the end of this module, the student should be able to:

  • develop a critical awareness of current issues in cochlear implant research and development within the broader context of management of severe and profound deafness
  • interpret data from cochlear implant assessment in determining candidacy for implantation
  • understand key concepts in cochlear implants design and signal processing so that the student is able to interpret and review a paper in current cochlear implant science critically
  • begin to develop an understanding of the role of the audiologist in tuning and monitoring of cochlear implant devices in adult patients
  • be able to reflect on a clinical observation session and through this to demonstrate an awareness of broader ethical, clinical management and professional issues surrounding the management of severe to profound deafness

introduction: This module extends understanding of how structures behave, and can be analysed.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Extend understanding of how structures behave, and can be analysed.
  • To recognise the concepts of stress-state, strain-state and yield by considering the behaviour of simple structures.
  • Explain the elastic analysis of statically indeterminate structures, and to show the key implications of redundancy.
  • Understand the use of plastic theory for analysis of simple structures.
  • To understand the non-linear mechanics of structures.
  • Explain principles of dynamics and introduce and apply fundamental dynamic modelling.
  • To understand the nature of stiffness, mass and damping in civil engineering structures.
  • Analyse systems with more than one degree of freedom.
    Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
    Knowledge and understanding
    Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
  • Apply the concept of stress-state and strain-state; be able to represent them in 2-D and 3-D by Mohr's Circles.
  • Apply the Tresca and von Mises yield criteria in structural analysis.
  • Analyse statically indeterminate truss and frame structures.
  • Find upper bound estimates of the failure load of beams, plane portal frames and slabs.
  • Find lower bound estimates of the failure load of beams.
  • Apply the influence line analysis for beams and 2-D trusses.
  • Solve stability (i.e. buckling) problems in columns.
  • Know the fundamental assumptions of lumped parameter mass, stiffness and damper models.
  • Solve the standard-form equations for the response to simple harmonic, free damping and forced dynamics systems.
  • Obtain and solve differential equations for systems with more than one degree of freedom.
    https://sharepoint.soton.ac.uk/sites/ese/quality_handbook/Handbook/Employability%20Statement.aspx

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to:

  • Understand and appreciate the subject as an essential structural design tool.
  • Assess stress state in a structure or component.
  • Estimate safe design loads for a range of basic structures.
  • Understand the material, geometric and boundary conditions non-linearity involved in structures.
  • Determine both free and forced vibrations of single degree/ multi degrees of freedom systems.
    Practical skills
    Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to:
  • Determine stiffness matrix of a simple structure and identification of principal axes.
  • Experiment on dynamic response of an idealised multi-degrees-of freedom simple structure.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to:

  • Apply analytical skills to practical problems.
  • Problem analysis and problem solving.
  • Read flexibly and with purpose.
  • self-management (e.g. time management).

introduction:

2. The economic tools needed for project management and how to apply them.

Intellectual skills

learningoutcomes: This module will provide you with a detailed understanding of the economics of engineering project management. Particular focus will be placed on appraisal techniques to determine whether engineering projects should be initiated, to determine their design and development and to inform on their implementation and operation. Evaluation techniques will be outlined that can determine whether a project has been successful. Broader approaches to project management will also be illustrated.

The aims of this module are to:
  • provide the experience needed to formulate approaches to the solution of problems in Design Search and Optimisation (DSO)
  • equip students to become intelligent practitioners in the setup, solution and analysis of design problems using relevant analysis tools
  • introduce how tools such as MATLAB can be used to support problem solving in DSO. NOTE: whilst some MATLAB functionality will be demonstrated in this course, detailed MATLAB tuition will not be provided (see note below in the Resources section).
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • the ways in which CAD tools can be used to formulate design intent in DSO problems;
  • the ways in which various tools can be brought together to tackle realistic DSO problems via the use of bespoke workflows;
  • the issues confronting engineers as they seek practical DSO approaches.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • more fully understand the components of a successful DSO approach to design;
  • make intelligent choices among the available DSO approaches;
  • evaluate the utility and robustness of DSO produced designs.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • set-up and solve simple DSO problems using commercially available CAD packages such as Solidworks

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide you with an introduction to the fundamental properties of floating bodies, covering those areas conventionally treated by hydrostatic methods.
  • Provide students with an early insight into the range of tasks involved in the design, construction, management and operation of marine vehicles and an awareness of the engineer's responsibility to society.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The concepts of area, first and second moments of area and their applications to floating bodies.
  • The concepts of equilibrium and changes in equilibrium of floating bodies.
  • The concepts of static and dynamic stability
  • The use of numerical methods for calculating hydrostatic properties.
  • The different types of marine vehicles and identify characteristics influencing their design. (T, D, AC).
  • The fundamental engineering and economic principles, their application to design and their influence on the development of marine vehicles. (T, D, AC)
  • The role and responsibilities of engineers in society. (T)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the basic principles of equilibrium of floating bodies.
  • Calculate relevant hydrostatic properties using theoretical and numerical methods.
  • Appreciate the technical and economical complexities involved in the design, construction, management and operation of marine vehicles. (T, D, AC)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use basic mathematical techniques, such as integration, to formulate and obtain hydrostatic properties of simple geometries.
  • Use basic numerical methods, such as Simpson's rule, to formulate and obtain hydrostatic properties of hull forms.
  • Use simple measurement techniques to obtain data.
  • Perform independent/directed research. (T, D, AC)
  • Communicate accurately your work in written reports and assignments. (T, D, AC)

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn through tutorials and begin to learn independently.
  • Obtain and accurately analyse data applying your knowledge/understanding of this module.
  • Communicate accurately your work in a written report.
  • Teamworking through laboratory experiment.
  • Ship geometry - lines plan, curve of areas.
  • Ship parameters - form coefficients, fineness coefficients.
  • Equilibrium of floating and submerged bodies - volume, centres of buoyancy and gravity.
  • Properties of irregular shapes - areas, first moments, second moments.
  • Longitudinal and transverse metacentres.
  • Problems involving changes of draught and trim.
  • Numerical integration.
  • Initial transverse stability.
  • Virtual centres - suspended weights, free surface, stability during docking.
  • Large angle stability - GZ curves and effects of changing hull geometry.
  • Dynamic stability - effect of sudden loads, stability criteria.
  • Flooding calculations - added weight, lost buoyancy, floodable length, permeability.
  • Launching calculations and curves.
  • Inclining experiment.

Study time allocation

Contact hours: 38
Private study hours: 62
Total study time: 100 hours

Teaching and learning methods

Teaching methods include
  • 24 lectures
  • Five 3-hour interactive tutorials (for each halve of the class)
  • Laboratory experiment. (duration 3 hours)
Learning activities include
  • Interactive tutorials
  • Directed reading
  • Example sheets
  • Experimentation
  • Report-writing (laboratory experiment)

Resources and reading list

Core Text

Typed comprehensive notes

Background Texts

K.J. Rawson and E.C. Tupper, Basic Ship Theory, Longmans, 1994.

E V Lewis (editor), Principles of Naval Architecture (vol I), 2nd Edition. SNAME, 1989.

Assessment methods

 

Feedback and student support during module study (formative assessment)

  • Feedback on example sheets
  • Feedback on laboratory report
  • Support and feedback from interactive tutorials

Relationship between the teaching, learning and assessment methods and the planned learning outcomes

Through the lectures and directed reading you will gain understanding of the basic hydrostatic concepts and the use of mathematical formulation to describe and evaluate hydrostatic properties. Example sheets and interactive tutorials will give you the opportunity to extend this understanding and apply it correctly. The laboratory experiment and report will give you the opportunity to observe and record data and analyse a simple hydrostatic experiment. Feedback from the interactive tutorials, and the coursework will inform you on your strengths and weaknesses in your knowledge and understanding of this module.

Relationship between learning outcomes and the teaching, learning and assessment methods:

Through the lectures and directed reading you will gain understanding of the basic hydrostatic concepts and the use of mathematical formulation to describe and evaluate hydrostatic properties. Example sheets and interactive tutorials will give you the opportunity to extend this understanding and apply it correctly. The laboratory experiment and report will give you the opportunity to observe and record data and analyse a simple hydrostatic experiment.

introduction:
The individual project is a learning experience that enables you to carry out independent research and perhaps bring together many of the concepts you have been learning in Parts I and II.

You will conduct your project through careful planning, research and execution of the tasks while developing critical judgement and engineering competence. The work from this project will provide you with the opportunity to produce information or results which can be of immediate engineering value, and are perhaps worthy of publication.

You should consult the section "Individual Project" in the Part III coursebook for full details regarding conducting the project, meetings, forms required and important deadline dates.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide an opportunity for students to pursue extended independent research into an aspect of engineering in which they may have developed a special interest.
  • To undertake a project within a research group that involves application of the taught material and also independent investigation and research.
  • To allow students to demonstrate mastery of an advanced aspect of the discipline, including critical evaluation of current research and research methods, and an awareness of the current limits of knowledge in this aspect of the discipline.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • your knowledge and understanding of essential facts, concepts, theories and principles of a particular subject area (depending on chosen project), and its underpinning science and mathematics.
  • that you have an appreciation of the wider multidisciplinary engineering context of the project and its underlying principles
  • you appreciation of the social, environmental, ethical, legal, economic and commercial considerations affecting the conclusions or decisions made during the conduct of the project.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • apply appropriate quantitative science and engineering tools to the analysis of problems tackled by the project, using relevant computer software if appropriate.
  • Demonstrate creative and innovative ability on the synthesis of solutions and in formulating design, taking into account constraints of environmental impact, sustainability, health and safety, cost and/or customer and user needs as appropriate.
  • Comprehend the broad picture and thus work with appropriate level of detail.

Practical skills and general transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Locate, read, understand and review research papers (T, D, AC).
  • Plan and meet your own deadlines (D).
  • Prioritise competing demands (D).
  • Communicate information at the forefront of your discipline both in writing and orally (T, D, AC).
  • Give a conference-style poster and presentation summarising your findings (AP)
  • Produce a technical report on your work (T, D, AC).
  • Approach a complex task in a systematic way (T, D, AC).
  • Note taking and time management (D, AC).
  • Depending on the subject of your project, you will learn specific practical laboratory, or manufacturing skills and or you will learn how to use certain computer software for analysis and design.

introduction: You will be able to describe the main designs used for research in audiology, methods used for gathering and recording data, and statistical methods for analysis. learningoutcomes:
To introduce methods used for research in neuroscience  in preparation for research project

Knowledge and understanding: You will be able to describe the main designs used for research in audiology, methods used for gathering and recording data, and statistical methods for analysis. You will understand the principles of experimental design and statistical inference. You will understand the requirement and procedures for obtaining ethical committee approval.

Cognitive skills: You will have further developed your ability to appraise evidence and research literature in audiology critically. You will be able to evaluate alternative designs and analysis methods for application to audiological research projects and understand the concept of statistical power. Interpret the output from commonly used analysis methods and draw conclusions based on a combination of the analysis and the underlying science.

Practical skills: You will be able to apply evidence from the research literature to individual cases. You will be able to design and analyse viable research studies in audiology.

Key transferable skills: You will be able to apply your critical appraisal skills to many aspects of study and work.

  • Identify /recall the key issues in transportation engineering analysis and design
  • Analyse traffic operations on roads and at junctions

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Use the junction design software LINSIG and/or ARCADY effectively.
  • Produce junction design drawings

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Use creativity and innovation in problem solving
  • Learn and study/research independently
  • Manage your time
  • Report your work effectively
  • Collate and synthesise/prioritise information
  • Manipulate and analyse data
learningoutcomes: This module introduces you to the principles and current practice of Transportation Engineering. The aim is for you to gain knowledge and understanding of traffic flow theory, of the analysis, design and evaluation processes for roads and road junctions, according to the requirements of efficiency, safety and environmental protection. The aim is also for you to develop key skills in analysis, design and evaluation, including software applications and a case study.

The aims of this module are to: 
  • Demonstrate an understanding of core mechanical engineering topics.
  • Give an overview of current issues in the different aspects (themes) of advanced mechanical engineering science.
  • Provide an opportunity to gain in-depth knowledge of a theme in advance mechanical engineering science.
  • Develop literature searching, information processing, research and laboratory skills to build an expertise in advanced mechanical engineering science.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

GENERAL LEARNING OUTCOMES

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:  

  • The fundamental scientific and technical aspects of a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science. A2, A3
  • The technical background of mechanical engineering science to permit study of the current literature, identification of gaps in information, and engagement in discussion with peer and a wide range of audiences. A2, A3
  • The limitations of current knowledge and the changing nature of technologies and the society, and the need to gain new knowledge through further study and teamwork in your professional field. A3, A4
  • Specific techniques with application to your own research and advanced scholarship. A3

Intellectual skills and research Skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Synthesise and Analyse information and ideas, and apply creative and original thought in order to propose appropriate new solutions to complex problems. A1, A4

Transferable and Generic  transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: 

  • A comprehensive understanding of the scientific principles of a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science and related disciplines. A2, A3
  • An awareness of developments related to a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science. A2, A3

Subject Specific Practical Skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Demonstrate practical laboratory skills associated with mechanical engineering science. A1
  • Demonstrate skills in technical writing, research planning and preparation for the full-time work on a research project. A4

 SPECIFIC LEARNING OUTCOMES

Underpinning Science and Mathematics (US)
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate:  

  • A comprehensive understanding of the scientific principles of a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science and related disciplines. A2, A3
  • An awareness of developments related to a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science. A2, A3

Engineering Analysis (E)
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate the:

  • Ability to use fundamental knowledge to investigate new and emerging technologies of a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science. A2, A3
  • Ability to extract data pertinent to an unfamiliar problem, and apply its solution using computer based engineering tools when appropriate. A1, A2

Design (D)
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate the: 

  • Ability to generate an innovative design for a system to fulfil needs in particular areas of advanced mechanical engineering science. A1

Economics Social and Environmental Context (S)
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate: 

  • Understanding of the need for a high level of professional and ethical conduct in advanced mechanical engineering science. A3, A4

Engineering Practice (P)
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate:  

  • A thorough understanding of current practice and its limitations and some appreciation of likely new developments in a number of themes in advanced mechanical engineering science. A2, A3
  • Ability to apply engineering techniques taking account of a range of commercial and industrial constraints. A4
  • Understanding of appropriate codes of practice and industry standards

The aims of this module are to:

Knowledge and understanding

Practical skills

General transferable (key) skills

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully complete the module, you will be able to

  • Discuss the generation and propagation of sound in fluids.
  • Explain the principle of the Lighthill Acoustic Analogy, and how this is related to sound generated by turbulent flows.
  • Explain how scaling laws may be derived (for some simple examples), and to interpret these.
  • Explain how mean flow and boundaries can affect sound generation and propagation.
  • Apply aeroacoustics theory to new problems (level M only).
  • Understanding of some of the current state-of-the-art research in aeroacoustics (level M only)

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to

  • Recognise "aeroacoustics" problems
  • Analyse aeroacoustics problems and select appropriate methods for solution of the problems
  • Assess whether the complexity of a problem in aeroacoustics may be reduced, e.g., by the use of scaing laws
  • Improved ability to read and interpret scientific textbooks and papers related to aeroacoustics (level M only),

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to

  • Recognise and define terms specific to aeroacoustics
  • Use relevant mathematical methods to solve problems in aeroacoustics
  • Link teory related to fluid dynamics and acoustics
  • Synthesise theory from different fields of study (e.g., fluid dynamics, acoustics, mathematical methods)
  • Model complex noise generation problems (Level M only)
  • Appreciate the difficulties associated with modelling aeroacoustic problems (Level M only).

Key transferable skills

  • Write computer programs and reports
  • Apply critical analysis and evaluation skills
  • Ability to read, understand and interpret scientifc papers
  • Synthesise information from a range of sources
  • Communicate clearly in written reports
learningoutcomes:
The specific aim of this module is to introduce some of the fundamental theory of aeroacoustics.

Also, a more general aim (as stated by the University Learning and Teaching Strategy) is the pursuit of scholarship, leading to highly employable graduates who are able to be responsible for their own learning.

  • To define "aeroacoustics"
  • To review (relevant) theory of fluid dynamics and acoustics
  • To explain how aeroacoustics is linked to fluid dynamics
  • To introduce some of the fundamental theory of aeroacoustics, by utilising relevant theory of fluid dynamics and acoustics
  • To describe some applications of aeroacoustics
  • To explain how to apply relevant mathematical methods to solve problems in aeroacoustics
  • To provide the basis for students to be able to conduct research in aeroacoustics

introduction: This module comprises the dynamics components of the Mechanics, Structures and Materials module (FEEG1002) and is specifically for students on the Acoustics and Music joint honours degree programme. The fundamental principles of dynamics covered here provide a foundation and prerequisite for the Mechanics, Machines and Vibration module (FEEG****) in part 2.
learningoutcomes:
This module aims to review the principles of dynamics and apply them to the solution of simple dynamic systems.

Learning outcomes

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

D1 The fundamental concepts of kinematics and kinetics of particles
  The fundamental concepts of kinetics of systems of particles
  Plane kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies
  Three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies
  Conservation of energy and momentum
  Rockets and jet propulsion
D2  The fundamental assumptions of lumped parameter mass, stiffness and damper models
  Free vibrations of a single degree of freedom mechanical system
  Steady-state vibration analysis of a single degree of freedom mechanical system subjected to harmonic forces and base motion.
  Vibration based transfer functions, how they are inter-related and portrayed graphically
  The trade-off between high and low stiffness/damping for vibration isolation

 

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

D1 Develop particle and rigid body trajectory equations
  Calculate the motion of rigid bodies
  Discuss the motion of rockets and jet-propelled vehicles
D2 Analyse both free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems
  Interpret, process and appropriately plot vibration based transfer functions
  Predict the effectiveness of a vibration isolator given single degree of freedom assumptions

introduction: This module aims to examine aspects of design relevant to the longitudinal and transverse strength of a ship. This is conducted through both first principles design and the use of classification society rules. In addition the production technology applicable to the shipbuilding industry is examined from the perspective of the shipyard and its management but also from a design for production viewpoint. The complementary management module will also provide production planning and scheduling relevant to ship production.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide an overview of shipbuilding practices and applications fundamental knowledge to ship design problems.
  • Apply principles of structural behaviour to structural components relevant to ships and other marine structures, and to the design of ships in terms of longitudinal and transverse strength analysis.

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • How shipyard facilities and machines are organised.
  • The manner in which these influence the various production stages.
  • The impact of some production activities on planning and management functions.
  • The role of Classification Societies and Registration Authorities.
  • The construction of a mid-ship section.
  • Classification Society rules governing local structural design and global hull girder longitudinal strength.
  • The application of slender beam theory for the analysis of ship structures.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Estimate labour, material, machine and space resource requirements.
  • Calculate productivity, ship efficiency and machine utilisation figures.
  • Derivation of activity networks for planning purposes.
  • Use theoretical principles provided in other lectures in a practical design environment.
  • Apply Classification society Rules to design a midship section.
  • Understand the principles of structural response to a variety of static loads.
  • Cultivate skilful application of associated methods to a variety of structures and loads (ie. knowing which method to apply for a particular structure/loading case).

Practical skills

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Sketch typical production shop layouts.
  • Manipulate historically derived production data for forward planning.
  • Estimate shop floor productivity indices.
  • Select and apply suitable Classification Society rules.
  • Use commercial design software.
  • Construct and solve suitable mathematical models to describe the response of structures and structural elements to static loads.
  • Use a range of measurement techniques to obtain data.
  • Use a range of analyses/techniques to present data.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Organise and plan work and allocate time for individual ship production tasks.
  • Use Classification Society rules.
  • Use commercial software in design context.
  • Communicate effectively your work in a technical written report.
  • Present technical data in a professional manner.
  • Undertake typical assignments which may be carried out in a design office base course
  • Learn independently.
  • Obtain and analyse critically data applying your knowledge/understanding of this module.

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
