introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Reminder of the wave equations for vibrations in beams and plates.
  • Introduction to variational calculus and the Lagrangian.
  • Formulation of the equation of motion for free vibrations in beams and plates using the Rayleigh-Ritz approximate method.
  • Formulation of the equation of motion for axial and bending free vibrations in beams using the Finite Element Method (FEM).
  • Numerical reduction of a FEM by means of geometrical considerations (symmetry, periodicity, constraints) and using the Guyan reduction technique.
  • Eigenvalue-eigenvector analysis of the matrix equation of motion derived with the Rayleigh-Ritz or FEM methods in order to determine the natural frequencies and natural modes of the structure modelled.
  • Eigenvalue-eigenvector intrinsic (orthogonality) and normalisation properties (construction of the modal matrix for the forced vibration analysis).
  • Forced vibration analysis using the direct and modal methods with reference to both harmonic and periodic excitations.
  • General purpose concepts for the use of commercial FEM codes.
  • Finite element model validation.

 

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Make appropriate modelling decisions (regarding meshing, element type, boundary conditions, solution type etc) which are consistent with the anticipated structural dynamic behaviour and knowledge of the FE formulation.
  • Assess, by comparisons with experimental data as directed, the appropriateness of the model.

 

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Operate the commercial code ANSYS to solve vibration problems on simplified model systems.
  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to numerical methods in structural dynamics.

 

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Program in Matlab to obtain numerical solutions to large order sets of equations.
  • Acquire a working knowledge of new software packages.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide a general introduction to the use of the finite element method for obtaining numerical solutions to the vibration response of mechanical systems.

 

 

  • To give the fundamental concepts of variational calculus, Hamilton and Lagrangian formulation and the Rayleigh and Ritz method for the calculation of natural frequencies and modes of distributed simple structures such as beams.
  • To provide a general introduction to the theory and use of finite element techniques for vibration analysis of practical structures.
  • To give the student direct experience of the use of computer software which employs numerical methods for the solution of vibration problems.

introduction:
Student outcomes

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems
h. the broad education necessary to understand the impact of engineering solutions in a global, economic, environmental and societal context
k. an ability to use the techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • A process flow sheet.
  • Appropriate treatment methods for municipal and certain industrial effluents.
  • How water and wasterwater treatment plants operate.
  • Simple design equations for water and wastewater treatment plant.
  • Standards that are applied to drinking water.
  • Standards that are applied to sludge arising from water and wastewater treatment processes.
  • Standards that are applied to wastewater treatment plant effluents.
  • The chemical and biological prociples behind unit processes used in water and wastewatre treatment unit processes.
  • The concept of a unit operation and a unit process.
  • The fundemental scientific processes underlying the design and operation of water and wastewater treatment plant.
  • The management of residuals from water and wastewater treatment.
  • The methods that are used for the design of a water and wastewater treatment plant.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Select the correct series of unit processes for a particular water and wastewater type.
  • Critically analyse problems that may arise in the operation of water and wastewater treatment plant.
  • Adapt and use in the correct context design equations for the design and operation of wastewater treatment plant.
  • Formulate approaches to treat water and wastewater in the most cost effective manner.
  • Recognise limitations to process design of water and wastewater treatment processes.
  • Recognise water and effluent treatment processes as part of our engineered infrastructure.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Key skills

  • Rearrange simple mathematical formula
  • Develop time management skills
  • Develop independent learning skills
  • Interpret numerical data
  • Look up key reference material in library
learningoutcomes:
The module is divided into two parts. One part looks at the types of process that are used to purify water to a standard acceptable for distribution. The subject material is taught so as to give a fundamental understanding of the physical, chemical and biological mechanisms involved in these operations. These include: coagulation and precipitation, sedimentation, filtration and disinfection. Water quality standards relevant to water use are reviewed, along with the rationale for the adoption of such standards from the perspective of protection of public health.

The other part of the module looks at the sources and types of wastewater that are generated by an industrialised society. These are considered from the viewpoint of how treatment is carried out so as to prevent environmental damage upon discharge. The taught element of the course covers the various unit operations concerned with the preliminary, primary and secondary treatment of municipal wastewaters: treatment of industrial wastewaters is also briefly mentioned as similar technologies are used, and any differences from municipal wastewater are highlighted. The treatment of the biosolids generated as a result of wastewater treatment is critically analysed in relation to the final disposal options.

introduction: In semester 1, this module sets out with generic content to examine professional engineering roles, creative thinking and the ability to evaluate new ideas for problem solving within the framework of the knowledge economy.  The module in semester 2 will introduce students to functional materials and provides a specific subject to reinforce the learned skills developed in semester 1 and exposes them to critically reviewing and interpreting cutting-edge science and engineering.
learningoutcomes:
This module combines both training as a professional engineer and introduction to modern, functional materials. It aims to:

  • To provide an appreciation of the responsibilities inherent in being a Professional Engineer.
  • To provide students with development opportunities for key skills that will be required throughout their studies. For example, interpersonal skills which are essential for modern engineers to effectively communicate their ideas in various formats: written reports and presentations, and effective team membership.
  • To begin the process of reflective practise where students evaluate / reflect on their skill levels, develop learning goals and manage their learning.
  • To provide fundamental understanding of functional materials and materials properties, including a selection of: electrical properties, optical properties, and magnetic properties.
  • To provide understanding of the concept, role, types, properties and production of surface coatings for mechanical engineering applications.
  • To provide a systematic and coherent understanding of nanotechnology and nanomaterials.

In semester 1, this module sets out with generic content to examine professional engineering roles, creative thinking and the ability to evaluate new ideas for problem solving within the framework of the knowledge economy. The module in semester 2 will introduce students to functional materials and provides a specific subject to reinforce the learned skills developed in semester 1 and exposes them to critically reviewing and interpreting cutting-edge science and engineering.

Learning Outcomes:

Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the following:

  • The historical development of and changing shape of Mechanical Engineering roles on the development of and changing shape of Mechanical Engineering roles.
  • Creativity and opportunity recognition in the knowledge economy and how this relates to enterprising mechanical engineering roles.
  • The ethical code of conduct for professional engineers – this will include personal values as well as national and international organisations / professional bodies.
  • Health and safety issues, highlighting risk assessment and regulatory frameworks within mechanical engineering.
  • The complexity of social and professional responsibilities of mechanical engineers.
  • Environmental issues and the importance of mechanical engineering to the quality of the environment and sustainability.
  • Fundamentals of modern, functional materials and related materials properties such as electrical, optical and magnetic properties.
  • Rudimentary electronic structure theory and quantum mechanics.
  • Properties and applications of metals and semi-conductors.
  • Fundamentals of surface coatings for mechanical engineering applications.
  • Fundamentals of nanotechnology and nanomaterials.

Intellectual skills. Having successfully completed the module you should be able to: 

  • Relate the knowledge economy to entrepreneurial behaviour
  • Predict and molecular simulate on wear failure.
  • Recognise, list and describe ethical issues raised in case studies and professional importance to the engineer.
  • Reflect / evaluate personal skills developed through the module and produce an effective action plan for further development of skills.
  • List and describe properties of functional materials.
  • Relate atomic/electronic structure to applications of functional materials.
  • Explain design concepts for functional materials.
  • List the main types of coatings for mechanical applications, their main synthesis processes, properties and applications.
  • List the main types of nanomaterials, their main synthesis processes, properties and applications.

Practical skills. Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:

  • Work effectively as a team member and identify aspects of team roles that need further development.
  • Work with others to effectively use presentation techniques for report writing and presentation using PowerPoint.
  • Work with others to effectively use problem solving/decision making techniques
  • Articulate your developing skills.
  • Apply professional skills to master a new subject with minimal guidance.
  • Obtain knowledge from primary scientific literature.

Read and apply commonly used Materials Science tools such as band structure diagrams to solve engineering tasks.

Key skills

  • Problem analysis and problem solving.
  • Research and independent study.
  • Communication in a professional environment.

The aims of this module are to:

Provide an understanding of the fundamental steps in the marine craft concept design process.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • The functions and applications of marine craft concept design methodologies.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply the methodologies and tools used in the marine craft concept design process to the concept design of a marine craft. 

Practical skills  
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Create a concept design and carry out relevant checks to verify its feasibility, given an outline specification.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Work as a group on a concept design assignment.

continuousassessment.description: Final coursework drawing(s), calculations and report

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Interdisciplinary approaches to assessing significance of effects
  • The current legislation covering EIA
  • The principles of EIA
  • The role of EIA in sustainable development
learningoutcomes: Environmental impact assessment (EIA) has been progressively introduced over recent decades as a tool to help deliver sustainable development. Across the world, major developments are usually subject to systematic assessment of the impacts they may have on the environment before permission is given for them to proceed. Impacts which are judged to be significant should be mitigated; alternatives should be considered, and the public involved in the decision making process. The process can also extend beyond projects to policy, plan or programme level, through Strategic EIA (or "SEA").  This module aims to train students in EIA, so they have general understanding of the process and sufficient knowledge to be involved professionally.

continuousassessment.description: Scoping report on a major development (group exercise with peeer assessment)

introduction:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide an introduction to the principles relevant to the exchange,
    transport and conservation of energy.

    occur.

The aims of this module are to:
  • provide an insight into the basic structural, electronic and operation of a vehicle which the automotive designer must take into consideration.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Electrical and electronic systems in Automotive application, with an emphasis on Electromechanical Devices, and to indicate future developments in this field.

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

The aims of this module are to:
  • Assess the requirements for spacecraft instrumentation
  • To provide an overview of the different types of instruments flown on spacecraft
  • To provide students with an appreciation and understanding of the development of the design processes involved for different instruments and how they interface with the spacecraft platform.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
The development of spacecraft instrumentation, starting from the definition of the requirements to the final instrument design and operation. You will also gain a good understanding of the basic principles of the interaction between the instrument and the platform and the space qualification process.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the basic physical principles involved in spacecraft instrument measurements and how these are translated into specific requirements for the instrument itself
  • Perform calculations from first principles to allow simple first order design analyses for a range of instruments
  • Select appropriate components to put together the design of complete instruments
  • Select and size an appropriate spacecraft platform to carry a specific instrument, identify ( at a high systems level) the key interfaces and do simple orbit/operations analyses.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide the theoretical understanding required to design suitable energy conversion devices suitable for exploiting wind, both on and offshore, ocean wave and marine currents.
  • To understand the practical limitations imposed by structural loadings and responses on such devices.
  • To be able to site such devices based on knowledge of local oceanographic and meteorological data.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:  

  • Physical principles that can be used to extract usable energy from wind, wave and current (T,AE).
  • Dynamics of the ocean and atmosphere relevant to energy extraction (T,AE).
  • Fluid dynamic analysis of potential or actual devices for extracting energy form the environment (T,AE,AC)
  • The methods of calculating the resultant structural loads and responses (T,AE)
  • How devices are sited and the considerations required for installation, maintenance, operational control and eventual decommissioning (T,AE,AC)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Search and critically review technical literature relevant to renewable energy (D,AC)
  • Analyse performance of wind and current turbines alongside a selection of wave energy devices (T,AE)
  • Aware of the trade-offs between suitable sites and issues associated with performance of renewable energy systems (T,AC)
  • Appreciate the complexities associated with their potential environmental impact on noise, visual intrusion, marine life alongside safety of shipping (T,AC).

Practical skills 
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Carry out Blade Element Momentum analysis calculations for turbine performance(AC)
  • Match performance of energy device to suitable generator system (AC)
  • Estimate the energy yield of a specific site based on knowledge of annual variation in sea state or wind speed or marine current (AE)
  • Calculate structural loads on devices as well as on foundations, fixings/mooring systems (AE)
  • Examine possible response modes and likely issues associated with long-term operation (AE)

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: 

  • Think, observe, communicate, evaluate information and data, analyse and solve problems (D,AC)
  • Awareness of interaction between engineering system design and local environment (D,AE)

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
Aims

The aims of this module are to:
• enable you to understand the pathological processes that can lead to disorders of hearing and balance
• enable you to understand the methods used for the assessment of the balance system
• enable you to understand electrophysiological methods of assessing hearing thresholds
• enable you to understand clinical findings and draw conclusions regarding diagnosis enable you to further develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from a variety of sources

Learning outcomes

The learning outcomes of this module are:
• that you will be able to outline the different pathologies associated with disorders of hearing and balance
• that you will be able to evaluate the different tests used to assess vestibular/balance system
• that you will be able to establish hearing thresholds using objective techniques
• that you will able to integrate results from a number of sources and differentiate between different diagnoses
• that you will be able to evaluate and synthesise information from the evidence base

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide a basic understanding of the theory and practice of fuel cells, batteries and related devices and to appreciate the challenges facing their design and operation.
  • Develop an understanding of photovoltaic solar energy conversion, provide an overview of solar cell operation and analyse photovoltaic systems as a power generation technology.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Electrochemical routes to energy conversion
  • The relative merits of batteries, fuel cells and redox flow cells
  • Solar radiation as an energy source
  • Solar cell operation and manufacture
  • Design and operation of a photovoltaic system

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Tackle simple problems of theoretical energy conversion
  • Relate cell current to materials conversion rates
  • Suggest an appropriate fuel cell or battery technology for a particular application
  • Analyse solar radiation in energy terms
  • Describe the fundamentals of photovoltaic energy conversion
  • Assess the operation and manufacture of a solar cell
  • Identify and size a photovoltaic system for a given application

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Access the literature on fuel cells and write reports on their development
  • Appreciate an industrial perspective of technology development
  • Process solar energy data for photovoltaic applications
  • Design a photovoltaic system

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide students with an understanding of the principles of fluid mechanics and the numerical procedures in CFD.
  • Provide students with knowledge of scientific programming (in C/C++).
  • Develop programming skills to solve some specific CFD problems.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Fundamental fluid dynamic principles and their applications. [T, AE]
  • The use of potential flow theory for incompressible problems and extension via Green's function to 3D flows around complex geometries. [T, AE, AC]
  • Finite difference/finite volume representation of pde's and how numerical solution procedures are applied. [T, AE, AC]
  • CFD solution procedures including grid generation and post processing. [T, AE, AC]
  • Fundamental elements of the C/C++ programming language, including program design and implementations. [T, AC]

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Solve viscous flow problems in particular for Reynolds Number typical in marine/aerospace applications concentrating on 2D thin boundary layer and RANS equations. [T, AE, AC]
  • Analyse, using classical techniques, a wider range of fluid dynamics problems and an understanding of how such techniques can be implemented using numerical calculations. [T, AE, AC]
  • Translate mathematical models into appropriate C/C++ programs. [T, AC]

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Write structured programs in C/C++ to solve numerically basic equations of fluid dynamics. [T, AC]

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Improve your numerical and I.T. skills. [T, AC]

Knowledge and understanding

introduction:

learningoutcomes:
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the following:

Intellectual skills.  Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:

Practical skills.  Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:

  • Select nanostructured materials for tribological applications
  • Assess and measure nano surface features
  • Recognize the appropriate techniques for measuring surface and bulk properties of biological materials.
  • Design a bacteria adhesion assay on different surfaces.

Key skills

  • Contribute to nano and bio tribology knowledge
  • Plan and organise both time and resources.
  • Problem analysis and problem solving.
  • Research and independent study

introduction:
This module sets the context for structural engineering from an interdisciplinary technical perspective as found in most large-scale building projects. The course covers the key technical parameters of construction systems, building services design, acoustics, fire engineering, and facades: all aspects that influence structural design. The module also examines the role of Building Information Modelling (BIM) in building design.

The module is particularly suitable for students who are working on a major building project design or considering a research field related to the design of buildings.
learningoutcomes:
At the end of the module, students will have gained knowledge and understanding of the key engineering disciplines involved in the design and construction of buildings and an ability to choose structural design options that address these inter-related and sometimes conflicting demands on a project.

The module is looking at the collaboration of technical ‘specialisms’ rather than generalising on construction outcomes as found in Project and Construction Management courses. The teaching outlook is based on a premise that the fundamental characteristic of current design practice is the effective collaboration of specialists that produce intelligent designs by integrating the technical, aesthetic, social and economic needs of a project (Spence R et al 2001 - Interdisciplinary education for design professionals – Gann D & Salter. Spence R, Macmillan S, Kirby P, 2001. Interdisciplinary Design in Practice. Thomas Telford, London).

The module compliments previous knowledge in mathematics, statics, structural analysis, and ground engineering. It will cover advanced areas of building construction in relation to structural theory, building ventilation and thermal performance, mechanical services for low energy design, fire engineering, acoustics and building façade technologies. To illustrate interdisciplinary design practice the course will use case studies taken from many building sectors such as schools, hospitals, research laboratories, commercial buildings (accommodation, offices and mixed-use developments), public buildings (museums & libraries), tall buildings and long-span lightweight structures (canopies, sports stadia).

Learning outcomes in detail are as follows:

1. Interdisciplinary design of construction systems
1.1 Awareness of the main architectural and technical drivers influencing the concept design of construction systems
1.2 Knowing how the main engineering disciplines collaborate on the schematic and detailed design of buildings.
1.3 Ability to develop structural designs based on building construction systems.
2. Building Environmental Control
2.1 Awareness of the human needs that drive environmental control systems for buildings.
2.2 Understanding the principles of passive design for environmental control of buildings
2.3 Knowing which building services systems to select for different spaces and environmental conditions
2.4 Ability to pre-size building services plant and interpret schematics for distribution networks.
3. Fire Engineering
3.1 Awareness of the statutory approach and the engineering approach to dealing with fire.
3.2 Knowing how a fire engineering approach can be used to influence the layout and construction of buildings.
3.3 Ability to analyse structures for fire engineering performance.
4. Building Acoustics
4.1 Awareness of the nature of sound and how acoustic & vibration performance is assessed in buildings
4.2 Knowing how to design buildings to optimise acoustic performance
4.3 Ability to calculate the acoustic profile of a spatial and construction arrangement.
5. Building Envelope
5.1 Awareness of the main criteria for specifying a building envelope
5.2 Knowing how façade systems perform.
5.3 Ability to select and detail a façade system.
6. Building Information Modelling (BIM)
6.1 Awareness of the growing impact of BIM in the collaborative process of project designs
6.2 Knowing how the different elements of design combine, based on a common data model
6.3 Ability to manipulate data to optimise integrated building design performance through BIM

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas: • anatomy of basic neurosensory systems. • physiological functioning of basic units and sub-systems of neurosensory system • Basic pathophysiological principles and assessment • Describe common forms of medical and surgical treatment and underline their principles

 

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • relate the functioning of the basic units to the neurosensory systems. You will be able to apply general concepts in psychology and sociology to neurosensory difficulties.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • relate aspects of neurosensory function and failure in individual cases to the underlying principles of biology, psychology and sociology.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in: • You will have gained a better understanding of human physiological systems and social behaviour in general.
learningoutcomes:
• To give you the basic underpinning knowledge in behavioural and human biological sciences to support learning in other modules. • enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from books, web based learning and relevant scientific literature.

• Describe the basic anatomy of body systems including the nervous system , central and peripheral • Describe the anatomy and physiology of the ear and hearing • Describe the anatomy and physiology of the visual system . • Describe the disease process and treatment in these systems • Basic pharmacology and pharmokinetics

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide you with a broad basis in understanding the principles of structural behaviour and the methods of predicting stresses and deformations resulting from a variety of static loads.
  • Apply these principles and methods to structural components relevant to ships and other marine structures, and to the design of ships in terms of longitudinal and transverse strength analysis.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The application of analysis of individual loading cases (ie. bending, buckling, shear, torsion) for structural components (eg. beams).
  • Extending the aforementioned methods to the analysis of structures (eg. beams on multiple supports, frames, ships).
  • Generic methods (eg. energy methods) and their application to structures/components.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the principles of structural response to a variety of static loads.
  • Cultivate skilful application of associated methods to a variety of structures and loads (ie. knowing which method to apply for a particular structure/loading case).

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Construct and solve suitable mathematical models to describe the response of structures and structural elements to static loads.
  • Use a range of measurement techniques to obtain data.
  • Use a range of analyses/techniques to present data.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn independently.
  • Obtain and analyse critically data applying your knowledge/understanding of this module.
  • Communicate effectively your work in a written report.
  • Teamworking through Laboratory experiment.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Be able to integrate the biological and engineering principles of resource use and productivity in a quantitative manner in order to assess the effectiveness of agricultural and agroforestry biomass production systems
  • Be able to locate relevant information sources on biomass energy and to critically assess the quality of the data and the information source
  • Be able to produce clear and concise analyses of benefits and problems relating to the production and use of different forms of biomass energy
  • Be aware of the framework within which biomass is considered as a renewable energy source, including the socio-economic, political, historical, and environmental contexts that are relevant
  • Carry out a quantitative outline process and systems design which illustrates the approach that needs to be adopted when considering biomass as a renewable energy source
  • Have a broad knowledge of the main sources of biomass, the origins of these sources, and the means by which they can be exploited for energy generation
  • Have a detailed quantitative understanding of the energy-generating potential of biomass as an energy source used in different ways and be able to perform analyses of the energy conversion potential from these within the context of a full life cycle approach
  • In the context of the design choices, make the appropriate assumptions, utilise the right tools and analyses, and select systems that work for the community, the environment and the client
  • Understand the design basis of biomass-driven power generation and biofuel production and be able to narrow the focus of design choices in a particular context

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Analyze , synthesize and summarize information critically, including prior research
  • Collate and integrate lines of evidence from different disciplines to develop and consolidate knowledge and understanding on an objective basis
  • Propose reasoned arguments, justifying conclusions and recommendations by reference to appropriate analytical frameworks and supporting evidence
  • Use facts and data to support arguments, and assemble and critically evaluate relevant information from several sources and develop a personal point of view

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Demonstrate the ability to present and defend research
  • Compare different bioenergy technologies from various perspectives
  • Assemble a technical report

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Problem analysis and problem solving
  • Information handling
  • Critical Analysis
  • Report writing
  • Exercise independent judgement.
  • Presentation
learningoutcomes:
• To analyse the main systems and supply chains that can be used for biomass energy conversion and utilisation.
  • To be able to develop designs for biomass energy conversion and utilisation within the context of a whole systems approach.
  • To critically evaluate the environmental benefits and consequences of biomass energy production.

introduction:
Discuss the nature of electricity (electrostatic and magnetic forces), define basic quantities (charge, electric field, current, voltage and power) and introduce Coulomb electrostatic force law, Faraday's Law of induction, Ohm's law and Ampere's magnetic force law.
Introduce electric circuit theory including circuit elements, Kirchhoff's laws, and circuit analysis techniques.
Introduce the concept of phasors and its application to the analysis of AC circuits.
Introduce op-amps, diodes and transistor circuits.
Introduce digital logic circuits
Provide an introduction to electric machines and transformers, and the principle of operation of synchronous generator, the DC motor, brushless dc motor, induction motor and switched reluctance motor.
Introduce some application of electrical systems in measurement systems (transducers), signal conditioning and control.
learningoutcomes:
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Basic electrical quantities (charge, electric field, current, voltage and power) and laws (Coulomb electrostatic force law, Faraday's Law of induction, Ohm's law and
  • Ampere's magnetic force law.)
  • Principle of operation of synchronous generators and batteries.
  • Alternative electricity supplies.
  • Principle of operation of some sensors (strain gauges, thermal sensors, and other mechanical sensors).
  • Basic circuit elements of resistance, inductance and capacitance, ideal sources and their voltage/current relationships.
  • Kirchhoff's circuit laws, Thevenin's and superposition theories, and their application to circuit analysis
  • Op-amp circuit analysis, and their applications
  • Diodes and transistors theory of operation and their applications.
  • Logic circuits analysis and design techniques.
  • Principle of operation of common electrical machines including synchronous generator, the DC motor, brushless dc motor, induction motor and switched reluctance motor.
  • Principle of operation of transducers including strain gauges, accelerometers, displacement sensors, pressure sensors (including microphones), and temperature sensors.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Solve simple problems applying Faraday's Law of induction (e.g. synchronous generator, vibration sensors, transformer)
  • Solve simple problems to calculate electrostatic forces (e.g. in an electrostatic ink jet printer).
  • Solve simple problems calculating magnetic forces (e.g. in a DC motor).
  • Analyse dc circuits containing resistors, inductors and capacitors using a variety of techniques including solving loop equations; using circuit simplifications (series/parallel/star delta), thevinin or superposition theories.
  • Analyse Wheatstone bridge circuits of strain gauges and temperature sensing resistors.
  • Write state space equations for circuits containing resistors, inductors and capacitors.
  • Analyse AC circuits
  • Analyse simple circuits containing op-amps, diodes and transistors.
  • Analyse and design logic circuits.
  • Appreciate the conceptual difficulties of learning and teaching the module content, and be able to effectively communicate the concepts to others.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use Oscilloscopes, multimeters and bench power supplies and waveform generators
  • Construct electric circuits on bread board
  • Make measurements of voltage, frequency and current in a circuit
  • Plot frequency response of a circuit.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Circuit analysis is used on other subjects such as analysis of thermal problems, pipe flow problems and control system modelling problems.
  • Electric circuit construction techniques
  • Electrical measurement techniques.

introduction:

  • The principles of single-channel control systems for tonal and random signals.
  • The use of the LMS algorithm in active control systems.
  • Active control of freefield sound.
  • Multichannel control of tones and random disturbances.
  • Active control of enclosed soundfields.
  • Active structural acoustic control using integrated actuators and sensors.

  • Active headsets.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Key transferable skills
Interpret manufacturers' catalogues.

  • Integrate knowledge between the fields of acoustics, vibration, electronics and control.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Give a broad understanding of the principles of active sound and vibration control.

  • To introduce the physical principles involved in the active control of sound and vibration.
  • To discuss the various control strategies which can be used, particularly adaptive feedforward and feedback.

The aims of this module are to:
  • develop in the undergraduate the ability to analyse and thereby gain a deep understanding of the performance and dynamic characteristics of VSTOL aircraft (including rotary wing aircraft, in particular the single main and tail rotor configuration.) To achieve this, the various phenomena which affect the rotor blade aeroelastic behaviour are described, together with their influence on the overall air vehicle design. The operation of vectored thrust aircraft will be outlined with particular emphasis on the JSF and the ski jump technique of aircraft launch.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate a detailed knowledge and understanding of:

  • The methodology of the performance assessment of a VSTOL aircraft configuration and demonstrate an in-depth awareness of the contrast with conventional aircraft
  • The manner in which the basic rules of aerospace engineering apply to VSTOL configurations.
  • How advanced analytical techniques can be used to investigate all types of air vehicle and provide an across-the-board viewpoint of the future direction of aerospace.
  • Gain an introduction to the application of CAD to helicopter design and technology

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Undertake a full analysis and application of the VSTOL aircraft & helicopter design process and the effect on these results of the many features of such an aircraft to ensure efficiency and safety of operation.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Calculate helicopter performance, rotor blade motion, helicopter trim, vibration alleviation, and ground resonance.
  • Analyse the operation of vectored thrust aircraft and the demands that these place on its overall design.
  • Use case studies to demonstrate the ability to assess a proposed design for development and subsequent production.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Break down complex engineering systems into sub components for analysis. Undertake the detailed tasks in VSTOL & helicopter design by understanding the interplay between the various sub-systems and the subsequent development and flight testing of the complete air vehicle. This will be strengthened by the use of CAD with relevant examples.

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

introduction:
Student outcomes

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering
c. an ability to design a system, component, or process to meet desired needs within realistic constraints such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability, and sustainability
e. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems
k. an ability to use the techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • Define the key components of a functioning groundwater model
  • Determine the main aquifer properties – permeability, transmissivity and storage
  • Identify geological formations capable of storing and transporting groundwater
  • Understand how groundwater models can be applied in engineering analysis 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: 

  • Appraise aquifer - aquitard systems
  • Assemble the key data required to construct a functioning groundwater model
  • Analyse pumping test data
  • Construct groundwater models
  • Evaluate the risk to drinking water posed by contamination 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: 

  • Carry out a hydro-geological survey and a pumping test
  • Analyse data from pumping tests

  • Synthesize findings obtained from simulation models into a consultant's report 

Key skills

  • learn independently

learningoutcomes:
This module will describe how to assess the groundwater water resources of the UK and other countries, how to determine the key aspects of local and regional hydrogeology, and how to create ground water models. The module considers the characterisation of key aquifer types (permeability, transmissivity, storage) using both laboratory and field methods. Aquifer pumping tests will be described and the numerical techniques that are used to calculate aquifer properties.

Students will learn how to construct functioning groundwater models using MODFLOW and then apply the models to solve engineering problems. Applications in water resources, foundation de-watering and contaminated groundwater will be described using a series of case studies.

introduction: This module begins with the introduction and derivation of the fundamental conservation equations for fluid mechanics (mass, momentum and energy). The application of these equations for solving simple flow problems will be demonstrated. This is followed by sections covering (1) viscous flow theory with an emphasis on boundary layers, (2) potential flow, (3) turbomachinery fluid dynamics, (4) compressible flow (5) turbulence and (6) CFD. The lectures are complemented by 2 laboratory classes with relevance to the taught material
learningoutcomes:
To provide a basic awareness of important flow physics that mechanical and acoustical engineers are likely to encounter in the range of science and industry careers we would hope they follow.

Provide the fundamental basis for further optional courses involving fluid mechanics in part III and IV of all the degree programmes that are offered by the school.


Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Conservation laws for mass, momentum and energy.
  • Laminar and turbulent boundary layers.
  • The importance of common dimensionless groups.
  • A basic understanding of compressible fluid flow.
  • An awareness of turbulent flow.
  • Turbomachinery fluid mechanics.
  • Elementary potential flow theory.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Solve simple one-dimensional flow problems by making appropriate assumptions and by applying sensible boundary conditions.
  • Use dimensionless groups to predict the type of flow physics likely to be present.
  • Solve simple problems in one-dimensional isentropic and non-isentropic flow.
  • Qualitatively appreciate the complexity of turbulence and the need for computational models for turbulent flow
  • Solve simple turbomachinery flow problems
  • Solve simple potential flow problems
  • Apply CFD methods to calculate simple flows

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:
Demonstrate skills associated with:

  • Solve problems systematically
  • Researching and reporting assignments

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:

  • To extend your clinical procedural skills in the assessment, management and rehabilitation of adults with hearing difficulties
  • To introduce you to the basic skills required to assess children with hearing difficulties
  • To introduce you to the basic skills required to assess adults with balance difficulties
  • To further develop your skills required for interacting with patients/clients and their families

 The (teaching) objectives of this module are to:

  • Describe equipment and procedures used for the further assessment of hearing loss, testing and fitting of hearing aids, and general management and rehabilitation according to safe work practices.
  • Develop your skills in managing, interviewing, assessing and counselling patients (and their families).

 The planned learning outcomes for this module are listed in the table below. 

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas:

  • Advanced auditory assessment procedures for use with adult patients
  • Basic vestibular assessment procedures
  • Basic paediatric auditory assessment procedures
  • The need for a structured approach to patient assessment and examination
  • Basic clinical and technical procedures and processes used in interviewing adult patients with auditor or vestibular disorders and interviewing families of children with hearing difficulties
  • When and how individual procedures and processes should be applied to individual patients
  • Differences between individual patients, and how individuals vary from stereotypes
  • Deaf awareness

Cognitive skills

Having successfully completed the module, under appropriate supervision you will be able to:

  • Evaluate information in order to enable you to recognise, select and plan appropriate techniques for successful investigation of auditory disorders in adults
  • Evaluate information in order to enable you to recognise, select and plan appropriate techniques for successful investigation of vestibular disorders in adults
  • Evaluate information in order to enable you to recognise, select and plan appropriate techniques for successful investigation of auditory disorders in children
  • Assess the validity of your clinical observations and interpret them
  • Analyse, synthesise and evaluate information from a variety of sources (including information from the patient and the results of assessment procedures) to identify specific auditory disorders in adults and plan appropriate management interventions
  • Analyse, synthesise and evaluate information from a variety of sources (including information from the patient and the results of assessment procedures) to identify specific vestibular disorders in adults
  • Analyse, synthesise and evaluate information from a variety of sources (including information from the patient and the results of assessment procedures) to identify specific auditory disorders in children
  • Describe the outcomes of a clinic session and combine them with other relevant details in a formal report

Practical skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Gather salient information from patients/clients and their families or carers
  • Communicate relevant information to patients/clients and their families or carers, using appropriate terminology and counselling skills
  • Form a clinical strategy of investigation for individuals with either auditory or balance difficulties
  • Perform a range of Audiological procedures safely and accurately with co-operative adults and children
  • Assess the validity and accuracy of a range of Audiological procedures in individual cases and interpret those results on an individual basis
  • Understand ‘whole-case' management, co-operative intra-professional and inter-professional working, and the need for clear pathways for onward referral.

Key transferable skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will have improved your skills in:

  • Safe working practices
  • The use of technical apparatus including computer based procedures
  • Communicating with a range of adults and children (and their families)

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be expected to be able to:

  • Recognise dose-response relationships in humans and associated risks caused by human exposure to hand-transmitted vibration and whole-body vibration.

Having successfully completed the module, you will be expected to be able to:

  • Understand and critically assess the assumptions inherent in methods of measuring, evaluating and assessing human response to vibration with reference to current national and international standards.

learningoutcomes:
• To introduce you to human responses to vibration and how they can be predicted from measurements of vibration exposure.

introduction:
The Undergraduate Ambassador Scheme was initially founded to encourage graduates to consider teaching as a career, particularly in shortage subject areas (maths, sciences), and is currently available in other schools within the University of Southampton as well as in some other universities. However, importantly this module aims to provide you with teaching experience and valuable transferable skills. The module has no formal lectures, but instead involves you spending time outside of university within a local school (primary, secondary or tertiary) for approximately ½ day a week for a full semester (10 weeks) supported by tutorials at university. During the placements, you will initially observe teaching but gradually become more involved in the classroom, ultimately carrying out a special project with pupils. As you will be acting as a role model within a local schools and due to the limited number of placements, there is an interview process. This also serves to match you up with an appropriate school and teacher based on your preferences and what you want to get out of the module.

The module is reliant on placements being secured in local primary, secondary schools or tertiary colleges, which limits the number of students that this module can be made available to. A cap of about 20 students is a reasonable estimate. It is therefore important to select students based on an application form and interview process to assess their suitability for the module and to act as representatives of the University. A Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) check is also necessary before placements can commence, therefore participation on this module cannot be guaranteed to all students that pass the interview.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • To develop an appreciation for what it takes to be a teacher and absorb some of the requisite skills.
  • To develop communication and organisational skills and to learn to understand and address other individuals' needs, particularly in a learning context.
  • To develop ideas for presentation that provide inspiration for learning
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AC) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • The needs of different learners in institutional settings and how appropriate teaching methods might address these. (D,AC)
  • The multi-faceted nature of teaching to a variety of individuals with different sets of needs in potentially unpredictable circumstances. (D,AC)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Develop and plan teaching materials which are appropriate for the relevant age or standard. (D,AC,AP)
  • Modify and redesign subject material in different ways in order to reach a wider audience. (D,AC,AP)
  • Identify material that represents a source of intellectual excitement and hence worthy of careful study. (D,AC,AP)

Practical and General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Provide support and assistance to teachers in a responsible and confident manner, thus developing skills for collaboration and teamwork. (D,AC)
  • Develop communication and organisational skills. (D,AC,AP)
  • Make up lesson plans and teaching materials. (D,AC)
  • Assess and respond to challenging circumstances in a public forum. (D,AC,AP)
  • Improvise in a responsible way. (A,AC.AP)
  • Provide reflective feedback to others. (A,AC)

introduction:
Modern audio equipment allows effective recordings to be made without necessarily requiring any indepth understanding of the physical principles and technical concepts involved. However, understanding the desired qualities of the end product and how these can best be achieved by taking into account the acoustical characteristics of the sources, the acoustic spaces in which they are recorded, and the capabilities and limitations of the equipment, ensures that the user is fully aware of all technical
possibilities and thereby increases the chances of successfully obtaining higher quality recordings or recordings which more closely approach to desired characteristics. The main aim of this course is to enhance that understanding.
learningoutcomes:
Modern audio equipment allows effective recordings to be made without necessarily requiring any indepth understanding of the physical principles and technical concepts involved. However, understanding the desired qualities of the end product and how these can best be achieved by taking into account the acoustical characteristics of the sources, the acoustic spaces in which they are recorded, and the capabilities and limitations of the equipment, ensures that the user is fully aware of all technical
possibilities and thereby increases the chances of successfully obtaining higher quality recordings or recordings which more closely approach to desired characteristics. The main aim of this course is to enhance that understanding.

Objectives (teaching)

  • To review and understand relevant theory, including the acoustical characteristics of sources and
    rooms, transducers, processing techniques, and (data) recording systems.
  •  To become familiar with practical audio equipment and its limitations based upon understanding the theory behind its operation.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)
Knowledge and understanding
In this field, technical aspects are subservient to creative and/or commercial success, which are in turn dependent on subjective attitudes and opinions and not necessarily on frequency response or signal to noise ratio. However, increased knowledge and understanding of the technical aspects listed below will enhance opportunities to contribute to creative and/or commercial success. Having successfully
completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply physical acoustics and audio perception theory to understand the capabilities and limitations of audio recording facilities and equipment.
  • Explain the interactions between sources and acoustic spaces used for recordin
  • Describe the various options available for acoustic treatment.
  • Select and operate transducers to obtain performance consistent with creative objectives, and explain and justify your choices.
  • Select monitoring options in relation to advantages and disadvantages in different recording situations, and explain and justify your choices.
  • Select and operate audio processing and explain and justify your choices.
  • Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of alternative analogue and digital techniques.
  • Produce a basic mix-down of sample multi-track recordings, with a written explanation and justification describing all choices and assumptions made during the process starting from setting up the initial recordings to the final product.

Cognitive (thinking) skills

  • Critically interpret a wide range of both practical and scientific textbooks and papers related to audio recording
  • Apply theory to practical problems
  • Evaluate evidence and reach sound judgements in complex multi-variable situations.

Practical, subject-specific skills

  • Select recording techniques and equipment for different applications in professional audio
  • Operate audio recording equipment in respect of known technical capabilities and limitations

Key transferable skills

  • Analysis, synthesis and critical evaluation of technical information in a practical context
  • Engineering judgement based on both objective and subjective criteria of judging audio recording quality
  • Mathematical analysis, modelling and problem solving
    Presentation skills (see assignment No. 1)

introduction:
The module is focussed around advanced computational methods incorporating C and compiled languages, computational modelling numerical techniques for science and engineering. It builds on lower level courses such as FEEG1001 and FEEG2001 and assumes that the students are familiar already with one programming language (typically Python).

Through the lectures (3 per week) and directed reading you will be able to gain understanding of the principles and methods of advanced numerical techniques along with C programming skills and how these are applied to problem solving. The labs will cover both C programming and numerical modelling and will give you the opportunity to apply and enhance this understanding. Support in the lab sessions will help you to prepare for programming assignments, which will provide you with feedback on your ability to apply your knowledge and skills to a variety of problems. Module overview
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide students with a sound understanding of computational methods and how this can be applied to engineering problems
  • Provide insight and practical skills in C programming
  • Provide insight into advanced data structures, algorithms and software design techniques

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • How to employ the sonar equations, to model and assess the performance of sonar systems.
  • The trade-offs involved when designing a sonar system.
  • Elementary modelling of acoustic scattering: as it affects both acoustic targets and volume reverberation.
  • The range of propagation models available.
  • Ray tracing methods in a range independent, deep water, context and in shallow water through the use of the method of images.
  • Normal mode methods for shallow water propagation modelling, assuming simple boundary conditions.
  • The transduction mechanisms in marine mammals.
  • The role of underwater acoustics in the protection of marine mammals.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to underwater acoustics.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • To select an appropriate propagation model.
  • To advise on the construction of an EIA from underwater noise.

Key transferable skills

  • Understand the issues associated with acoustic modelling in general.
  • Appreciate system design issues.
  • Comprehend the basics of the need to assess environmental impacts.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • To provide an overview of mathematical techniques used in sonar system modelling and to provide an appreciation of the potential impact of sonar systems on marine mammals.

  • To provide a summary of sonar system performance evaluation techniques, through the âsonar equationsâ.
  • To offer a basic understanding of the principles of simple acoustic propagation models.
  • To provide an overview of how marine mammals employ sonar and to understand how human noise can impact on them.

introduction: This module will teach a systems approach to water resources planning and management using the principles of simulation, optimization and multi-criterion decision making in the context of sound engineering economics.
learningoutcomes:
Water resources are under increasing pressure from growing demands from towns, industry and agriculture. We are also facing an uncertain future due to anticipated climate change. The recent sequences of drought and flood years has shown that that traditional civil engineering solutions to managing water resources are not necessarily the most effective. Water resources planning and management has to look beyond simple utilization of existing structures. Solutions have to work within the Water Framework Directive so water resources planning and management needs a systems analysis approach. This will include managing the available water resource and water demands within the constraints set by technical, social, political and economic drivers. This module will teach a systems approach to water resources planning and management using the principles of simulation, optimization and multi-criterion decision making in the context of sound engineering economics.

Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:
- Quantify water demands from various sectors (towns, agriculture and industry)
- Identify available water resources and how these vary in time
- Understand how to construct and operate river basin models e.g. WEAP
- Understand the constraints of the Water Framework Directive
- Build simple optimisation models using Linear Programming
- Construct and operate optimisation models with uncertain data
- Be competent in the use of advanced optimisation models such as LINGO.
- Evaluate risk in planning for floods and droughts
- Generate stochastic models to evaluate system management options
- Design performance criteria for model operation
- Apply optimisation models to a river basin system

The aims of this module are to:

  • To emphasise the importance of considering noise control at the design stage rather than as a remedial process
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Assess the noise control requirements arising from simple acoustics sources
  • Design and evaluate such items as acoustic enclosures, screens and walls.
  • Design a simple silencer using an absorptive or reactive model and determine its effectiveness.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Appreciate how legal, health and safety, and ergonomic issues interact in an applied engineering discipline.
  • Identify key facts and produce summary notes

introduction: At the end of the module the students should be able to describe the functioning of the auditory system, explain what covers the frequency characteristics and also why the metrics used (dB, dBA, etc) have been adopted to quantify noise.  Good understanding of the acoustic plane wave equation should be displayed by a physical interpretation of waves, their propagation, reflection, transmission and absorption. Calculations based 1D acoustic systems can be performed.  For a given application and requirement, the students should be able to choose and explain the instrumentation and identify its limitations and uses for acoustic measurements.
learningoutcomes:
The aims are to introduce the fundamentals of acoustics with emphasis on the underlying physical principles.  The course will concentrate on longitudinal plane wave acoustics. In addition, the basic physiology of the auditory system and the metrics involved in sound measurements and perception will be covered.  For the purposes of practical measurements, the associated microphone technology will be described, showing how they operate and the underlying physical mechanisms that govern the frequency and amplitude characteristics.

At the end of the module the students should be able to describe the functioning of the auditory system, explain what produces the frequency characteristics and also why the metrics used (dB, dBA, etc) have been adopted to quantify noise.  Good understanding of the acoustic plane wave equation should be displayed by a physical interpretation of waves, their propagation, reflection, transmission and absorption. Calculations based 1D acoustic systems can be performed.  For a given application and requirement, the students should be able to choose and explain the instrumentation and identify its limitations and uses for acoustic measurements.

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

The auditory system

  • Identify the parts of the outer, middle and inner ear explaining their role"
  • Describe what governs or affects the hearing of an individual.
  • Explain the role of the two ears in distinguishing the direction of an acoustic source.

The acoustic metrics

  • Convert noise levels into dB and linear levels, combining noise sources either coherent or incoherent.
  • From narrowband data be able to convert into third and octave band levels either with linear or A weighting.

 Acoustic measurement technology

  • Describe the physical principles for such simple transducers
  • Explain what governs their frequency response and which type is appropriate for different acoustic applications.

 Waves

  • define "what is a wave?"
  • explain the difference between dispersive and non-dispersive wave motion.
  • describe examples of some common wave phenomena.

Sound Waves in Fluids

  • recognize that elasticity and inertia are the key properties that support sound waves in fluids.
  • calculate the theoretical speed of sound in a fluid

Acoustic Signals

  • understand that acoustic signals can be represented in the time or frequency domain, and recognize the usefulness of time-harmonic signals.
  • define different dB levels used in acoustics.

Acoustic Plane Waves

  • recognize the plane wave equation, and understand how to solve this equation using the complex exponential function exp(jwt) for time-harmonic waves.
  • interpret solutions of the plane wave equation in terms of one-dimensional travelling waves.
  • define a standing wave, and perform calculations for one-dimensional examples of standing waves.

 Sound propagation, reflection, transmission, refraction and absorption

  • explain geometrical spreading for cylindrical and spherical waves.
  • understand the difference between rigid and pressure-release boundaries.
  • calculate reflection and transmission coefficients for transmission at a fluid-fluid interface (normal incidence only).
  • describe examples of sound refraction in the atmosphere and underwater, and use Snell's law.
  • explain how to evaluate the absorption coefficient for a sample of material using an impedance tube.

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Appreciate the relevance of acoustics in practical applications.
  • Recognize examples of common wave phenomena.
  • Improved ability to read and interpret acoustics texts.
  • Model simple problems in acoustics, and derive solutions to these problems.

Practical skills

Having successfully completed the module you will be able to:

  • Carry out calculations relating to acoustic predictions
  • Use a sound level meter and be able to measure sound pressure levels which are calibrated and repeatable, with awareness of the uncertainty and factors that might affect the measurements
  • Undertake simple acoustic measurements on one dimensional acoustic phenomena
  • Collate experimental data
  • Manipulate experimental data in order to draw specific conclusions

General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will have developed skills in:

  • Information handling
  • Written communication
  • Numeracy and manipulating data
  • Being an independent learner

introduction:
The aims of this module are to:
• equip you with the basic knowledge and understanding required to provide a clinical hearing aid service or to pursue research in a hearing-aid related field.
• enable you to apply your practical and theoretical knowledge and comprehension as a clinical scientist to all aspects of the rehabilitation needs of adult hearing impaired patients.
• enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from the relevant scientific literature.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to: 

  • equip you with the basic knowledge and understanding required to provide a clinical hearing aid service or to pursue research in a hearing-aid related field.
  • enable you to apply your practical and theoretical knowledge and comprehension as a clinical scientist to all aspects of the rehabilitation needs of adult hearing impaired patients.
  • enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from the relevant scientific literature.

Learning outcomes

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas:

  • how to assess and analyse an individual patient's hearing needs, take an accurate ear impression, select an appropriate NHS hearing aid fitting on the basis of audiometric and other information, select a suitable earmould with appropriate modifications, measure and evaluate the technical performance and check the other functional properties of a hearing aid, both in a coupler and the real ear, provide relevant instruction and information to a new hearing-aid user and optimise the potential benefit from the hearing aid fitting.
  • awareness of the range of different technologies used in the manufacture of commercially available hearing aids and the variation in performance achieved, the benefits and limitations of the various techniques used to assess the outcome of hearing-aid fitting, the existence and relative performance of other hardware such as the range of assistive devices that can be of benefit to hearing-impaired people.
  • awareness of Cochlear Implants, their components, functioning and candidacy for implantations.
  • awareness of social issues that may arise from acquired hearing loss, tinnitus and balance dysfunction.
  • awareness of the range of counselling skills and counselling tools employed by the audiologist.
  • awareness of the importance of good communications strategies and approaches to optimising communication
  • evaluate and synthesise information from the evidence base relating to the above interventions.


Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • synthesise all the relevant information you have obtained about each individual patient and, with reference to the evidence base, recognise and select appropriate techniques for successful management and evaluation of that management.

Practical, subject-specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • take impressions of the ear, test hearing aids, carry out real ear measurements.
  • recognise how hearing loss affects speech perception and language acquisition.

Key transferable skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in:

  • patient handling, patient management, counselling and communication.
  • the use of technical apparatus including computer based procedures.
  • managing patient records and report writing.
  • communication with those having difficulty, including hearing impaired people who may have limited language ability.

introduction:

introduction:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide you with an introduction to the fundamental properties of floating bodies, covering those areas conventionally treated by hydrostatic methods.
  • Provide students with an early insight into the range of tasks involved in the design, construction, management and operation of marine vehicles and an awareness of the engineer's responsibility to society.
learningoutcomes:
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The concepts of area, first and second moments of area and their applications to floating bodies.
  • The concepts of equilibrium and changes in equilibrium of floating bodies.
  • The concepts of static and dynamic stability
  • The use of numerical methods for calculating hydrostatic properties.
  • The different types of marine vehicles and identify characteristics influencing their design. (T, D, AC).
  • The fundamental engineering and economic principles, their application to design and their influence on the development of marine vehicles. (T, D, AC)
  • The role and responsibilities of engineers in society. (T)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the basic principles of equilibrium of floating bodies.
  • Calculate relevant hydrostatic properties using theoretical and numerical methods.
  • Appreciate the technical and economical complexities involved in the design, construction, management and operation of marine vehicles. (T, D, AC)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use basic mathematical techniques, such as integration, to formulate and obtain hydrostatic properties of simple geometries.
  • Use basic numerical methods, such as Simpson's rule, to formulate and obtain hydrostatic properties of hull forms.
  • Use simple measurement techniques to obtain data.
  • Perform independent/directed research. (T, D, AC)
  • Communicate accurately your work in written reports and assignments. (T, D, AC)

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn through tutorials and begin to learn independently.
  • Obtain and accurately analyse data applying your knowledge/understanding of this module.
  • Communicate accurately your work in a written report.
  • Teamworking through laboratory experiment.
  • Ship geometry - lines plan, curve of areas.
  • Ship parameters - form coefficients, fineness coefficients.
  • Equilibrium of floating and submerged bodies - volume, centres of buoyancy and gravity.
  • Properties of irregular shapes - areas, first moments, second moments.
  • Longitudinal and transverse metacentres.
  • Problems involving changes of draught and trim.
  • Numerical integration.
  • Initial transverse stability.
  • Virtual centres - suspended weights, free surface, stability during docking.
  • Large angle stability - GZ curves and effects of changing hull geometry.
  • Dynamic stability - effect of sudden loads, stability criteria.
  • Flooding calculations - added weight, lost buoyancy, floodable length, permeability.
  • Launching calculations and curves.
  • Inclining experiment.

introduction: This module introduces the fundamental principles of aircraft propulsion, and covers air-breathing and rocket propulsion systems. The module focuses on the analysis and determination of thrust and performance criteria for propulsion systems such as ramjets, turbo-jets, turbo-fans and rockets. Three laboratory sessions complement the taught material.
learningoutcomes:
To provide a first course in aerospace propulsion, emphasising the basic principles To introduce the major classes of aerospace propulsion systems, and to develop consistent methods of overall performance evaluation.

Planned learning outcomes
Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
