learningoutcomes:

  • Introduce you to the concepts of waves and electromagnetic fields
  • Enable you to develop your understanding and skills in the operation and calibration of instrumentation relevant to the human neurosensory system

The teaching objectives of this module are to:

  • Introduce methods for analysing mechanical, acoustical, optical and electrical systems, and the operation and calibration of instrumentation according to recognised standards
  • Provide examples that link the material in this module to other programme modules

Planned learning outcomes:

Cognitive (thinking) skills

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module, in the context of psychoacoustics, are to:

  • Inspire an enthusiasm for, and engagement in, scientific exploration and discovery

  • Facilitate the development of your general scientific skills in areas of:
    • Thinking (e.g. curiosity, critical analysis and reasoning, integration of knowledge across disciplines, integration of theory and observations, problem solving strategies, creativity)
    • Working (e.g. technical, collaborative and independent working, project management and data/statistical analysis)
    • Communication (e.g. written, graphical and verbal)

The learning outcomes are: 

  1. Develop specific answerable hypotheses, design an ethical and effective experiment to test them, and articulate and justify your decisions (e.g. demonstrating critical evaluation in the development and design).
  2. Present and justify your interpretations of the outcome of the experiment (e.g. demonstrating critical evaluation of the analysis and the experimental methods [having conducted the experiment] and during contextualisation with existing theory and previous research).
  3. Reflect critically on your learning needs and experiences.
  4. Demonstrate effective scientific thinking, working and communication skills, including collaborative working.

continuousassessment.description: Team assignment: Safety and Ethics application

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Communicate a personal point of view in more than one medium based on critical evaluation of relevant information from several sources
  • Demonstrate scientific knowledge through general reading and understand the role of science in the broader community.
  • Demonstrate transferable skills which will be useful to future employers (e.g. team work, presentation, information technology, writing) via a combination of group work and individual activities.
  • Show an understanding of environmental and ethical accountability for the business community
  • Integrate knowledge of Environmental Sciences by considering topical environmental issues (e.g. climate, resource management, biofuels, energy, food, water, biodiversity) and scientific advances.
  • Summarise facts and data from a range of sources and make evidence-based assessments and judgements
learningoutcomes:
1. To broaden and deepen ES students’ awareness of topical environmental issues and their interrelated nature.
  2. To integrate the knowledge gained over the degree course through consideration of topical environmental issues.
  3. To raise awareness of the attitudes and roles of the range of stakeholders (from private citizens to industry, NGOs, government and research organisations) active in environmental decision-making and implementation.
  4. To prepare for employment through role-playing exercises.
  5. To bring together all ES third year students regularly to exhange information and ideas

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide further Advanced FEA knowledge and techniques for solving complex problems in engineering.
  • To learn the ability to model and to solve complex problems in engineering.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Plates and shell elements
  • Buckling problems
  • Nonlinear problems using FEA
  • The application of the above through workshops and course assignments

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse and build FEA model for complex engineering problems
  • Identify information requirements and sources for design and evaluation
  • Synthesise information and ideas for use in the evaluation process

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Build FEA model for some complex structural problems, such as plate and shell structures, nonlinear and buckling problems
  • Solving complex problems using FEA software
  • Build nonlinear FEA model for engineering problems

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Learn and research independently
  • Collate and synthesise/prioritise information according to task objectives
  • Manipulate and analyse data, selecting and applying appropriate statistical processes
  • Communicate your work in written reports/drawings and verbally
  • Demonstrate study/time management skills, both individually and through team-working.

introduction: In this module the fundamental concepts of aerodynamics are introduced. The main focus is on inviscid, incompressible flow, but compressible and viscous effects will be introduced. The lectures are complemented by 4 laboratory sessions with relevance to the taught material.
learningoutcomes:
To introduce a range of core material in Aerodynamics, including potential flow, simple theories for 2D aerofoils and finite wings, 1D gasdynamics, real (viscous) flow effects, and fundamentals of computational fluid dynamics.

Planned learning outcomes
Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) or Coursework (AC).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The fundamentals of Aerodynamics as applied to aircraft. (T, AC, AE)
  • Potential flow theory and the principles by which potential flow concepts can be applied to predict the approximate behaviour of aerofoils and wings. (T, AC, AE)
  • One-dimensional inviscid high-speed flow (T, AC, AE)
  • Laminar and turbulent boundary layers (T, AC, AE)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Perform simple approximate calculations of combinations of flow elements. (T, AC, AE)
  • Perform simple approximate calculations of aerofoil and finite wing characteristics. (T, AC, AE)
  • Determine flow property variations across shock waves (T, AC, AE)
  • Specify flow properties within a converging/diverging nozzle under design and off-design conditions (T, AC, AE)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Study and learn both independently (D)
  • Communicate work in written reports (D, AC)
  • Demonstrate study and time management skills (D)
  • Solve problems (D, AC, AE)
  • Appreciate some of the technical issues associated with aerospace vehicle design
  • General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Study and learn independently. (D)
  • Communicate work in written reports. (D, AC)
  • Demonstrate study and time management skills. (D)
  • Solve problems systematically. (D, AC, AE)

introduction:
• Introduce advanced methods for stress and deflection analysis of more complex engineering components and systems
  • Develop and deepen knowledge already gained in FEEG1002 of the relationship between composition, microstructure and properties of materials in structural performance
  • Establish a relationship between materials engineering and structural design
  • Prepare students for higher level modules
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Introduce advanced methods for stress and deflection analysis of more complex engineering components and systems
  • Develop and deepen knowledge already gained in FEEG1002 of the relationship between composition, microstructure and properties of materials in structural performance
  • Establish a relationship between materials engineering and structural design
  • Prepare students for higher level modules

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Static and fatigue failure of engineering components subject to combined loading
  • The buckling of imperfect struts subject to axial and eccentric loads
  • The application of energy methods to predict internal forces and deformations in determinate and indeterminate structures
  • Advanced topics in bending and torsion
  • Introduction to continuum mechanics in two and three dimensions
  • Properties of important engineering materials and how they are influenced by heat treatment and manufacture
  • Relationship between understanding of materials properties, service performance and the design process

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Identify regions of high stress and deformation in engineering components and systems, and predict failure by using traditional methods of stress analysis
  • Identify major failure mechanisms and relate to design/service conditions.
  • Critically analyse a situation involving materials and prepare questions to be answered by experts in the field.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Conduct scientific experiments and critically analyse results
  • Produce scientific reports

General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Interpret component/system failure in a wider context
  • Team working through laboratory experiments

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Random processes
  • Spectral analysis
  • Detection, estimation and classification theory
  • Use of statistical signal processing to solve particular problems

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply spectral analysis with understanding of its limitations

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • To provide an introduction to analysis tools and methodologies used in the analysis of random processes.

  • To provide an understanding of spectral analysis.
  • Give an appreciation of the inter-relationship between the problems of detection, estimation and classification.
  • To provide some experience of specific applications.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • Appropriate methods and techniques for statistical data analysis
  • The statistical characteristics of transportation related datasets

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Interpret, summarise and report transportation data using appropriate statistical descriptors
  • Identify and apply appropriate analysis methods for transportation data
  • Formulate appropriate statistical models and test statistical hypotheses
  • Evaluate transportation proposals/schemes with statistical rigour

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Use statistical software to analyse transportation related datasets

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Use creativity and innovation in problem solving
  • Learn and study/research independently

learningoutcomes: This module is designed to provide knowledge of the basic data analysis techniques necessary for understanding and analysing transportation related datasets. This includes identification of suitable analysis methods, applications/calculations of appropriate techniques and models (including with the use of statistical analysis software), interpretation of model and statistical test results and presentation of conclusions.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Economic appraisal and evaluation methods and their application in developing and developed countries.
  • Economic theory as applied to transport, including demand, supply and pricing theory.
  • The links between transport and the wider economy.
  • The role of elasticities.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Utilise demand, supply and pricing theory and elasticities in economic analysis
  • Evaluate the economic impacts of a scheme using cost benefit analysis
  • Appraise the characteristics and issues relating to road pricing
  • Identify /recall the key issues in transport economics and economic appraisal

Key skills

  • Use creativity and innovation in problem solving
  • Learn and study/research independently
  • Manage your time
  • Report your work effectively
  • Collate and synthesise/prioritise information
  • Manipulate and analyse data
  • Develop and use spreadsheets for appraisal
learningoutcomes: This module introduces you to the principles of transport economics and how these principles are applied in practice in transport studies and in scheme appraisals. From an introduction of micro-economic theory, the module then covers economic analysis in practice, including demand and cost forecasting, cost benefit analysis in both developed and developing countries and road pricing. The course also examines the links between transport and the wider economy.

introduction: Module overview
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide students with a broad appreciation of the processes involved in the design of selected spacecraft subsystems
  • Illustrate the application of a systems engineering approach by the use of case studies in each of the major mission types (communications, science, remote sensing and manned missions)
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • How a variety of spacecraft subsystems are designed
  • The key design drivers, interfaces and subsystem interactions involved in the design of a range of different space missions

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the details of spacecraft subsystem design.
  • Appreciate the complexity of the interaction and interfaces between spacecraft subsystems
  • Understand the overall process involved in the design of a spacecraft to meet a set of mission requirements

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Perform design calculations for a range of subsystems
  • Identify design drivers and perform systems trade-offs for different types of space missions

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Solve problems systematically
  • Appreciate other engineers' problems and hence be a better team player
  • Analyse complex engineering systems

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide an understanding of ship propulsors, the components of ship powering and service requirements including estimations of weather margins and conduct of ship trials.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The components of ship powering and the additions which have to be made to the powering of ships in service.
  • The choice of a suitable propulsor and propulsion machinery for a particular task.
  • Propeller design aspects in some depth, including cavitation, strength and off design performance.

Intellectual skills
 Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Describe the components of ship powering, ship propulsion units and available propulsion machinery.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Carry out calculations for the derivation of the components of ship power, service requirements and detailed aspects of propeller and propulsor design.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Apply design and analysis methodologies.

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide students with a sound understanding of modern high performance computing
  • Provide insight into how high performance can be obtained on modern computer architecture
  • Familiarise the students with the techniques of high performance computing
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • Software development processes (T,AC)
  • Parallel programming (T,AC) with OpenMP and MPI
  • Writing parallel algorithms using industry-standard programming techniques (D, AC)
  • A variety of numerical and computational methods relevant to parallel programs (T,AC)

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse problems to identify potential parallelism (T,D,AC)
  • Choose appropriate parallel programming methods to solve numerical problems (T,D,AC)
  • Design and develop software relevant to scientific simulation and modelling processes (D,AC)
  • Translate physical systems into parallel computational models (T,D,AC)
  • Write parallel software (T,D,AC)
  • Plan, design and implement parallel software projects (T,D,AC)
  • Use a range of parallel programming paradigms (D,AC)
  • Decompose a problem into smaller tasks that can be solved in parallel by a computer (D)
  • Exploit multi-core CPUs and clusters (T,D,AC)
  • Use of the Linux Cluster of the University of Southampton, Iridis (T,D)
  • Use of the UK’s HPC machine HECToR (T,D,AC)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

learningoutcomes: To undertake independent, original and critical research on a relevant topic and to communicate the research objectives, methodology, analysis, results and conclusions effectively through the production of a Dissertation.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The principles of parametric and non-parametric array processing algorithms.
  • The performance of a variety of algorithms.
  • Signal processing methods employed in solving standard sonar signal processing tasks.
  • Some of the practical issues associated with implementation of sonar and array processing algorithms.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to sonar signal processing.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Select an appropriate array processing algorithms to solve a specified task.
  • Define a suitable processing chain to solve a variety of sonar signal processing problems.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • A wider appreciation of the issues associated with algorithmic design.
  • Understand some of the practical issues associated with sonar system design.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Provide an overview of array processing techniques, with particular reference to sonar processing and to summarize some of the most common specialist sonar signal processing algorithms.

  • To offer an understanding of array processing algorithms.
  • To provide the student with experience of using the algorithms in a simulation environment.
  • Give an appreciation for the advantages and disadvantages of the various methodologies.
  • Explain some of the basic problems in sonar signal processing and to details standard solutions to some of these problems.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • How problems are addressed in a legal context
  • How the contract will be administered during the execution of a project.
  • How the legal system works
  • The criteria which will lead to the adoption of a particular form of contract.
  • The law of contract.
  • The legal aspects of managing health and safety
  • The legal system and the conceptual structure of law
  • The meaning of the key clauses in the standard forms of contract.
  • The process of interpretation and rule making
  • The province of principle
  • The significance of statutes and case law
  • The way in which the law of contract is implemented in the standard forms of contract.

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Interpret health and safety legislation
  • Critique and analyse unstructured information
  • Evaluate the legal impacts on a particular construction project
  • Interpret individual cases and make informed judgements based on evidence
  • Critique the suitability of alternative forms of contract.
  • Evaluate the contractual risks of the contractual arrangement.
  • Manage health and and safety in a proactive way

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Use case law to analyse contractual relationships.
  • Apply critical and rigorous arguments to justify a particular contractual approach.

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Use effective communication to demonstrate rigorous argument through written reports.
  • Synthesise and abstract knowledge from a range of sources and apply to a given situation.
  • Manage the health and safety of yourself and others.
learningoutcomes: This module will provide a detailed understanding of the law of contracts and how the law applies to civil engineering and construction overall. In addition, health and safety and the tort of negligence will receive particular attention. The module will examine the contractual aspects of the ICE 5th, 6th and 7th forms of contract, the NEC and also make comparisons with JCT. The module will also consider substitute, additional and amended clauses, their legal interpretation and their impact on contract administration.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The contribution of science, engineering or communication to the identification, understanding and, where appropriate, resolution of environmental issues and concerns
  • The importance of environmental concepts, terms, principles and methods and the need for multi- and interdisciplinary approaches
  • The value of an holistic approach to environmental science by using techniques and ideas in different subject disciplines

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use facts and data to support arguments, and assemble and critically evaluate relevant information from several sources and develop a personal point of view
  • Analyse synthesize and summarize information critically
  • Collate and integrate lines of evidence from different disciplines to develop and consolidate knowledge and understanding on an objective basis
  • Produce reasoned arguments, justifying conclusions and recommendations by reference to appropriate analytical frameworks and supporting evidence

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Design plan, execute and write-up a specialist project in environmental science, including use of primary data collected by the students themselves
  • Compile , locate and retrieve data and information from a variety of sources

Key skills

  • IT skills
  • Analyse data using appropriate processes
  • Communicate effectively both orally and in writing
  • Work towards being an effective team member.
learningoutcomes:
The overall aims of the module are:
1.To provide a grounding in research techniques for environmental scientists both in the field and laboratory
2.To refresh familiarity with safety at work requirements, both for fieldwork and lab work under the COSH regulations
3.To prepare you mentally for the Advanced Research Project which most will do in the following summer months
4.To provide transferable skills in team work and individual skills in data collection, data analysis and technical writing.

The aims of this module are to:
  • The aims of this module are to: develop fundamental understanding and the role of materials to allow surface selection for extreme mechanical contacts (in machines).
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • in-service performance of commercial surface engineered materials
  • stress analysis of bulk and coated systems

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • describe failure micromechanisms occurring for a range of service conditions
  • relate these failure micromechanisms to optimised surface engineered microstructures
  • assess likely service failures for a range of service conditions
  • identify appropriate testing approaches to evaluate service performance
  • analyse complex service failure problems and determine the correct surface engineering solution by applying contact mechanics

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Identify failure mechanisms for surface engineered components
  • Suggest possible coatings and surface finishes for a particular wear situation

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • evaluate complex data and propose appropriate engineering solutions
  • discuss problem solving approaches in large and small groups

The aims of this module are to:
  • Enable students to appreciate more thoroughly how and why materials fail in service.
  • Make students aware of how design and manufacturing influence the susceptibility of materials to fail by the various failure modes.
  • Enable students to use good design and the correct use of appropriate manufacturing techniques to reduce the susceptibility to failure of components.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Why components/structures can give unsatisfactory service.
  • What can be done to improve the in service performance of components/structures.
  • Issues involved in predicting the fatigue strength of a component, bolted structure and welded structure.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Critically analyse the factors affecting component/structure performance.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Predict how a component/structure would behave under given service conditions.
  • Predict the fatigue strength of a component with a complex geometry, a bolted structure and a welded structure.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse key factors influencing performance.
  • Problem solving - problem analysis, creative problem solving, decision making.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use advanced techniques for the measurement of aspects of sound and vibration phenomena and data processing.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read and understand the literature relating to experimental studies and measurement techniques in advanced acoustics, vibration and signal processing.
  • Critically review experimental procedures and develop further experimental procedures.

 

Practical, subject specific skills
Having sucessfully completed the module, you will be able to:

Key transferable skills

  • Undertake experimental work.
  • Read and write technical reports.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Develop aspects of sound and vibration measurement, data analysis and interpretation skills together with report writing skills.

 

 

  • To provide you with advanced measurement, data analysis and interpretation tasks under close supervision and to present you with associated reporting tasks.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • How and why the structure and function of freshwater ecosystems differs between standing water (lakes & ponds) and running water (upland and lowland rivers).
  • The application of the theory of fish ecology to fisheries management and conservation
  • The impacts of human activity on the structure of freshwater ecosystems, including remediation, management and restoration of structure and function
  • The interplay between the physics, chemistry and biology of freshwater ecosystems.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Explain how and why the physical, biological and chemical attributes of standing and running waters differ.
  • Identify the main symptoms of degradation of freshwater ecosystems and provide a conceptual framework for management and/or restoration of ecosystems form and/or function.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Identify and recognise the main habitat features of standing waters
  • Use visual observation of standing waters as a means of assessing likely anthropogenic pressures and factors influencing pond ecology
  • Recognise the symptoms of standing water degradation and provide a viable programme of actions to restore favourable conditions.

Key skills

  • Research and Independent Study
  • Write a report
learningoutcomes: The aim of the module is to provide students with an understanding of freshwater ecosystems, fish ecology, and fisheries management, and the factors influencing ecosystem function.

continuousassessment.description: Practical Exercise: production of a report on an urban pond restoration and management

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • To introduce students to basic concepts of race car aerodynamics, in particular ground effect aerodynamics
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The role of aerodynamics in the behaviour of high-performance road vehicles such as Formula One racing cars. The course will focus on wing- and diffuser-in-ground effect aerodynamics and provide an overview of wind-tunnel testing of race vehicles

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
Understand basic racing car aerodynamics and its design implications.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
Perform simple aerodynamic analysis in relation to ground-effect aerodynamics.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Study and learn independently
  • Communicate work in written reports
  • Demonstrate study and time management skills
  • Solve problems
  • Highlight critical issues within a complex environment such as high-performance road-vehicle aerodynamic design

introduction: .
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • enhance your understanding of the taught modules by providing practical and theoretical examples of the principles;
  • develop an understanding of the link between theory and experiment;
  • develop skills in laboratory procedures and techniques and carry these out with due regard to safety;
  • introduce you to reporting of experimental procedure and analysis of data and the scientific writing style;
  • develop your ICT skills;
  • develop your academic skills.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • laboratory and measurement techniques;
  • good practice in recording and reporting experimental procedure and results;
  • an understanding of how to use a common computer operating system;
  • a knowledge of IT packages for report writing, presentation, data analysis and computer programming.

Intellectual skills

  • Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
  • discuss practical examples where the theoretical concepts developed in the other modules apply;
  • communicate scientific information;
  • assess the validity of chemical, biological and mathematical data, experiments, inferences and statements.

Practical skills

  • Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:
  • demonstrate safe and skilful practical techniques;
  • devise and plan experimental activities, selecting appropriate techniques;
  • record observations and measurements methodically and with appropriate precision;
  • interpret, explain, evaluate and communicate results clearly and logically, demonstrating chemical knowledge and understanding.

General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • manage your own learning;
  • apply mathematical methods to solve problems;
  • apply problem solving techniques to familiar and unfamiliar problems;
  • communicate scientific information effectively;
  • record, analyse and evaluate data effectively;
  • use ICT to support your learning.

continuousassessment.description: Coursework assessed through reports, assignments, presentations etc. as required.

introduction:
The course is split into 5 basic sub-topics 24 lectures:

  • Tribometers and profilometers
  • Physics of tribology
  • Principles of modelling: analytical and computational aspects
  • Statistics, design of physical and computational experiments, data mining and analysis
  • Analytical and computational techniques (theory/applications): finite difference, finite element, finite volume, atomistic and molecular dynamics
learningoutcomes:
Aims:

  • Provide theoretical and applied knowledge of the main tribometers and profilometers
  • Provide the ability to select tribometers and profilometers according to their specification and the studied tribological contact
  • Provide the ability to use and interpret tribometer results
  • Provide theoretical and applied knowledge of the physics of tribological phenomena
  • Provide the ability to model key tribological processes occurring within complex tribosystems via advanced mathematical and computational techniques
  • Provide the ability to design and analyse physical and computational tribological experiments
  • Provide the ability to model and to solve complex problems arising in a wide range of industrial tribological applications 

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Types and utilization of tribometers and profilometers
  • Physics of tribology
  • Principles of modelling in tribology: analytical and computational aspects
  • Statistics, design of physical and computational experiments, data mining and data analysis
  • A variety of numerical and computational methods relevant to tribology: finite difference, finite element, finite volume, atomistic and molecular dynamics

Intellectual skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Select tribometers and testing conditions which mimic a specific tribological contact
  • Design and analyse physical and computational experiments to characterise tribological systems
  • Develop analytical and numerical models of tribological systems
  • Analyse and solve complex engineering tribological problems
  • Identify information requirements and sources for design and evaluation
  • Synthesise information and ideas for use in the evaluation process

 

Practical skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use tribometers and profilometers and interpret their results
  • Formulate mathematically a tribological problem using knowledge of the tribophysical phenomena involved
  • Select a sound modelling approach and suitable computational technique(s) to solve a particular tribological problem
  • Design and analyse physical/computational experiments to characterise tribosystems
  • Analyse complex tribosystems using general computational solving techniques and commercial software applications

 

General transferable (key) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Manipulate and analyse data, selecting and applying appropriate statistical processes
  • Communicate your work in written reports/drawings and verbally
  • Demonstrate study/time management skills, both individually and through team-working.

learningoutcomes: This module aims to deliver science in context and allied to research methods and applications; it is intended that this module’s content cuts across and links to other part 1 provision, particularly ENVS1005 (reinforcement of quantitative and analytical methods) and ENVS1007 (training in field, practical and research techniques). A problem- or question-based approach provides a starting point (e.g. highlighting the societal need or concern), combined with a focus on applications.

learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide the student with an advanced knowledge base and understanding  of manoeuvring theory applied to a marine vehicle operating in calm and/or restricted waters.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • Manoeuvring theory based on fundamental principles and concepts providing an appreciation of the limitations of the theory as applied to hull and control surface design.
  • The safe operation of a vessel through the development of stability criteria.
  • The measurement of hydrodynamic data required in an assessment of directional stability.
  • Model or full scale trials to assess the manoeuvrability and controllability of marine vehicles operating in calm and/or restricted waters.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Determine the directional stability of a marine vehicle based on developed criteria.
  • Postulate the necessary experiments to measure hydrodynamic data for manoeuvring and control assessments. 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Calculate the influence of changing control  surface dimensions on stability and design.
     

General transferable (key) skills

introduction:
In its first part this module aims to establish the principles of lubrication, give a detailed description of the lubrication regimes, describe the lubricant types, applications, composition and properties, how they are selected for specific tribological applications, ways to perform an effective lubricant condition monitoring and analysis, lubricant recycling, testing and specifications. 
Students will be able to assess the lubrication regime of tribological systems and select adequate lubricants based on the lubricant physical, chemical and tribological properties. 

They will gain knowledge of how different types of base stocks and additives influence the the properties and performance of a lubricant and will be able to design and/or work with the oil supplier to formulate lubricants which can meet the specific demands of a tribological application. 

They will know how to efficiently and safely use, handle, test and recycle lubricants. 

They will be able to perform adequate oil condition monitoring, understand the results of the oil analysis, assess the state of the machinery and plan the maintenance activity. 

The second part of the module aims to establish an understanding of the tribology encountered in internal combustion engines.  The module will explore the range of types, sizes, speeds and horsepower of engines, where energy is typical lost due to tribological processes and what the common lubrication regimes encountered are.

The components (such as engine bearing, valve train, cylinder liner - piston rings) that encounter tribological problems will be explored to examine designs, the typical wear mechanisms encountered and surface engineering utilised, as well lubrication regimes.

Current advances in automotive design and surface engineering, such as advanced materials design and coatings technology will also be reviewed, as well comparing the relevance of laboratory-based testing with engine performance.

Students will analyse and critically assess the physical and tribological properties of surfaces, hardness, friction and wear in order to be able to develop robust tribologically engineered solutions with enhanced performance and sustainability of machines.  Furthermore, they will be able to deepen their understanding of the interrelation of tribological issues in a design project.
learningoutcomes:
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the following:

  • Desk based research using various forms of media spanning the fields of tribology, lubrication, lubricant chemistry and engineering
  • Lubricant viscosity and its role in the development of Reynolds' equation
  • The main regimes of lubrication and lubricant requirements
  • Lubricant types, composition, properties, applications
  • Lubricant handling, use, disposal and recycling
  • Lubricant condition monitoring and oil analysis
  • Lubricant testing and specifications
  • Basic engine tribology concepts
  • Lubrication regimes in engines
  • Frictional loss in engines
  • Wear mechanisms in engines
  • Design of engine components
  • Material selection of engine components
  • Coating and surface engineering solutions employed in engine tribology

Intellectual skills.  Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:

  • Conduct a thorough literature research of a given research topic
  • Measure and calculate lubricant viscosity in the operating conditions and show its role in the development of Reynolds' equation
  • Calculate film thickness of lubricant
  • Analyse and critically assess the main regimes of lubrication and the lubricant requirements
  • Perform oil condition monitoring, understand the results of the oil analysis, assess the state of the machinery and plan the maintenance activity
  • Identify key tribological components in an engine
  • Identify designs of engine components
  • Understand the application of lubrication theory (e.g. Stribeck Curve/EHL) to specific lubrication regimes of engine components
  • Select suitable materials (and coatings) for engine tribological contacts
  • Understand the principles of tribological testing for engine components
  • Understand the importance of friction and wear of engine components.

Practical skills.  Having successfully completed the module you should be able to:

  • Write a well-structured, clear and concise research review.
  • Demonstrate the ability to present and defend individual research.
  • Use equations to determine lubrication regime.
  • Develop and convey an engine component design concept/approach.

Key skills

  • Exercise independent judgement.
  • Graphical presentation of an engineering concept/approach.
  • Plan and organise both time and resources.
  • Problem analysis and problem solving. Research and independent study.

introduction: A module in which students will learn the basis of ship design whilst considering the economic implications. In parallel the students will undertake the general arrangement of a given ship which will enhance their understanding of some design implications.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • To provide an understanding of basic design methodologies, the components of the ship design process and an appreciation of economic considerations.
  • To give an appreciation of the importance of safety considerations within the ship design process and its impact on operational considerations.
  • Gain an understanding of process of creating and purpose of a General Arrangement drawing (G.A).

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The need to integrate safe design and operation within the ship design process.
  • The design process to subdivide and layout a ship ensuring a space balanced ship which meets statutory and regulatory regulations.
  • Statutory and regulatory requirements in ship design.

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:

  • Apply design tools and synthesise information.

  • Apply the methodology and tools used in the ship design process to a design office based ship General Arrangement.
  • Ensuring the General Arrangement meets the requirements for layout, capacities, choice of deck equipment and machinery, safety and statutory regulations.

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide the student with an advanced knowledge base and understanding of the dynamic behaviour of a rigid or flexible marine structure (mono or multi-hull vessel, offshore) travelling in a random seaway.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • First principles, to develop a hydroelastic theory applied to a uniform flexible beam to illustrate concepts such as free motion in vacuo, natural frequency, principal mode shape, principal coordinate, forced motion in waves, wave loading, resonance, fluid-structure interactions and the differing ways of displaying motion data (ie transfer function, receptance, polar plots, etc).  To extend the concepts with application to real ships with more advanced beam theory, finite elements, etc and to illustrate that there is no increase in conceptual thinking but in data handling when considering symmetric vertical motions of heave, pitch and distortions and antisymmetric coupled motions of sway, yaw, roll and distortions. To show that traditional seakeeping theory is a subset of motions within the unified theory.  By examining different ship types to demonstrate the influence of natural frequency, mode shape, resonance, etc on fatigue, the safe passage of vessels and design.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Gain increased power of analysis, critical assessment and the nuances of dynamics in relation to ship design and operation.
  • Derive statistical measures to assess wave loading, ship behaviour in different sea states and to compare performance between ships.
  • Appreciate the dynamic behaviour of differing ship types through synthesis of concepts into engineering application and design.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Solve complex dynamic problems.
  • Use statistical data to compare dynamic behaviour of different ship types.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse and solve complex engineering problems.

a. an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • The implications of using feedback on accuracy and stability of a control system.
  • Classical control actions and the consequences for accuracy, speed of response and stability.
  • The construction and operation of a d.c. servomechanism for position and speed control.
  • Block diagrams for representation of system dynamics and simple algebraic manipulations for block diagram reduction.
  • Dynamic modelling of engineering system elements and the analogies between mechanical, electrical, fluid and thermal systems.
  • Transfer function representation of system dynamics.
  • State variable representation of system dynamics and the relationship with transfer functions.
  • Poles and zeros and the relationship between system poles, transient response and stability.
  • Closed loop system stability assessment using the Routh-Hurwitz technique.
  • The root locus technique for predicting dynamic performance of closed loop systems.
  • Frequency domain analysis of system dynamics using polar and Bode representations.
  • Closed loop system stability and relative stability prediction using the frequency domain.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Read, understand and interpret the literature relating to classical control system design.
  • Recognise and select appropriate techniques for the modelling and analysis of classical, closed loop control systems.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Select appropriate control actions for classical control systems.
  • Design an experiment to investigate the dynamic performance of a d.c. servomechanism.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be better able to:

  • Carry out experimental frequency analysis of dynamic systems.
  • Plot system dynamics in the form of root loci, polar and Bode diagrams.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to

  • To introduce students to the principles of feedback control.
  • To demonstrate and investigate its application to servomechanisms.

  • To introduce the student to the formal basis for the analysis and design of dynamic systems which include feedback.
  • To revise and extend the modelling of dynamic systems elements and to draw analogies between mechanical, electrical, fluid and thermal systems.
  • To describe time and frequency domain methods of dynamic system analysis.
  • To give the student direct experience of a d.c. servomechanism.

introduction: This module aims to provide the most important knowledge and intellectual skills for students to be able to assess earthquake hazards and ground motions (shaking), and then to analyse and design structures for earthquake resistance. It also enables students to understand the economic and social context of earthquake engineering on a global scale.
learningoutcomes: This module aims to provide the most important knowledge and intellectual skills for students to be able to assess earthquake hazards and ground motions (shaking), and then to analyse and design structures for earthquake resistance. It also enables students to understand the economic and social context of earthquake engineering on a global scale. The module covers the analysis of structures subject to earthquake-induced loads as well as the evaluation of different design techniques including equivalent static analysis, response spectra, capacity design and pushover analysis. Implementation in practice includes introduction to earthquake design codes (such as IBC and EC8) and ductile detailing practice for reinforced concrete buildings in earthquake zones

introduction: This module further develops the fundamental concepts underpinning aircraft flight, stability, and control. The focus is initially on capturing the aerodynamic behaviour of lifting and control surfaces within simple mathematical models leading to simple 3-DOF equations of motion for a rigid aircraft. Ideas of equilibrium and trim are captured by determining the steady control inputs needed to fly simple steady trajectories, including feasibility, conditional static stability, and drag optimality. These concepts are extended into three-dimensions using ideas of motion as a geometric transformation leading to the full 6-DOF dynamical systems, state space formulation, and flight simulators; linearization about a steady trajectory leads to linear state space models, characteristic motions and dynamic stability, response to gusts, stability augmentation, and linear control. The lectures are complemented by laboratory sessions and coursework with relevance to the taught material.
learningoutcomes:
To develop further a range of core concepts in mechanics of flight, stability, and control of aircraft, including simple aerodynamic modelling, 3-DOF and full 6_DOF equations of motion for a rigid aircraft, Euler angles and rates, equilibrium and trim, drag, static and dynamic stability, flight simulation, characteristic motions and eigenmodes, response to disturbances, control inputs for simple steady trajectories, stability augmentation.

Planned learning outcomes
Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
• Aerodynamic and control forces acting on aircraft, including high-lift devices, origins of drag. (T, A)
• Aircraft equilibrium, control/trim inputs required for steady trajectories, static stability, optimality. (T, A)
• Description of motion in three-dimensions, Euler angles and rates, full 6-DOF equations for rigid symmetrical aircraft, state space formulation, solution in the time domain and flight simulation. (T, A)
• Linearised state space equations for small disturbances about a steady trajectory, aerodynamic derivatives, longitudinal and lateral characteristic motions, eigenmodes, dynamic stability. (T, A)
• Control inputs for steady sideslip, coordinated turns. Linear response to control inputs and wind gusts. Simple state feedback and autopilots. (T, A)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:
• Perform simple calculations of aircraft trim, lift and drag, static stability. (T, A)
• Perform simple calculations and computations of aircraft characteristic motions in both time-domain and in terms of eigenmodes. (T, A)
• Analyse aircraft lift/drag/moment data. (T, A)

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:
• Study and learn both independently (D)
• Communicate work in written reports (D, A)
• Demonstrate study and time management skills (D)
• Solve problems (D, A)
• Appreciate some of the technical issues associated with aerospace vehicle design

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, the student will be able to:
• Study and learn independently. (D)
• Communicate work in written reports. (D, A)
• Demonstrate study and time management skills. (D)
• Solve problems systematically. (D, A)

learningoutcomes: The module aims to give students an introduction to the principles of Soil Mechanics and acquaint them with the approaches that allow us to quantify and predict the behaviour of different types of soils in a variety of loading conditions. More particularly, the module aims to: a) introduce students to the behaviour of soils as engineering materials, and b) give them the basic analytical methods that apply the concepts introduced to standard engineering problems, like foundations, retaining walls, groundwater flow and ground settlement calculations.

introduction: An introduction to the principles and practical application of hearing aids, cochlear implants and assistive listening devices.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to : • introduce you to non-linear analogue and digital hearing instruments, assistive listening devices and other specialist devices including cochlear implants, and show you how their performance is measured, how they are prescribed, fitted and verified. • enable you to apply your theoretical knowledge and comprehension as an Audiologist to all aspects of the rehabilitation needs of adult patients. • enable you to develop skills to critically evaluate and analyse information from books, web based learning and relevant scientific literature.

Learning outcomes

Knowledge and understanding

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding in the following areas: • function, specification, measurement, prescription, fitting and verification of non-linear analogue and digital hearing aids. • the range, scope and selection of assistive listening devices. • the function of, and candidacy for, CROS, bone conduction and bone anchored hearing aids (BAHA). • the function of, candidacy for, implantation, tuning and assessment for, cochlear implantation.

Cognitive (thinking) skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • synthesise all the relevant information you have obtained about an individual with hearing difficulties • With reference to the evidence base, select and evaluate alternative methods of management • Select and plan appropriate interventions.

Practical, subject-specific skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to: • contribute to the planning and management of individuals with hearing difficulties using your knowledge and understanding of advanced hearing aid devices, assistive listening devices and other specialist devices in order to determine the most appropriate management strategy. Key transferable skills

Key transferable skills

Having successfully completed the module, you will have skills in: • patient handling, rehabilitation planning, patient management • synthesis of data from the research literature.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To present the fundamental scientific principles and engineering techniques used in radar and communication systems and to relate them to the current and future systems used by civilian and military aircraft.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • radar and communication systems and techniques in use at present so that students can gain a clear understanding of the principles involved, the methods of implementation and how the systems relate to the operation of military and civilian aircraft radar. The use of countermeasures and stealth will also be covered. Future requirements will be discussed to indicate the development required of current and future radar systems. Advanced radars used for imaging will also be included.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • understand the key factors determining the design of communications and radar systems used in aircraft
  • apply the radar equation and set up and solve problems involving radar range, noise, and radar cross-section
  • have an appreciation of the issues concerned with stealth, protection and countermeasures

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • study and learn independently;
  • solve problems.

The aims of this module are to:
  • To provide a first course in aerospace propulsion, emphasising the basic principles
  • To introduce the major classes of aerospace propulsion systems, and to develop consistent methods of overall performance evaluation.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Knowledge of typical propulsion system configurations and their performance indicators.
  • Understanding how the typical aerospace propulsion systems work.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Calculate fundamental performance indicators of an entire engine (such as specific thrust and specific fuel consumption) for given flight regime, engine design parameters, and performance indicators of the engine components (such as the flight Mach number, compressor pressure ratio, and turbine efficiency etc.)
  • Evaluate intuitively how, and explain why variations in the flight regime, design parameters and components performance affect the overall performance of the engine.


Practical skills [where appropriate]
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • N/A


General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use the Web-based tools in learning.

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

 

  • The range of presentational formats used.
  • The use of SPSS in data presentation and analysis.
  • The variety of data types commonly recorded.

 

 

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Identify data types and classify these according to a scale of measurement.
  • Use facts and data properly to support arguments, and assemble and critically evaluate relevant information from several sources and develop a personal point of view.
  • Apply an appropiate presentational format to a wide variety of newly acquired data.
  • Select an appropiate statistical procedure given a variety of data sets and scenarios.
  • Collect and integrate several lines of evidence to formulate and test hypotheses.

 

 

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

 

  • Use enter and code a range of data types using SPSS.
  • Produce a range of presentational formats and statistical analysis for transfer into presentations, essays, reports and dissertations
  • Construct reports using statistical nomenclature.

 

 

Key skills

 

  • Interpret numerical data.
  • Analyse information critically.
  • Use information and communication technology to acquire, collate, process and analyse data and information, and to make the results available to others in written or electronic form.
  • Prepare, process, interpret and present data, using appropriate qualitative and quantitative techniques and ICT packages.
learningoutcomes: The module will introduce you to a number of key statistical concepts and data presentation formats. The module begins with an examination of a variety of data types using scales of measurements to define the nature and properties of data you are likely to encounter. Emphasis is placed on distinguishing between population parameters and sample statistics and to explore the nature of distributions. This is aided via the introduction of a powerful graphics package, a component part of SPSS; a dedicated statistical software. You will become familiar with the concept of central tendancy and the measurement of variation and how these may be presented graphically. Emphasis is placed on information transfer to aid in the construction of presentations, essays, reports and dissertation. Central to the enture module is your exposure of to SPSS in which you will become familiar. However, in addition to computer technology the module aims at improving your skills in the use of hand calculator for use in laboratory and the field applications. A significant portion of the module is given to developing your understanding of a variety of common statistical procedures including establishing the presence and strength of a realtionship between variables and standard approaches for determing if significant differences exist between groups within a variety of experimental designs. Central to this is the concept of hypotheses testing. The overall aim of the module is to empower you with the ability to understand statistical nomenclature in the literature and to carry out statistical analysis and data presentation for use throughout your undergraduate career and beyond.

introduction:
Acoustical engineers are required to demonstrate knowledge of the basic methods for acquisition, analysis, processing and reproduction of audio data and audio material. They must be familiar with the theoretical fundamentals of these techniques and be capable of applying them to practical engineering problems.

The first part of this module covers a range of basic signal processing techniques for the analysis and processing of audio signals. The theory is reviewed of a number of topics that students have encountered in other modules with emphasis on their relevance to audio technologies, and elements of digital signal processing are introduced to students. Students are trained, especially through computing tutorials, to apply these theoretical tools to practical engineering problems.

The second part of the module covers the fundamentals of electroacoustical transduction (especially microphones and loudspeakers) and of systems and technologies for audio capturing and reproduction. The concept of channel quality and its objective descriptors (noise, distortion, etc.) are explained and put into relation to human sound perception, some aspects of which are introduced.

It is emphasized that the theory of some of the topics is covered in this module at a basic level. An advanced theoretical analysis of these topics will be provided during the third- and fourth-year modules.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are:

  1. to convey an understanding of a range of signal processing basic principles and tools
  2. to endow students with the ability to apply these tools to the analysis and processing of audio signals
  3. to teach, through theory and applications, the fundamentals of linear system analysis
  4. to introduce students to the operating principles of a number of electroacoustical transducers and data acquisition systems
  5. to develop an understanding of the fundamentals of audio reproduction

On successful completion of the module students will be able:

  1. to demonstrate a working knowledge of Fourier analysis and to apply it the analysis of audio signals and systems
  2. to demonstrate a working knowledge of the concept of convolution, of the convolution theorem and of some of their applications
  3. to demonstrate a knowledge of the basics of digital signals and digital signal processing
  4. to demonstrate a working knowledge of the basic theory of digital filters and to apply it to the processing of audio signals
  5. to apply the basic signal processing techniques to estimate the impulse response and frequency response function of a linear, time-invariant system and to interpret the results
  6. to describe and explain the basic operating principles of a range of electroacoustical transducers and systems for data acquisition and reproduction
  7. to understand the metrics and specifications associated with audio channel quality
  8. to demonstrate a knowledge of the operating principles of sound reproduction and of its limitations

introduction:
Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, students will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Concepts fundamental to signal modelling, signal generation and signal classification.
  • The similarities and differences between continuous and discrete signals.
  • The rationale for and interpretation of Fourier analysis.
  • The methods used to describe random signals.
  • The effects of filters.

Cognitive (thinking) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Appreciate the significance and importance of time series data.
  • Interpret information contained in time histories through transformation (Fourier) methods.

Practical, subject specific skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Understand and recognise the various classes of signals.
  • Understand the need for both time and frequency domain descriptions of data and to decide which description is most appropriate for a particular application.
  • Interpret results taking due account of the several sources of error that arise and to quantify those errors.
  • Have a practical understanding of single-channel and dual-channel frequency domain concepts such as a frequency spectrum, spectral density, cross-spectrum and coherence.

Key transferable skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Use Fourier transform methods for all classes of data in any application.
learningoutcomes:
The aims of this module are to:

  • Introduce the concepts that are basic to the acquisition, analysis and interpretation of time histories.
  • Ensure that students acquire an appreciation of the generic nature of signal processing and the relevance and applicability of the methodology to engineering and many other fields.
  • Ensure that students develop sufficient mathematical expertise to underpin the study of signal processing.

  • Students new to this topic very often find it 'difficult', 'confusing' and very soon get lost in new terminology, unfamiliar concepts and the need to use mathematical language and methods. The most important outcome of this course is that students should be able to distinguish between conceptual ideas and principles and the mathematical language. This will lead to being able to see the wide relevance of the subject and confidence in being able to tackle data analysis problems systematically.

introduction: The aim of this module is to understand the relationship between environmental management and law.
learningoutcomes:
• To understand the relationship between environmental management and law
  • To understand the theory behind national and international environmental legislation, environmental policy, and the environmental regulatory system
  • To understand the relationship between the range of stakeholders and the application of law and management
  • To develop a practical understanding of environmental legislation and to understand how it can lead to improved environmental performance in business and society
  • To understand the role of environmental management systems in reducing environmental impacts from business

The aims of this module are to:
  • introduce topics related to analysis of compressible flows, including treatment of nozzle flows, shock waves and Prandtl-Meyer flows
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Key: Taught (T), Developed (D) and Assessed either by Examination (AE) Coursework (AC) or Presentation (AP).

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: 

  • inviscid compressible high-speed flows (T, A)

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you are expected to:

  • determine flow property variations across shock waves and expansions (T, A)
  • specify flow properties within a converging/diverging nozzle under design and off-design conditions (T, A)
  • predict lift and drag on subsonic and supersonic aerofoils (T, A)

Practical and General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you are expected to:

  • study and learn both independently (D)
  • communicate work in written reports (D, A)
  • demonstrate study and time management skills (D)
  • solve problems (D, A)
  • appreciate some of the technical issues associated with aerospace vehicle design

The aims of this module are to:
  • Provide the students with an introduction to nuclear reactor technology with particular emphasis of power generation, hydrogen production, desalination and waste transmutation.
  • Introduce the students to the key disciplines of reactor physics and thermal hydraulics as applied in the design of a nuclear reactor system for power generation, hydrogen production, desalination and waste transmutation.
  • Introduce the students to the industry-standard codes used in the design process of nuclear reactors.
Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and Understanding:

  • Describe the current status of nuclear reactors for electricity generation, powering of desalination and hydrogen production plants, marine power plants and special nuclear reactors for transmutation of nuclear waste.
  • Appreciate the advantages and disadvantages of different types of nuclear reactor for applications in a sustainable energy economy.
  • For the Pressurised Water Reactor (PWR) specifically, develop a detailed understanding of the underlying reactor physics and engineering aspects of the design, sufficient to predict the steady state and dynamic response of the plant.
  • Understand the underlying principles of energy conversions systems for transforming nuclear heat into power and compare and contrast their applicability to electricity generation, powering of desalination and hydrogen production plants and special nuclear reactors for transmutation of nuclear waste.
  • Identify the key safety issues associated with nuclear power generation.
  • Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the application of industry-standard design codes for nuclear reactors.
  • Describe in outline the development of new-generation reactors and assess their application for electricity generation, powering of desalination and hydrogen production plants and special nuclear reactors for transmutation of nuclear waste.

Intellectual Skills:

  • Apply the knowledge gained in the module to develop a mathematical model capable of predicting the steady-state and dynamic response of a nuclear power plants.
  • Critically appraise different reactor types, including novel designs, for various applications in a sustainable energy economy.

Practical Skills:

  • Using a 'basic principles' PWR simulator, operate a reactor during reactor start up, normal power operation, abnormal operations and shut down and explain the observed behaviour in terms of the underlying reactor physics and engineering.

The aims of this module are to:

  • Allow students to analyse and design advanced power, propulsion, heating, and cooling systems using thermodynamic principles.

Objectives (planned learning outcomes)

Knowledge and understanding
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:

  • Theoretical and practical constraints on the performance of gas-turbines, steam and vapour cycles, and combined cycles.
  • Current technologies for improving the performance of power and refrigeration plant.
  • Thermodynamic properties of real fluids – including liquid-vapour systems, mixtures, and non-ideal gases – and their use in engineering calculations.
  • Environmental and economic factors driving energy technology.

Intellectual skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Compute changes in thermodynamic properties due to: mixing, throttling, compression, expansion, heat exchange, and combustion.
  • Determine operating conditions for thermodynamic cycles in order to optimise power or efficiency. Design machines for improved efficiency using thermodynamic reasoning.

Practical skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Undertake experimental evaluation of thermal plant and energy systems.
  • Evaluate fluid properties manually and computationally, by using the equation-of-state, property tables, or charts.

General transferable (key) skills
Having successfully completed the module, you will be able to:

  • Analyse experimental data and summarise findings.
  • Use a computer to perform parametric design studies.
  • Devise appropriate plots for analysis, communication, and justification of design decisions.
  • Communicate in a clear, structured and efficient manner.
